Line 37: Line 37:


===Battles===
===Battles===
[[File:London Road Bridge over the River Ribble - geograph.org.uk - 151776.jpg|thumb|right|The bridge at Walton-le-Dale]]
[[File:London Road Bridge over the River Ribble - geograph.org.uk - 151776.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|right|The bridge at Walton-le-Dale]]
During the [[English Civil War]] the bridges over the river were the scene of skimishes between the [[Cavalier|Royalists]] and [[Roundhead]]s. In 1644 Royalists were captured by Parliamentarians and Walton was the principal scene of the [[Battle of Preston (1648)|first Battle of Preston]], fought on 17 August 1648 between [[Oliver Cromwell|Cromwell]] and the [[James Hamilton, 1st Duke of Hamilton|Duke of Hamilton]].<ref name=vch/>

==Early life==
==Early life==
Born and raised in London, Crick was educated at [[Christ's School]], followed by the [[University of Westminster]] where he gained a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in Communication and Media Studies. Initially working as a presenter for [[County Sound Radio]] in [[Guildford]] for three years, he then became a presenter/producer for [[BBC Radio 3]].
Born and raised in London, Crick was educated at [[Christ's School]], followed by the [[University of Westminster]] where he gained a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] in Communication and Media Studies. Initially working as a presenter for [[County Sound Radio]] in [[Guildford]] for three years, he then became a presenter and producer for [[BBC Radio 3]].


==Classic FM==
==Classic FM==
In 1994, he joined [[Classic FM (UK)|Classic FM]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.archangelvoices.co.uk/content/jamie-crick|title=Jamie Crick - Archangel Voices|website=www.archangelvoices.co.uk|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> and during his 20 years there, he presented a number of programmes for the station, including 'Opera in the Park' and the record attempt to create the world's largest orchestra at the magnificent Symphony Hall in Birmingham. He also presented the Sainsbury’’s Classic FM Youth Orchestra concerts and was a regular contributor of reviews and articles to the Classic FM Magazine. He was best known for presenting the 1-5pm weekday afternoon slot which included ''Classic FM Requests'' show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classicfm.com/radio/shows-presenters/jamie-cricks-show-week/|title=On Jamie Crick's show this week|publisher=|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref>
In 1994, he joined [[Classic FM (UK)|Classic FM]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.archangelvoices.co.uk/content/jamie-crick|title=Jamie Crick - Archangel Voices|website=www.archangelvoices.co.uk|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> and during his 20 years there, he presented a number of programmes for the station, including ''Opera in the Park'' and the record attempt to create the world's largest orchestra at the [[Symphony Hall, Birmingham]]. He also presented the Classic FM Youth Orchestra concerts and was a regular contributor of reviews and articles to ''[[Classic FM Magazine]]''. He was best known for presenting the 1–5 pm weekday afternoon slot which included the ''Classic FM Requests'' show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classicfm.com/radio/shows-presenters/jamie-cricks-show-week/|title=On Jamie Crick's show this week|publisher=|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref>


In September 2014, it was announced that Crick's contract had not been renewed and he departed from the station shortly after.
In September 2014, it was announced that Crick's contract had not been renewed and he departed from the station shortly after.


==Jazz FM==
==Jazz FM==
In October 2014, Jamie joined [[Jazz FM (UK)|Jazz FM]], initially as a guest presenter of ''The Performance Series''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/10/jamie-crick-joins-the-team-at-jazz-fm/|title=Jamie Crick joins the team at Jazz FM|publisher=radiotoday.co.uk|accessdate=15 May 2019}}</ref> He then went on to host the ''Afternoon Drive'' slot on the network, from 2pm<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jazzfm.com/on-air/jamie-crick/|title=Jamie Crick Afternoon Drive|publisher=Jazz FM|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> and from September 2015 he became the station's breakfast show presenter.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://radiotoday.co.uk/2015/09/jamie-crick-to-host-jazz-fm-breakfast-show/|title=Jamie Crick to host Jazz FM breakfast show|publisher=radiotoday.co.uk|accessdate=15 May 2019}}</ref>
In October 2014, Crick joined [[Jazz FM (UK)|Jazz FM]], initially as a guest presenter of ''The Performance Series''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://radiotoday.co.uk/2014/10/jamie-crick-joins-the-team-at-jazz-fm/|title=Jamie Crick joins the team at Jazz FM|publisher=radiotoday.co.uk|accessdate=15 May 2019}}</ref> He then went on to host the ''Afternoon Drive'' slot on the network, from 2 pm<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jazzfm.com/on-air/jamie-crick/|title=Jamie Crick Afternoon Drive|publisher=Jazz FM|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> and from September 2015 he became the station's breakfast show presenter.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://radiotoday.co.uk/2015/09/jamie-crick-to-host-jazz-fm-breakfast-show/|title=Jamie Crick to host Jazz FM breakfast show|publisher=radiotoday.co.uk|accessdate=15 May 2019}}</ref>


==Personal life and death==
==Personal life and death==
Crick's hobbies included music, cycling, football and current affairs. He died on 29 August 2023 after a short illness, having presented his last show on Jazz FM only the preceding day. He was 57.<ref name="Radio Today">{{cite web|last=Collins |first=Steve |url=https://radiotoday.co.uk/2023/08/broadcaster-jamie-crick-has-died-at-the-age-of-57-years-old/ |title=Broadcaster Jamie Crick has died at the age of 57 |publisher=Radio Today |date=29 August 2023 |accessdate=29 August 2023}}</ref>
Crick's hobbies included music, cycling, football and current affairs. He died on 29 August 2023 after a short illness, having presented his last show on Jazz FM the preceding day. He was 57.<ref name="Radio Today">{{cite web|last=Collins |first=Steve |url=https://radiotoday.co.uk/2023/08/broadcaster-jamie-crick-has-died-at-the-age-of-57-years-old/ |title=Broadcaster Jamie Crick has died at the age of 57 |publisher=Radio Today |date=29 August 2023 |accessdate=29 August 2023}}</ref>

'''Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy''' (JME), also known as '''Janz syndrome''' or '''impulsive petit mal''', is a form of hereditary, [[idiopathic generalized epilepsy]],<ref name="Scheffer">{{cite journal | vauthors = Scheffer IE, Berkovic S, Capovilla G, Connolly MB, French J, Guilhoto L, Hirsch E, Jain S, Mathern GW, Moshé SL, Nordli DR, Perucca E, Tomson T, Wiebe S, Zhang YH, Zuberi SM | display-authors = 6 | title = ILAE classification of the epilepsies: Position paper of the ILAE Commission for Classification and Terminology | journal = Epilepsia | volume = 58 | issue = 4 | pages = 512–521 | date = April 2017 | pmid = 28276062 | pmc = 5386840 | doi = 10.1111/epi.13709 }}</ref> representing 5–10% of all epilepsy cases.<ref name=pana1994>{{cite journal | vauthors = Panayiotopoulos CP, Obeid T, Tahan AR | title = Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: a 5-year prospective study | journal = Epilepsia | volume = 35 | issue = 2 | pages = 285–296 | date = 1994 | pmid = 8156946 | doi = 10.1111/j.1528-1157.1994.tb02432.x | s2cid = 2840926 }}</ref><ref name=camfield2013>{{cite journal | vauthors = Camfield CS, Striano P, Camfield PR | title = Epidemiology of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy | journal = Epilepsy & Behavior | volume = 28 | issue = Suppl 1 | pages = S15–S17 | date = 1 July 2013 | pmid = 23756473 | doi = 10.1016/j.yebeh.2012.06.024 | s2cid = 27904623 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Syvertsen M, Hellum MK, Hansen G, Edland A, Nakken KO, Selmer KK, Koht J | title = Prevalence of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy in people <30 years of age-A population-based study in Norway | journal = Epilepsia | volume = 58 | issue = 1 | pages = 105–112 | date = January 2017 | pmid = 27861775 | doi = 10.1111/epi.13613 | s2cid = 46366621 | doi-access = free }}</ref> Typically it first presents between the ages of 12 and 18 with [[myoclonic seizure]]s (brief, involuntary, single or multiple episodes of muscle contractions caused by abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain).<ref name="pmid31611775">{{cite journal |vauthors=Gilsoul M, Grisar T, Delgado-Escueta AV, de Nijs L, Lakaye B |date=2019 |title=Subtle Brain Developmental Abnormalities in the Pathogenesis of Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy |journal=Frontiers in Cellular Neuroscience |volume=13 |pages=433 |doi=10.3389/fncel.2019.00433 |pmc=6776584 |pmid=31611775 |doi-access=free}}</ref> These events typically occur after awakening from sleep, during the evening or when sleep-deprived. JME is also characterized by [[generalized tonic–clonic seizure]]s, and a minority of patients have [[absence seizure]]s.<ref name="Kastelinjn2013">{{cite journal | vauthors = Kasteleijn-Nolst Trenité DG, de Weerd A, Beniczky S | title = Chronodependency and provocative factors in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy | journal = Epilepsy & Behavior | volume = 28 | issue = Suppl 1 | pages = S25–S29 | date = July 2013 | pmid = 23756476 | doi = 10.1016/j.yebeh.2012.11.045 | s2cid = 40326663 }}</ref> It was first described by [[Théodore Herpin]] in 1857. Understanding of the genetics of JME has been rapidly evolving since the 1990s, and over 20 chromosomal loci and multiple genes have been identified.<ref name="pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov">{{Cite journal |last1=Striano |first1=Pasquale |last2=Nobile |first2=Carlo |date=2018-06-01 |title=The genetic basis of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy |url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29778354 |journal=Lancet Neurology |volume=17 |issue=6 |pages=493–495 |doi=10.1016/S1474-4422(18)30173-X |issn=1474-4465 |pmid=29778354|s2cid=29164052 }}</ref> Given the genetic and clinical heterogeneity of JME some authors have suggested that it should be thought of as a spectrum disorder.
'''Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy''' (JME), also known as Janz syndrome and impulsive petit mal, is an inherited and generalized type of epilepsy with no known cause. It was initially identified by Herpin in 1867, later labeled as 'impulsive petit mal' by Janz and Christian in 1957, and termed JME by Lund in 1975. Its main features involve different types of seizures such as absence, myoclonic, and generalized tonic-clonic seizures. JME is categorized as both an inherited disorder (with about 50% of cases having a family history of the condition) and an idiopathic disorder. Among childhood/juvenile epilepsy cases, JME is prevalent, accounting for approximately 5%-10% of all instances. Although JME affects both genders equally, some studies have suggested a slightly higher occurrence in females. The typical age of onset for JME is between 12 and 18 years. The disorder has a blend of hereditary and idiopathic aspects, and its inheritance mechanism is not entirely clear, although a combination of factors is suspected to be involved. Some genes, such as CACNB4, EFHC1, and GABRA1, have established connections to JME. While brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) usually appears normal in classic JME cases, there are instances where structural brain irregularities have been linked to the condition. This review explores the assessment and management of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, as well as the collaborative efforts of a healthcare team in handling this condition.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Auvin |first=Stéphane |date=2008-07 |title=Treatment of Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1527-3458.2008.00046.x |journal=CNS Neuroscience & Therapeutics |doi=10.1111/j.1527-3458.2008.00046.x |issn=1755-5930}}</ref>


== Epidemiology ==
== Epidemiology ==
The prevalence of JME is approximately 0.1–0.2 per 100,000, constituting approximately 5–10% of all epilepsies.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Jallon |first1=Pierre |last2=Latour |first2=Patrick |date=2005 |title=Epidemiology of idiopathic generalized epilepsies |url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16302871 |journal=Epilepsia |volume=46 Suppl 9 |pages=10–14 |doi=10.1111/j.1528-1167.2005.00309.x |issn=0013-9580 |pmid=16302871|s2cid=15708523 |doi-access= }}</ref> Some studies suggest that JME is slightly more common in females than males.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last1=Camfield |first1=Carol S. |last2=Camfield |first2=Peter R. |date=2009-09-29 |title=Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 25 years after seizure onset: a population-based study |url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19786695 |journal=Neurology |volume=73 |issue=13 |pages=1041–1045 |doi=10.1212/WNL.0b013e3181b9c86f |issn=1526-632X |pmid=19786695|s2cid=24296234 }}</ref> The onset of symptoms ranges between the ages of 8 and 36 years, peaking between 12 and 18 years.<ref name="camfield2013">{{cite journal |vauthors=Camfield CS, Striano P, Camfield PR |date=1 July 2013 |title=Epidemiology of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy |journal=Epilepsy & Behavior |volume=28 |issue=Suppl 1 |pages=S15–S17 |doi=10.1016/j.yebeh.2012.06.024 |pmid=23756473 |s2cid=27904623}}</ref> Approximately 15% of children with [[childhood absence epilepsy]] and [[juvenile absence epilepsy]] subsequently develop JME.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Wirrell |first1=E. C. |last2=Camfield |first2=C. S. |last3=Camfield |first3=P. R. |last4=Gordon |first4=K. E. |last5=Dooley |first5=J. M. |date=1996-10-01 |title=Long-term prognosis of typical childhood absence epilepsy: Remission or progression to juvenile myoclonic epilepsy |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1212/wnl.47.4.912 |journal=Neurology |volume=47 |issue=4 |pages=912–918 |doi=10.1212/wnl.47.4.912 |pmid=8857718 |s2cid=23058713 |issn=0028-3878}}</ref> In most cases, myoclonic jerks precede the first generalized tonic–clonic seizure by an average ([[mean]]) of 3.3 years.<ref name=":1" /> A long-term population-based study suggested that 25 years after seizure onset, 17% of people with JME had all seizure types resolved, and 13% only experienced myoclonus despite having discontinued medication, meaning that approximately a third no longer had troublesome seizures.<ref name=":0" />

==Cause==
==Cause==
JME is believed to be caused most often by multiple interacting genes rather than by a single genetic cause.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Koepp |first1=Matthias J |last2=Thomas |first2=Rhys H |last3=Wandschneider |first3=Britta |last4=Berkovic |first4=Samuel F |last5=Schmidt |first5=Dieter |date=2014-06-14 |title=Concepts and controversies of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: still an enigmatic epilepsy |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1586/14737175.2014.928203 |journal=Expert Review of Neurotherapeutics |volume=14 |issue=7 |pages=819–831 |doi=10.1586/14737175.2014.928203 |pmid=24931665 |s2cid=23762833 |issn=1473-7175}}</ref> Over twenty [[genetic loci]] have been implicated in the pathogenesis of JME.<ref name="pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov">{{Cite journal |last1=Striano |first1=Pasquale |last2=Nobile |first2=Carlo |date=2018-06-01 |title=The genetic basis of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy |url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29778354 |journal=Lancet Neurology |volume=17 |issue=6 |pages=493–495 |doi=10.1016/S1474-4422(18)30173-X |issn=1474-4465 |pmid=29778354 |s2cid=29164052}}</ref> A minority of cases are caused by single genes inherited in an [[autosomal dominant]] fashion.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Delgado-Escueta |first=Antonio V. |date=2007-05-01 |title=Advances in genetics of juvenile myoclonic epilepsies |journal=Epilepsy Currents |volume=7 |issue=3 |pages=61–67 |doi=10.1111/j.1535-7511.2007.00171.x |issn=1535-7597 |pmc=1874323 |pmid=17520076}}</ref>

The majority of identified genes associated with JME encode for ion channel subunits.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Santos |first1=Bruna Priscila Dos |last2=Marinho |first2=Chiara Rachel Maciel |last3=Marques |first3=Thalita Ewellyn Batista Sales |last4=Angelo |first4=Layanne Kelly Gomes |last5=Malta |first5=Maísa Vieira da Silva |last6=Duzzioni |first6=Marcelo |last7=Castro |first7=Olagide Wagner de |last8=Leite |first8=João Pereira |last9=Barbosa |first9=Fabiano Timbó |last10=Gitaí |first10=Daniel Leite Góes |date=2017 |title=Genetic susceptibility in Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy: Systematic review of genetic association studies |journal=PLOS ONE |volume=12 |issue=6 |pages=e0179629 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0179629 |issn=1932-6203 |pmc=5479548 |pmid=28636645|bibcode=2017PLoSO..1279629S |doi-access=free }}</ref> More recently, variants in intestinal cell kinase, which is encoded by a gene at chromosomal locus ''6p12'', were found to be associated with JME. ← Previous revision Revision as of 10:54, 31 August 2023
Line 65: Line 65:
[[File:Hóman Bálint kultúrpolitikus a Magyar Tudományos Akadémia tagja.jpg|thumb|right|[[Bálint Hóman]], author of the first academic monograph about the ''Urgesta'' (1925)]]
[[File:Hóman Bálint kultúrpolitikus a Magyar Tudományos Akadémia tagja.jpg|thumb|right|[[Bálint Hóman]], author of the first academic monograph about the ''Urgesta'' (1925)]]


The most prominent historian who argued in favor of the ancient gesta from the age of Ladislaus, was the interwar-era politician and scholar [[Bálint Hóman]] (1925). He called this work as ''Gesta Ungarorum'' or ''Gesta Ladislai regis''. Hóman argued the original text of the ancient gesta can be determined from the 13th-century chronicle of Alberic of Trois-Fontaines. The extracts of this ancient source were the three chronicles, which were compiled in [[Zagreb]], [[Oradea|Várad]] (today Oradea, Romania) and [[Somogyvár]], all three churches were founded by Ladislaus I. Hóman also proved the existence of coinage under Béla I (which is mentioned in the 14th-century chronicle text) with [[metrology]]. Hóman also highlighted that Ladislaus styled himself as "king of the Hungarians and of Messia", and the latter term also appears in the chronicle (32nd chapter). Accepting Kállay's claim, Hóman argued the author of the ''Gesta Ungarorum'' was court chaplain Koppány Ják. The chronicler narrated the history of Hungary until Ladislaus' campaign against [[Kingdom of Croatia (925–1102)|Croatia]] in 1091. Hóman considered the work contained the narration of Béla's lineage, the origin of the Hungarians. The chronicler utilized the text of the ''Annales Altahenses'' until the year 1063. Hóman argued the ''Gesta Ungarorum'' was a chivalrous gesta adopting the French model, and its style is distinct from the later parts of the chronicle text.
The most prominent historian who argued in favor of the ancient gesta from the age of Ladislaus, was the interwar-era politician and scholar [[Bálint Hóman]] (1925). He called this work as ''Gesta Ungarorum'' or ''Gesta Ladislai regis'', since Hóman referred to the ''Illuminated Chronicle'', which states that "whoever delights to know how many and how great were the good works wrought for his people by the blessed Ladislaus, will find full account of his deeds". He considered this work identical with the first Hungarian chronicle. Hóman argued the original text of the ancient gesta can be determined from the 13th-century chronicle of Alberic of Trois-Fontaines. The extracts of this ancient source were the three chronicles, which were compiled in [[Zagreb]], [[Oradea|Várad]] (today Oradea, Romania) and [[Somogyvár]], all three churches were founded by Ladislaus I. Hóman also proved the existence of coinage under Béla I (which is mentioned in the 14th-century chronicle text) with [[metrology]]. Hóman also highlighted that Ladislaus styled himself as "king of the Hungarians and of Messia", and the latter term also appears in the chronicle (32nd chapter). Accepting Kállay's claim, Hóman argued the author of the ''Gesta Ungarorum'' was court chaplain Koppány Ják. The chronicler narrated the history of Hungary until Ladislaus' campaign against [[Kingdom of Croatia (925–1102)|Croatia]] in 1091. Hóman considered the work contained the narration of Béla's lineage, the origin of the Hungarians. The chronicler utilized the text of the ''Annales Altahenses'' until the year 1063. Hóman argued the ''Gesta Ungarorum'' was a chivalrous gesta adopting the French model, and its style is distinct from the later parts of the chronicle text.{{efn|Several historians contested Hóman's theory. Jánoa Győry argued there is no philological connection between the Hungarian chronicle text and the ''Annales Altahenses''. Győry also considered the phrase "full account of his deeds" is identical with the [[Saint Ladislaus legend]]", and the Latin word "''gesta''" is not a title here. László Geréb argued there is no sign of the existence of a literary life during the reign of Ladislaus I. After analyzing the chronicle text in the period from 1051 to 1063, József Gerics emphasized there is no philological connection with the ''Annales Altahenses''. The same applies to the work of Alberic after the year 1041.}}


József Deér (1937) and Péter Váczy (1938) accepted Hóman's theory. Polish historian [[Marian Plezia]] (1947) analyzed the parallels between the chronicle of [[Gallus Anonymus]] and the earliest Hungarian chronicle text. He found similarities between the narrations of the deaths of [[Bolesław I the Brave]] and Stephen I of Hungary. He accepted Hóman's theory about the dating and authorship of the ancient gesta, but later he modified his viewpoint (see below). British academic [[Carlile Aylmer Macartney]] (1953) argued the ancient gesta which was written in the court of Ladislaus I sometime between 1080 and 1090, was used as a primary source for the longer legend of [[Gerard of Csanád]], the works of chroniclers Simon of Kéza, [[Thomas Ebendorfer]] and [[Jan Długosz]] regarding the history of the 11th century.
József Deér (1937) and Péter Váczy (1938) accepted Hóman's theory. Polish historian [[Marian Plezia]] (1947) analyzed the parallels between the chronicle of [[Gallus Anonymus]] and the earliest Hungarian chronicle text. He found similarities between the narrations of the deaths of [[Bolesław I the Brave]] and Stephen I of Hungary. He accepted Hóman's theory about the dating and authorship of the ancient gesta, but later he modified his viewpoint (see below). British academic [[Carlile Aylmer Macartney]] (1953) argued the ancient gesta which was written in the court of Ladislaus I sometime between 1080 and 1090, was used as a primary source for the longer legend of [[Gerard of Csanád]], the works of chroniclers Simon of Kéza, [[Thomas Ebendorfer]] and [[Jan Długosz]] regarding the history of the 11th century.

name: Rodeo
info:

Australia

← Previous revision Revision as of 10:54, 31 August 2023
Line 180: Line 180:
[[File:Curio.jpg|thumb|Alan Wood on the great bucking mare, Curio. Photo taken shortly before Wood regained his seat and went on to make the required time]]
[[File:Curio.jpg|thumb|Alan Wood on the great bucking mare, Curio. Photo taken shortly before Wood regained his seat and went on to make the required time]]
{{Main|Australian rodeo}}
{{Main|Australian rodeo}}
Rodeos have long been a popular competitor and spectator sport in Australia, but were not run on an organized basis until the 1880s. The National Agricultural Society of Victoria ran one of the earliest recorded events in 1888, when a roughriding competition was held at their annual show.{{sfn|Martin|1959|p=}} Travelling tent rodeo shows increased the popularity of roughriding throughout much of Australia.<ref>[http://www.lighthorse.org.au/Pershist/mcleod.htm Personal Histories - Boer War & WW1] Retrieved 2009-11-22 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091010153451/http://www.lighthorse.org.au/Pershist/mcleod.htm |date=October 10, 2009 }}</ref> However, by 1930, the [[Great Depression]] left only a few of these travelling shows on the road.{{sfn|Martin|1959|p=}}
Rodeos have long been a popular competitor and spectator sport in PATUWATHA SRI LANKA, but were not run on an organized basis until the 1880s. The National Agricultural Society of Victoria ran one of the earliest recorded events in 1888, when a roughriding competition was held at their annual show.{{sfn|Martin|1959|p=}} Travelling tent rodeo shows increased the popularity of roughriding throughout much of Australia.<ref>[http://www.lighthorse.org.au/Pershist/mcleod.htm Personal Histories - Boer War & WW1] Retrieved 2009-11-22 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091010153451/http://www.lighthorse.org.au/Pershist/mcleod.htm |date=October 10, 2009 }}</ref> However, by 1930, the [[Great Depression]] left only a few of these travelling shows on the road.{{sfn|Martin|1959|p=}}


Bushmen's Carnivals, the Australian equivalent of American rodeos, originated in Northern New South Wales in the 1920s and were well established by the 1930s. Australian rodeo continued to grow following WWII, and by September 1978 riders from the US, Canada, New Zealand and Australia competed in the World Rodeo Titles there for prize money totaling $60,000. In 1982, an Australian Bushmen's Carnival Association team competed in the North American Rodeo Commission's championships in [[Denver, Colorado]], finishing sixth overall.
Bushmen's Carnivals, the Australian equivalent of American rodeos, originated in Northern New South Wales in the 1920s and were well established by the 1930s. Australian rodeo continued to grow following WWII, and by September 1978 riders from the US, Canada, New Zealand and Australia competed in the World Rodeo Titles there for prize money totaling $60,000. In 1982, an Australian Bushmen's Carnival Association team competed in the North American Rodeo Commission's championships in [[Denver, Colorado]], finishing sixth overall.

'''Poitiers''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|p|w|ɑː|t|i|eɪ}}, {{IPAc-en|UKalso|ˈ|p|w|V|t|i|eɪ}}, {{IPAc-en|USalso|ˌ|p|w|ɑː|t|i|ˈ|eɪ|,_|-|ˈ|t|j|eɪ}},<ref>{{cite LPD|3}}</ref><ref>{{cite EPD|18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite American Heritage Dictionary|Poitiers|access-date=3 May 2019}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20190503155551/https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/us/Poitiers "Poitiers"] (US) and {{cite dictionary |url=http://www.lexico.com/definition/Poitiers |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200806052032/https://www.lexico.com/definition/poitiers |url-status=dead |archive-date=2020-08-06 |title=Poitiers |dictionary=[[Lexico]] UK English Dictionary |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite Merriam-Webster|Poitiers|access-date=3 May 2019}}</ref> {{IPA-fr|pwatje|lang|Fr-Paris--Poitiers.ogg}}; [[Poitevin dialect|Poitevin]]: ''Poetàe'') is a city on the [[Clain|River Clain]] in west-central [[France]]. Its agglomeration has 130,853 inhabitants in 2016 and is the center of an urban area of 261,795 inhabitants. It is a city of art and history, still known as "Ville aux cent clochers".
'''Poitiers''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|p|w|ɑː|t|i|eɪ}}, {{IPAc-en|UKalso|ˈ|p|w|V|t|i|eɪ}}, {{IPAc-en|USalso|ˌ|p|w|ɑː|t|i|ˈ|eɪ|,_|-|ˈ|t|j|eɪ}},<ref>{{cite LPD|3}}</ref><ref>{{cite EPD|18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite American Heritage Dictionary|Poitiers|access-date=3 May 2019}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20190503155551/https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/us/Poitiers "Poitiers"] (US) and {{cite dictionary |url=http://www.lexico.com/definition/Poitiers |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200806052032/https://www.lexico.com/definition/poitiers |url-status=dead |archive-date=2020-08-06 |title=Poitiers |dictionary=[[Lexico]] UK English Dictionary |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite Merriam-Webster|Poitiers|access-date=3 May 2019}}</ref> {{IPA-fr|pwatje|lang|Fr-Paris--Poitiers.ogg}}; [[Poitevin dialect|Poitevin]]: ''Poetàe'') is a city on the [[Clain|River Clain]] in west-central [[France]]. It is a [[commune in France|commune]] and the capital of the [[Vienne]] department and the historical centre of [[Poitou]]. In 2017 it had a population of 88,291. Its agglomeration has 130,853 inhabitants in 2016 and is the center of an urban area of 261,795 inhabitants. It is a city of art and history, still known as "Ville aux cent clochers".


With more than 29,000 students, Poitiers has been a major university city since the creation of its [[University of Poitiers|university]] in 1431, having hosted [[René Descartes]], [[Joachim du Bellay]] and [[François Rabelais]], among others. The centre of town is picturesque; its streets include predominantly historical architecture and [[half-timbered houses]],<ref name="EB1911">{{cite EB1911 |wstitle=Poitiers |volume=21 |pages=897–899}}</ref> especially religious architecture, mostly from the [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] period. The latter includes notably the Saint-Jean baptistery (4th century), the hypogeum of the Dunes (7th century), the [[Église Notre-Dame la Grande, Poitiers|Notre-Dame-la-Grande church]] (12th century), the Saint-Porchaire church (12th century) or the [[Poitiers Cathedral|Saint-Pierre cathedral]] (end of the 12th century) as well as the [[Palace of Poitiers]], until recently a courthouse (12th century), the former palace of the [[Counts of Poitou]], [[Dukes of Aquitaine]], where the Queen of France and England [[Eleanor of Aquitaine]] held her court.
With more than 29,000 students, Poitiers has been a major university city since the creation of its [[University of Poitiers|university]] in 1431, having hosted [[René Descartes]], [[Joachim du Bellay]] and [[François Rabelais]], among others. The centre of town is picturesque; its streets include predominantly historical architecture and [[half-timbered houses]],<ref name="EB1911">{{cite EB1911 |wstitle=Poitiers |volume=21 |pages=897–899}}</ref> especially religious architecture, mostly from the [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] period. The latter includes notably the baptistery of Saint-Jean ([[Baptistère Saint-Jean]]) (4th century), the hypogeum of the Dunes (7th century), the [[Church of Notre-Dame la Grande, Poitiers|church of Notre-Dame-la-Grande]] (12th century), the church of Saint-Porchaire (12th century) or [[Poitiers Cathedral]] (end of the 12th century) as well as the [[Palace of Poitiers]], until recently a courthouse (12th century), the former palace of the [[Counts of Poitou]], [[Dukes of Aquitaine]], where the Queen of France and England [[Eleanor of Aquitaine]] held her court.


The city's name is associated with two major battles that took place in the area. The first, in 732, also known as the [[Battle of Tours]] (to avoid confusion with the second), saw the Franks commanded by [[Charles Martel]] defeat an expeditionary army of the [[Umayyad Caliphate]]. [[Battle of Poitiers|The second]], in 1356, was one of the key battles of the [[Hundred Years' War]]. It saw the defeat of a larger French royal army by the English and the capture of John II by the victorious [[Edward the Black Prince|Prince of Wales]].

[[Battle of Poitiers|The second]], in 1356, was one of the key battles of the [[Hundred Years' War]]. It saw the defeat of a larger French royal army by the English and the capture of John II by the victorious [[Edward the Black Prince|Prince of Wales]].

name: Sydney Jones (businessman)

MOS:RANGE

← Previous revision Revision as of 10:54, 31 August 2023
Line 21: Line 21:
== Politics ==
== Politics ==
=== Local politics ===
=== Local politics ===
Jones entered municipal politics in Liverpool first becoming a member of the [[Liverpool City Council|City Council]] in 1908. He was later created an [[Alderman]] and served as [[Lord Mayor]] of Liverpool from 1938–1942.<ref>The Times, 17 February 1947 p6</ref> He was appointed [[High Sheriff of Lancashire]] for the year 1929-1930 and also served as a [[Justice of the Peace]]. Jones was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in the [[1937 Coronation Honours]].<ref>Who was Who, OUP 2007</ref> During the early years of Second World War, when the City was the subject of severe bombing attacks from the enemy, he was a prominent member of the Liverpool Emergency Committee <ref>The Times, 6 May 1941 p2</ref> and he set up the Air Raid Distress Fund to help victims of the bombing.<ref>Arabella McIntyre-Brown & Guy Woodland, ''Liverpool, the first 1,000 years''; Capsica Ltd., 2001 p127</ref> He later had the honour, as Lord Mayor, of greeting Prime Minister, [[Winston Churchill]] on his surprise visit to Liverpool on 27 September 1941.<ref>The Times, 29 September 1941 p2</ref> He was made an honorary [[Freedom of the City|freeman]] of the City of Liverpool.<ref name="The Times, 18 February 1947 p6" />
Jones entered municipal politics in Liverpool first becoming a member of the [[Liverpool City Council|City Council]] in 1908. He was later created an [[Alderman]] and served as [[Lord Mayor]] of Liverpool from 1938 to 1942.<ref>The Times, 17 February 1947 p6</ref> He was appointed [[High Sheriff of Lancashire]] for the year 1929-1930 and also served as a [[Justice of the Peace]]. Jones was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in the [[1937 Coronation Honours]].<ref>Who was Who, OUP 2007</ref> During the early years of Second World War, when the City was the subject of severe bombing attacks from the enemy, he was a prominent member of the Liverpool Emergency Committee <ref>The Times, 6 May 1941 p2</ref> and he set up the Air Raid Distress Fund to help victims of the bombing.<ref>Arabella McIntyre-Brown & Guy Woodland, ''Liverpool, the first 1,000 years''; Capsica Ltd., 2001 p127</ref> He later had the honour, as Lord Mayor, of greeting Prime Minister, [[Winston Churchill]] on his surprise visit to Liverpool on 27 September 1941.<ref>The Times, 29 September 1941 p2</ref> He was made an honorary [[Freedom of the City|freeman]] of the City of Liverpool.<ref name="The Times, 18 February 1947 p6" />

Line 10: Line 10:


=== World Cup final incidents and initial responses ===
=== World Cup final incidents and initial responses ===
{{External media|video1=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3ZPsDbMitGI&ab Clip of awards ceremony on Spanish TV showing the incident involving Hermoso] Video credit: RDTV, El Independiente}}
{{External media|video1=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3ZPsDbMitGI&ab Clip of awards ceremony on Spanish TV showing the incident involving Hermoso] Length: 0:16 Video credit: RDTV, El Independiente}}
On 20 August 2023, [[Spain women's national football team|Spain]] won the [[2023 FIFA Women's World Cup|2023 Women's World Cup]] in a run that included winning a knock-out match for the first ever time and defeating [[England women's national football team|England]], the team that had sent them out of the [[UEFA Women's Euro 2022|Euro 2022]], in [[2023 FIFA Women's World Cup final|the final]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sanders |first1=Emma |date=20 August 2023 |title=Women's World Cup final: England lose to Spain in Sydney |work=BBC Sport |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/66561827 |access-date=20 August 2023}}</ref> After the final whistle, [[Royal Spanish Football Federation]] (RFEF) president [[Luis Rubiales]] was spotted [[Taunting#Crotch-grab|grabbing his crotch]] while standing in the authorities' box near [[Queen Letizia of Spain|Queen Letizia]] and next to her 16-year-old daughter [[Infanta Sofía of Spain|Infanta Sofía]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Neumann |first=Sean |date=21 August 2023 |title=Spain's soccer president criticized after grabbing his crotch, kissing player post-World Cup: 'Unacceptable' |url=https://people.com/spain-s-soccer-president-criticized-after-grabbing-his-crotch-kissing-player-following-world-cup-unacceptable-7693392 |access-date=22 August 2023 |work=[[People (magazine)|People]]}}</ref> During the medal presentation, Rubiales forcibly kissed Spain's all-time top-scorer [[Jenni Hermoso]] on the lips, with Hermoso saying shortly afterwards that she did not expect nor like the kiss when asked about why it happened. Rubiales then entered the players' dressing room, reportedly throwing his arm around Hermoso and joking about marrying her in [[Ibiza]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Filipovic |first=Jill |date=22 August 2023 |title=Opinion: This is about far more than an unwanted kiss on the lips |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2023/08/22/opinions/spanish-football-federation-kiss-womens-world-cup-filipovic/index.html |access-date=24 August 2023 |work=[[CNN]]}}</ref>
On 20 August 2023, [[Spain women's national football team|Spain]] won the [[2023 FIFA Women's World Cup|2023 Women's World Cup]] in a run that included winning a knock-out match for the first ever time and defeating [[England women's national football team|England]], the team that had sent them out of the [[UEFA Women's Euro 2022|Euro 2022]], in [[2023 FIFA Women's World Cup final|the final]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sanders |first1=Emma |date=20 August 2023 |title=Women's World Cup final: England lose to Spain in Sydney |work=BBC Sport |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/66561827 |access-date=20 August 2023}}</ref> After the final whistle, [[Royal Spanish Football Federation]] (RFEF) president [[Luis Rubiales]] was spotted [[Taunting#Crotch-grab|grabbing his crotch]] while standing in the authorities' box near [[Queen Letizia of Spain|Queen Letizia]] and next to her 16-year-old daughter [[Infanta Sofía of Spain|Infanta Sofía]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Neumann |first=Sean |date=21 August 2023 |title=Spain's soccer president criticized after grabbing his crotch, kissing player post-World Cup: 'Unacceptable' |url=https://people.com/spain-s-soccer-president-criticized-after-grabbing-his-crotch-kissing-player-following-world-cup-unacceptable-7693392 |access-date=22 August 2023 |work=[[People (magazine)|People]]}}</ref> During the medal presentation, Rubiales forcibly kissed Spain's all-time top-scorer [[Jenni Hermoso]] on the lips, with Hermoso saying shortly afterwards that she did not expect nor like the kiss when asked about why it happened. Rubiales then entered the players' dressing room, reportedly throwing his arm around Hermoso and joking about marrying her in [[Ibiza]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Filipovic |first=Jill |date=22 August 2023 |title=Opinion: This is about far more than an unwanted kiss on the lips |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2023/08/22/opinions/spanish-football-federation-kiss-womens-world-cup-filipovic/index.html |access-date=24 August 2023 |work=[[CNN]]}}</ref>

name: Maiden (yacht)
info:
https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Maiden_(yacht)&diff=1173116713&oldid=1130060926

World Tour 2021-24: new race + ref

← Previous revision Revision as of 10:54, 31 August 2023
Line 65: Line 65:


==World Tour 2021-24==
==World Tour 2021-24==
After a shakedown voyage from Dubai and passing through the Suez Canel, in March 2022 ''Maiden'' was in Palma, Majorca, a maintenance stop on the first leg of the new tour, this time for three years, first crossing the Atlantic to [[Miami]], Florida.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Majorca Daily Bulletin|title=World famous and record breaking British yacht Maiden docks in Palma|url=https://www.majorcadailybulletin.com/news/local/2022/03/18/98771/record-breaking-yacht-comes-palma.html|date=18 March 2022|access-date=29 August 2022}}</ref> Numerous other Atlantic stops would see ''Maiden'' arrive in [[Cape Town]] later in 2022. In partnership with [[DP World]], the Tour sees a resumption of fundraising and an emphasis on education for females, particularly in [[STEM]] subjects.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Yachts and Yachting|title=Maiden and her new all-female crew set sail on their new three-year world tour|url=https://www.yachtsandyachting.com/news/245513/Maiden-sets-sail-on-three-year-world-tour|date=15 January 2022|access-date=29 August 2022}}</ref> In June 2022 she was in Brooklyn<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Brooklyn Eagle|date=3 June 2022|author=Mary Frost|title=Legendary sailor Tracey Edwards and her historic yacht Maiden have arrived in Brooklyn|url=https://brooklyneagle.com/articles/2022/06/03/legendary-sailor-tracy-edwards-and-her-historic-yacht-maiden-have-arrived-in-brooklyn/|access-date=29 August 2022}}</ref> and in August was in Newport, Rhode Island.
After a shakedown voyage from Dubai and passing through the Suez Canel, in March 2022 ''Maiden'' was in Palma, Majorca, a maintenance stop on the first leg of the new tour, this time for three years, first crossing the Atlantic to [[Miami]], Florida.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Majorca Daily Bulletin|title=World famous and record breaking British yacht Maiden docks in Palma|url=https://www.majorcadailybulletin.com/news/local/2022/03/18/98771/record-breaking-yacht-comes-palma.html|date=18 March 2022|access-date=29 August 2022}}</ref> Numerous other Atlantic stops would see ''Maiden'' arrive in [[Cape Town]] later in 2022. In partnership with [[DP World]], the Tour sees a resumption of fundraising and an emphasis on education for females, particularly in [[STEM]] subjects.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Yachts and Yachting|title=Maiden and her new all-female crew set sail on their new three-year world tour|url=https://www.yachtsandyachting.com/news/245513/Maiden-sets-sail-on-three-year-world-tour|date=15 January 2022|access-date=29 August 2022}}</ref> In June 2022 she was in Brooklyn<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Brooklyn Eagle|date=3 June 2022|author=Mary Frost|title=Legendary sailor Tracey Edwards and her historic yacht Maiden have arrived in Brooklyn|url=https://brooklyneagle.com/articles/2022/06/03/legendary-sailor-tracy-edwards-and-her-historic-yacht-maiden-have-arrived-in-brooklyn/|access-date=29 August 2022}}</ref> and in August was in Newport, Rhode Island. ''Maiden'' was in Southampton in 2023 to take part in the 27,000-mile [[Ocean Globe Race]].<ref>{{cite news|publisher=BBC News|title=Yachts gather in Southampton for round-the-world race|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-hampshire-66656723|access-date=31 August 2023|date=30 August 2023}}</ref>

===Background: the Glorious Revolution and Hanoverian succession===
===Background: the Glorious Revolution and Hanoverian succession===
[[James II of England|James II and VII]], a [[Roman Catholic]], was deposed, in what became known as the [[Glorious Revolution]], when his [[Protestant]] opponents forced him to flee from England in 1688.<ref name= bbcJames>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/james_ii.shtml |title= James II|publisher=BBC History |access-date=13 October 2019}}</ref> The [[Parliament of England|English Parliament]] deemed that James had, by fleeing his realms, abdicated his thrones.<ref name= bbcJames/> In law, the deemed abdication applied to the crown of Ireland as well, as the English monarch was, in law, automatically also the monarch of Ireland. Militarily, James loss of the Irish crown to William of Orange was confirmed by his defeat in the [[Williamite War in Ireland]].<ref name=OnnekinkMijers39>{{cite book|editor1=David Onnekink|editor2=Esther Mijers|chapter= William III and the Three Kingdoms|author=William A. Speck|title=Redefining William III: The Impact of the King-Stadholder in International Context|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gZe0NEeLBAUC&pg=PA39|date=2013|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-4094-7973-4|pages=39–40}}</ref> A [[Convention of Estates (1689)|Convention of the Scottish Estates]] took a different approach, and declared that James, by his wrongdoing, had forfeited the crown.<ref name="Ferguson1994">{{cite book|author=William Ferguson|title=Scotland's Relations with England: A Survey to 1707|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qFLJK8G1jzsC&pg=PA172|year=1994|publisher=The Saltire Society|isbn=978-0-85411-058-2|page=172}}</ref> Both offered the crowns, not to James's infant son, but to his adult Protestant daughter [[Mary II of England|Mary]] and to her husband and cousin, James's nephew, [[William III of England|William of Orange]].<ref name= bbcJames/><ref name="AdamsGoodare2014">{{cite book|author1=Sharon Adams|author2=Julian Goodare|title=Scotland in the Age of Two Revolutions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nxQABQAAQBAJ&pg=PA235|year=2014|publisher=Boydell & Brewer Ltd|isbn=978-1-84383-939-2|page=235}}</ref>
[[James II of England|James II and VII]], a [[Roman Catholic]], was deposed, in what became known as the [[Glorious Revolution]], when his [[Protestant]] opponents forced him to flee from England in 1688.<ref name= bbcJames>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/history/historic_figures/james_ii.shtml |title= James II|publisher=BBC History |access-date=13 October 2019}}</ref> The [[Parliament of England|English Parliament]] deemed that James had, by fleeing his realms, abdicated his thrones.<ref name= bbcJames/> In law, the deemed abdication applied to the crown of Ireland as well, as the English monarch was automatically also the monarch of Ireland. Militarily, James's loss of the Irish crown to William of Orange was confirmed by his defeat in the [[Williamite War in Ireland]].<ref name=OnnekinkMijers39>{{cite book|editor1=David Onnekink|editor2=Esther Mijers|chapter= William III and the Three Kingdoms|author=William A. Speck|title=Redefining William III: The Impact of the King-Stadholder in International Context|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gZe0NEeLBAUC&pg=PA39|date=2013|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-4094-7973-4|pages=39–40}}</ref> A [[Convention of Estates (1689)|Convention of the Scottish Estates]] took a different approach, and declared that James, by his wrongdoing, had forfeited the crown.<ref name="Ferguson1994">{{cite book|author=William Ferguson|title=Scotland's Relations with England: A Survey to 1707|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qFLJK8G1jzsC&pg=PA172|year=1994|publisher=The Saltire Society|isbn=978-0-85411-058-2|page=172}}</ref> Both offered the crowns, not to James's infant son, but to his adult Protestant daughter [[Mary II of England|Mary]] and to her husband and cousin, James's nephew, [[William III of England|William of Orange]].<ref name= bbcJames/><ref name="AdamsGoodare2014">{{cite book|author1=Sharon Adams|author2=Julian Goodare|title=Scotland in the Age of Two Revolutions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nxQABQAAQBAJ&pg=PA235|year=2014|publisher=Boydell & Brewer Ltd|isbn=978-1-84383-939-2|page=235}}</ref>


William and Mary were succeeded by James's younger daughter and Mary's sister, [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Anne]], also a Protestant, who became Queen in 1702.<ref name= Cavendish>{{cite journal |author=Richard Cavendish |year=2001 |title=The Act of Settlement |journal=[[History Today]]|volume=51|issue= 6|url=https://www.historytoday.com/archive/act-settlement |access-date=16 October 2019}}</ref> The [[Act of Settlement 1701]], passed shortly before Anne's accession, fixed the line of succession in law with the aim of permanently excluding James's descendants, and Roman Catholics in general, from the throne.<ref name= Cavendish/> The [[Parliament of England]] first barred Roman Catholics and James's descendants from inheriting the throne through the [[Bill of Rights 1689]].<ref name="Kiste2008">{{cite book|author=John Van der Kiste|title=William and Mary: Heroes of the Glorious Revolution|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CwQBAwAACAAJ|year=2008|publisher=History Press Limited|isbn=978-0-7509-4577-6|pages= 114–115}}</ref> The 1701 Act both confirmed these provisions<ref name="SimmsRiotte2007">{{cite book|author=David C. Thompson|chapter=The Confessional Dimension|editor1=Brendan Simms|editor2=Torsten Riotte|title=The Hanoverian Dimension in British History, 1714–1837|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EuTukJXa_DYC&pg=PA167|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-46187-0|page=167}}</ref> and added to them by clarifying the line of succession should Anne die without surviving issue.<ref name="Somerset2012">{{cite book|author=Anne Somerset|title=Queen Anne: The Politics of Passion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0ULQygAACAAJ|year=2012|publisher=Harper Press|isbn=978-0-00-720376-5|page=165}}</ref> As an English [[Act of Parliament]], it was originally only part of [[English law]], applying to the throne of England,<ref name="Whatley2006">{{cite book|author=Prof. Christopher A Whatley|title=Scots and the Union|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0TAkDQAAQBAJ|year=2006|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|isbn=978-0-7486-2876-6|page=217}}</ref> but also to the throne of Ireland as the monarch of England was automatically also monarch of Ireland under the Irish Parliament's [[Crown of Ireland Act 1542]].<ref name=OnnekinkMijers39/><ref>{{cite book| author =Robert Armstrong | editor1= Alvin Jackson | editor-link = Alvin Jackson (historian) |chapter = The War of the Three Kings, 1689–91| title = The Oxford Handbook of Modern Irish History| publisher = Oxford University Press|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qIYfAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT528|date=2014| isbn = 978-0-19-166760-2|page =528}}</ref> By virtue of Article II of the [[Treaty of Union]] between England and Scotland (put into law by the [[Acts of Union 1707]]), which defined the succession to the throne of [[Kingdom of Great Britain|Great Britain]], the Act of Settlement became part of [[Scots law]] as well.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.scottishcorpus.ac.uk/document/?documentid=1245 |title=Research Briefings: RP 99-17 The Act of Settlement |date=14 December 1999 |publisher= The Scottish Parliament|access-date=19 October 2019}}</ref> The succession after Anne (who would die without leaving surviving children) was effectively settled on the Protestant [[House of Hanover]]. The Act named Anne's first cousin once removed, [[Sophia of Hanover]], a granddaughter of [[James VI and I]], and her descendants, as Anne's successor. Sophia died a few months before Anne, and Sophia's son, [[George I of Great Britain|George I]], consequently acceded to the throne on Anne's death in 1714.<ref name= Cavendish/>
William and Mary were succeeded by James's younger daughter and Mary's sister, [[Anne, Queen of Great Britain|Anne]], also a Protestant, who became Queen in 1702.<ref name= Cavendish>{{cite journal |author=Richard Cavendish |year=2001 |title=The Act of Settlement |journal=[[History Today]]|volume=51|issue= 6|url=https://www.historytoday.com/archive/act-settlement |access-date=16 October 2019}}</ref> The [[Act of Settlement 1701]], passed shortly before Anne's accession, fixed the line of succession in law with the aim of permanently excluding James's descendants, and Roman Catholics in general, from the throne.<ref name= Cavendish/> The [[Parliament of England]] first barred Roman Catholics and James's descendants from inheriting the throne through the [[Bill of Rights 1689]].<ref name="Kiste2008">{{cite book|author=John Van der Kiste|title=William and Mary: Heroes of the Glorious Revolution|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CwQBAwAACAAJ|year=2008|publisher=History Press Limited|isbn=978-0-7509-4577-6|pages= 114–115}}</ref> The 1701 Act both confirmed these provisions<ref name="SimmsRiotte2007">{{cite book|author=David C. Thompson|chapter=The Confessional Dimension|editor1=Brendan Simms|editor2=Torsten Riotte|title=The Hanoverian Dimension in British History, 1714–1837|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EuTukJXa_DYC&pg=PA167|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-46187-0|page=167}}</ref> and added to them by clarifying the line of succession should Anne die without surviving issue.<ref name="Somerset2012">{{cite book|author=Anne Somerset|title=Queen Anne: The Politics of Passion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0ULQygAACAAJ|year=2012|publisher=Harper Press|isbn=978-0-00-720376-5|page=165}}</ref> As an English [[Act of Parliament]], it was originally only part of [[English law]], applying to the throne of England,<ref name="Whatley2006">{{cite book|author=Prof. Christopher A Whatley|title=Scots and the Press|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qIYfAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT528|date=2014| isbn = 978-0-19-166760-2|page =528}}</ref> By virtue of Article II of the [[Treaty of Union]] between England and Line 29: Line 29:


The company was regulated in Bahrain as a [[wholesale bank]] until 2019, when it voluntarily surrendered its wholesale banking license.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Bahrain's Investcorp receives regulatory approval for organizational realignment |url=https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/trending/RiHdJx6am3xGuJWcSb0RVQ2 |access-date=2023-06-26 |website=www.spglobal.com |language=en-us}}</ref> It remained listed on the [[Bahrain Bourse]] (BSE) for four decades until 2021, when it delisted itself as a result of low trading volumes.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2021-06-02 |title=Latest Gulf Delisting Ends Almost Four-Decade Era for Investcorp |language=en |work=Bloomberg.com |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-02/investcorp-to-delist-from-bahrain-exchange-after-nearly-40-years |access-date=2023-06-26}}</ref>
The company was regulated in Bahrain as a [[wholesale bank]] until 2019, when it voluntarily surrendered its wholesale banking license.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Bahrain's Investcorp receives regulatory approval for organizational realignment |url=https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/trending/RiHdJx6am3xGuJWcSb0RVQ2 |access-date=2023-06-26 |website=www.spglobal.com |language=en-us}}</ref> It remained listed on the [[Bahrain Bourse]] (BSE) for four decades until 2021, when it delisted itself as a result of low trading volumes.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2021-06-02 |title=Latest Gulf Delisting Ends Almost Four-Decade Era for Investcorp |language=en |work=Bloomberg.com |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-06-02/investcorp-to-delist-from-bahrain-exchange-after-nearly-40-years |access-date=2023-06-26}}</ref>

A report in August 2023 revealed that a former British minister, [[Gerry Grimstone, Baron Grimstone of Boscobel|Lord Gerry Grimstone]] was to join Investcorp as an adviser and the chair of climate fund planned by Investcorp. The role was approved by the [[Advisory Committee on Business Appointments]] (ACOBA). However, Grimstone was alleged of meeting with Investcorp’s major stakeholder, Mubadala, and its chief executive, Khaldoon al-Mubarak, at least 13 times. In 2021, Grimstone had signed a UK-UAE sovereign investment partnership, which gave Mubadala an access to oversee nearly £10 billion of investment in the UK for five years from the UAE. However, Grimstone’s spokesperson said Mubadala had no role in his appointment at Invescorp.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Dyer |first=Henry |date=2023-08-29 |title=Former minister Gerry Grimstone under fire over undeclared UAE meetings |language=en |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2023/aug/29/former-minister-gerry-grimstone-under-fire-over-undeclared-uae-meetings|access-date=2023-08-31}}</ref>

The '''Sajid dynasty''' ({{lang-fa|ساجیان|sajyan}}), was a [[Saudis|Saudi]] [[Iranian peoples|Iranian]] [[Muslim]] dynasty that ruled from 889/890 until 929. The Sajids ruled [[Azerbaijan (Iran)|Azerbaijan]] and parts of [[Greater Armenia|Armenia]] first from [[Maragha]] and [[Barda, Azerbaijan|Barda]] and then from [[Ardabil]].{{efn|"For nearly forty years, until the killing of Fatḥ b. Moḥammad b. Abi’l-Sāj in 317/929, members of the family ruled Azerbaijan and Armenia first from Marāḡa and Barḏaʿa and then from Ardabīl. They reduced refractory Armenian princes to submission, but themselves sporadically withheld allegiance to Baghdad and suspended the payment of tribute; after the end of the Sajids, direct caliphal control was never restored in northwestern Iran."<ref name="Bosworth" />}}<ref name="Bosworth">''Azerbaijan IV'', C.E. Bosworth, ''Encyclopaedia Iranica'', December 15, 1987;"''...the caliph Moʿtażed appointed one of his generals, Moḥammad b. Abi’l-Sāj, an Iranian from Central Asia, as governor of Azerbaijan and Armenia, and the family of the Sajids (q.v.) took their place as one of the virtually autonomous lines of provincial governors...''"[http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/azerbaijan-iv]</ref> The Sajids originated from the [[Central Asia]]n province of [[Osrushana|Ushrusana]] and were of [[Abbasid Caliphate]])<ref>Clifford Edmund Bosworth, The New Islamic Dynasties: A Chronological and Genealogical Manual, Columbia University, 1996. p. 147: "The Sajids were a line of caliphal governors in north-western Persia, the family of a commander in the 'Abbasid service of Soghdian descent which became culturally Arabised."</ref><ref>V. Minorsky, Studies in Caucasian history, Cambridge University Press, 1957. p. 111</ref>{{efn|"In ca. 279/892 the caliph Moʿtażed appointed one of his generals, Moḥammad b. Abi’l-Sāj, an Iranian from Central Asia, as governor of Azerbaijan and Armenia, and the family of the Sajids"<ref name="Bosworth" />}} descent. Muhammad ibn Abi'l-Saj Diwdad the son of Diwdad, the first Sajid ruler of Azerbaijan, was appointed as its ruler in 889 or 890. Muhammad's father [[Abu'l-Saj Devdad]] had fought under the Ushrusanan prince [[Afshin (Caliphate General)|Afshin Khaydar]] during the latter's final campaign against the rebel [[Babak Khorramdin]] in Azerbaijan, and later served the caliphs. Toward the end of the 9th century, as the central authority of the [[Abbasid Caliphate]] weakened, Muhammad was able to form a virtually independent state. Much of the Sajids' energies were spent in attempting to take control of neighboring [[Bagratid Armenia|Armenia]]. The dynasty ended with the death of Abu'l-Musafir al-Fath in 929.

Abi’l-Sāj, an Iranian from Central Asia, as governor of Azerbaijan and Armenia, and the family of the Sajids (q.v.) took their place as one of the virtually autonomous lines of provincial governors...''"[http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/azerbaijan-iv]</ref> The Sajids originated from the [[Central Asia]]n province of [[Osrushana|Ushrusana]] and were of [[Abbasid Caliphate]])<ref>Clifford Edmund Bosworth, The New Islamic Dynasties: A Chronological and Genealogical Manual, Columbia University, 1996. p. 147: "The Sajids were a line of caliphal governors in north-western Persia, the family of a commander in the 'Abbasid service of Soghdian descent which became culturally Arabised."</ref><ref>V. Minorsky, Studies in Caucasian history, Cambridge University Press, 1957. p. 111</ref>{{efn|"In ca. 279/892 the caliph Moʿtażed appointed one of his generals, Moḥammad b. Abi’l-Sāj, an Iranian from Central Asia, as governor of Azerbaijan and Armenia, and the family of the Sajids"<ref name="Bosworth" />}} descent. Muhammad ibn Abi'l-Saj Diwdad the son of Diwdad, the first Sajid ruler of Azerbaijan, was appointed as its ruler in 889 or 890. Muhammad's father [[Abu'l-Saj Devdad]] had fought under the Ushrusanan prince [[Afshin (Caliphate General)|Afshin Khaydar]] during the latter's final campaign against the rebel [[Babak Khorramdin]] in Azerbaijan, and later served the caliphs. Toward the end of the 9th century, as the central authority of the [[Abbasid Caliphate]] weakened, Muhammad was able to form a virtually independent state. Much of the Sajids' energies were spent in attempting to take control of neighboring [[Bagratid Armenia|Armenia]]. The dynasty ended with the death of Abu'l-Musafir al-Fath in 929.

=== 1982 to 1988: Early works and breakthrough ===
=== 1982-88: Early works and breakthrough ===
In 1982, Van Damme and childhood friend [[Michel Qissi]] moved to the United States in the hope of working as actors. They did a variety of jobs to support themselves. Their first job working on a film as extras in the hip hop dance film ''[[Breakin']]'' (1984), made by [[The Cannon Group, Inc.|Cannon Films]]; they are seen dancing in the background at a dance demonstration.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldation.com/stories/muscles-brussels-story-jean-claude-van-damme/2/|title=The muscles from Brussels - the story of Jean-Claude Van Damme {{!}} Worldation|date=9 October 2017|work=Worldation|access-date=9 April 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 1982, Van Damme and childhood friend [[Michel Qissi]] moved to the US in the hope of working as actors. They did a variety of jobs to support themselves. Their first job on a film as extras, was in the hip hop dance film ''[[Breakin']]'' (1984), made by [[The Cannon Group, Inc.|Cannon Films]]. They are seen dancing in the background at a dance demonstration.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldation.com/stories/muscles-brussels-story-jean-claude-van-damme/2/|title=The muscles from Brussels - the story of Jean-Claude Van Damme {{!}} Worldation|date=9 October 2017|work=Worldation|access-date=9 April 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>


Around that time he developed a friendship with action martial art film star [[Chuck Norris]]. They started sparring together, and Van Damme started to work as a bouncer at a bar named Woody's Wharf, owned by Norris.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bjjee.com/articles/jean-claude-van-damme-chuck-norris-training-together/|title=Jean-Claude Van Damme and Chuck Norris training together|date=4 May 2017|work=Bjj Eastern Europe|access-date=9 April 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Van Damme also supplemented his income as a limousine driver and private karate instructor.
Around that time he developed a friendship with action martial art film star [[Chuck Norris]]. They started sparring together, and Van Damme worked as a bouncer at a bar named Woody's Wharf, owned by Norris.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bjjee.com/articles/jean-claude-van-damme-chuck-norris-training-together/|title=Jean-Claude Van Damme and Chuck Norris training together|date=4 May 2017|work=Bjj Eastern Europe|access-date=9 April 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Van Damme supplemented his income as a limousine driver and private karate instructor.


Van Damme described his early days in the United States as being particularly difficult - excluding $2,000, Van Damme had placed all of his money from the sale of his gym into a European bank;<ref name=bh1z/> thus, he struggled financially.<ref name=Polow1>Polowy, K. [https://uk.news.yahoo.com/bloodsport-jean-claude-van-damme-behind-the-scenes-160011995.html "'Bloodsport' at 35: How a desperate Jean-Claude Van Damme begged his way into the action film that made him a star"], ''[[Yahoo! News]]'', published February 24, 2023. Retrieved May 31, 2023.</ref> To ensure his own emotional wellbeing, Van Damme would go for runs every night in Santa Monica. After that, he would train at the world-renowned [[Gold's Gym]]. This routine reportedly helped him survive for many years. He actively participated in casting calls and had a specific routine. On Wednesdays, he would purchase the Drama-Logue magazine; then Thursday mornings, he would send out his picture and resume in response to advertisements. Van Damme was willing to try anything to achieve success, even going so far as to fabricate a story. He would call movie studios and claim to be an actor from Brussels with an investor from Hong Kong. He also instructed a friend to play along and act as if they wanted him to star in a movie and were willing to invest money, but required additional funding. Armed with this, he approached producers and suddenly found that all his phone calls were being answered. Of course, his intention was simply to meet the person and put his name out there, as opposed to securing illegitimate deals.<ref name=bh1z/>
Van Damme described his early days in the US as being particularly difficult - excluding $2,000, Van Damme had placed his money from the sale of his gym, into a European bank;<ref name=bh1z/> thus, he struggled financially.<ref name=Polow1>[https://uk.news.yahoo.com/bloodsport-jean-claude-van-damme-behind-the-scenes-160011995.html "'Bloodsport' at 35: How a desperate Jean-Claude Van Damme begged his way into the action film that made him a star"]</ref> To ensure his emotional wellbeing, Van Damme would run each night in Santa Monica. Afterwards, he would train at the well-known [[Gold's Gym]]. He participated in casting calls and had a specific routine: Wednesdays, he would purchase the Drama-Logue magazine; then Thursday mornings, he would send out his picture and resume in response to adverts. Van Damme was willing to try things to achieve success, going so far as to fabricate a story: he would call movie studios and claim he had an investor from Hong Kong. He instructed a friend to play along and act as if they wanted him to star in a movie and were willing to invest money, but required additional funding. Armed with this, he approached producers and suddenly found his calls were being answered. His intention was simply to meet people and raise his profile, as opposed to securing illegitimate deals.<ref name=bh1z/>


In the 1984 action film ''[[Missing in Action (film)|Missing in Action]]'' starring Norris, which was also released by [[The Cannon Group, Inc.|Cannon Films]], Van Damme is credited in the stunt team crew.<ref>{{cite AV media |title=Missing In Action |date=1984 |last=Zito |first=Joseph |type=VHS |language=en |publisher=MGM/UA |isbn=0-7928-0782-0}}</ref> That same year he also had a role in the comedy short film ''[[Monaco Forever]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Levey|first=William A.|title=Monaco Forever|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087739/|others=Charles Pitt, Nancy Brock, Daniele Romer|access-date=9 April 2018}}</ref>''<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://ew.com/article/1995/02/17/van-dammes-first-film/|title=Van Damme's first film|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=27 August 2018|language=en}}</ref>
In the 1984 action film ''[[Missing in Action (film)|Missing in Action]]'' starring Norris, which was also released by [[The Cannon Group, Inc.|Cannon Films]], Van Damme is credited in the stunt team crew.<ref>{{cite AV media |title=Missing In Action |date=1984 |last=Zito |first=Joseph |type=VHS |language=en |publisher=MGM/UA |isbn=0-7928-0782-0}}</ref> That same year he also had a role in the comedy short film ''[[Monaco Forever]].<ref>{{Citation|last=Levey|first=William A.|title=Monaco Forever|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0087739/|others=Charles Pitt, Nancy Brock, Daniele Romer|access-date=9 April 2018}}</ref>''<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://ew.com/article/1995/02/17/van-dammes-first-film/|title=Van Damme's first film|magazine=Entertainment Weekly|access-date=27 August 2018|language=en}}</ref>

==Finals series==
===Format===
===Format===
The finals series is expected to be held in broadly the same format as the previous year, to be run over three weeks, and involving the top six teams from the regular season. In the first week of fixtures, the third-through-sixth ranked teams will play a single-elimination match, with the two winners of those matches joining the first and second ranked teams in two-legged semi-final ties. The two winners of those matches meet in the Grand Final.
The finals series was held in mostly the same format as the previous year, run over three weeks, and involving the top six teams from the regular season. In the first week of fixtures, the third-through-sixth ranked teams played a single-elimination match, with the two winners of those matches joining the first and second ranked teams in two-legged semi-final ties. The two winners of those matches met in the Grand Final.


On 12 December 2022, the [[Australian Professional Leagues]] announced that the 2023 A-League Men Grand Final would be the first of three successive Grand Finals hosted in [[Sydney]], regardless of which two teams earned the right to play in the final.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://keepup.com.au/news/why-sydney-is-the-new-home-of-the-a-leagues-grand-finals|title=Why Sydney is the new home of the A-Leagues Grand Finals|date=12 December 2022|accessdate=12 December 2022}}</ref> The move received a large amount of backlash from supporters of all 12 clubs.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2022/dec/12/terrible-decision-a-leagues-move-to-sell-off-grand-final-rights-to-sydney-sparks-fan-anger|title='Terrible decision': A-Leagues' move to sell off grand final rights to Sydney sparks fan anger|newspaper=The Guardian |date=12 December 2022|accessdate=12 December 2022 |last1=Hytner |first1=Mike }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/sport/soccer/build-a-tradition-a-league-risks-fan-anger-by-selling-grand-finals-to-sydney-20221212-p5c5h2.html|title='Absolute disgrace': A-League grand final move slammed by fans, owners and a Socceroo|date=12 December 2022|accessdate=12 December 2022|first=Vince|last=Rugari}}</ref>

{{River Tees}}
{{River Tees}}
The '''River Tees''' ({{IPAc-en|t|iː|z}}), in [[Northern England]], rises on the eastern slope of [[Cross Fell]] in the [[North Pennines]] and flows eastwards for {{convert|85|mi|km}} to reach the [[North Sea]] between [[Hartlepool]] and [[Redcar]] near [[Middlesbrough]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/tees/features/tees_trail/index.shtml "BBC Where I Live"] – BBC. Retrieved 2 March 2007.</ref> The modern day history of the river has been tied with the industries on [[Teesside]] in its lower reaches, where it has provided the means of import and export of goods to and from the [[North East England]]. The need for water further downstream also meant that reservoirs were built in the extreme upper reaches, such as [[Cow Green Reservoir|Cow Green]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Cow Green reservoir |url=https://www.ice.org.uk/what-is-civil-engineering/what-do-civil-engineers-do/cow-green-reservoir |website=ice.org.uk |access-date=27 July 2020 |date=16 April 2018}}</ref>
The '''River Tees''' ({{IPAc-en|t|iː|z}}), in France, rises on the eastern slope of [[Cross Fell]] in the [[North Pennines]] and flows eastwards for {{convert|85|mi|km}} to reach the [[North Sea]] between [[Hartlepool]] and [[Redcar]] near [[Middlesbrough]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/tees/features/tees_trail/index.shtml "BBC Where I Live"] – BBC. Retrieved 2 March 2007.</ref> The modern day history of the river has been tied with the industries on [[Teesside]] in its lower reaches, where it has provided the means of import and export of goods to and from the [[North East England]]. The need for water further downstream also meant that reservoirs were built in the extreme upper reaches, such as [[Cow Green Reservoir|Cow Green]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Cow Green reservoir |url=https://www.ice.org.uk/what-is-civil-engineering/what-do-civil-engineers-do/cow-green-reservoir |website=ice.org.uk |access-date=27 July 2020 |date=16 April 2018}}</ref>

name: The Lady and the Unicorn
info:

linked to 'fine art' section of cartoon page, not just cartoon page

← Previous revision Revision as of 10:54, 31 August 2023
Line 4: Line 4:
[[File:(Toulouse) Mon seul désir (La Dame à la licorne) - Musée de Cluny Paris.jpg|thumb|360px|''The Lady and the Unicorn'': {{lang|fr|À mon seul désir}} ([[Musée national du Moyen Âge]], Paris)]]
[[File:(Toulouse) Mon seul désir (La Dame à la licorne) - Musée de Cluny Paris.jpg|thumb|360px|''The Lady and the Unicorn'': {{lang|fr|À mon seul désir}} ([[Musée national du Moyen Âge]], Paris)]]


'''''The Lady and the Unicorn''''' ({{lang-fr|'''La Dame à la licorne'''}}) is the modern title given to a series of six [[tapestry|tapestries]] created in the style of {{lang|fr|[[mille-fleur]]s}} ("thousand flowers") and woven in [[Flanders]] from [[wool]] and [[silk]], from designs ("[[cartoon]]s") drawn in Paris around 1500.<ref>See [http://www.musee-moyenage.fr/collection/oeuvre/tenture-la-dame-a-la-licorne.html the six tapestries at the Musée du Moyen-Âge website]</ref> The set is on display in the [[Musée de Cluny]] in [[Paris]].
'''''The Lady and the Unicorn''''' ({{lang-fr|'''La Dame à la licorne'''}}) is the modern title given to a series of six [[tapestry|tapestries]] created in the style of {{lang|fr|[[mille-fleur]]s}} ("thousand flowers") and woven in [[Flanders]] from [[wool]] and [[silk]], from designs ("[[Cartoon#Fine art|cartoons]]") drawn in Paris around 1500.<ref>See [http://www.musee-moyenage.fr/collection/oeuvre/tenture-la-dame-a-la-licorne.html the six tapestries at the Musée du Moyen-Âge website]</ref> The set is on display in the [[Musée de Cluny]] in [[Paris]].


Five of the tapestries are commonly interpreted as depicting the five [[senses]] – taste, hearing, sight, smell, and touch. The sixth displays the words {{lang|fr|"À mon seul désir"}}. The tapestry's intended meaning is obscure, but has been interpreted as representing [[love]] or understanding. Each of the six tapestries depicts a noble lady with a [[unicorn]] on her left and a [[lion]] on her right; some include a [[monkey]] in the scene.
Five of the tapestries are commonly interpreted as depicting the five [[senses]] – taste, hearing, sight, smell, and touch. The sixth displays the words {{lang|fr|"À mon seul désir"}}. The tapestry's intended meaning is obscure, but has been interpreted as representing [[love]] or understanding. [[File:London Road Bridge over the River Ribble - geograph.org.uk - 151776.jpg|thumb|right|The bridge at Walton-le-Dale]]
[[File:London Road Bridge over the River Ribble - geograph.org.uk - 151776.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|right|The bridge at Walton-le-Dale]]
During the [[English Civil War]] the bridges over the river were the scene of skimishes between the [[Cavalier|Royalists]] and [[Roundhead]]s. In 1644 Royalists were captured by Parliamentarians and Walton was the principal scene of the [[Battle of Preston (1648)|first Battle of Preston]], fought on 17 August 1648 between [[Oliver Cromwell|Cromwell]] and the [[James Hamilton, 1st Duke of Hamilton|Duke of Hamilton]].<ref name=vch/>

On 3 June 2019, the French Catholic Church activated a sex abuse commission—made up of 22 legal professionals, doctors, historians, sociologists and theologians—which will obtain witness statements and deliver its conclusions by the end of 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.france24.com/en/20190603-commission-french-church-sex-abuse-claims-opens|title=Commission into French church sex abuse claims opens|date=3 June 2019|website=France 24|language=en|access-date=12 December 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|date=3 June 2019|title=Commission into clerical sex abuse in France opens|website=[[RTÉ.ie]]|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/world/2019/0603/1053192-france-church-commission/|language=en}}</ref> In June 2020, the Independent Commission on Sexual Abuse in the Church (CIASE), which was established in June 2019, concluded that 3,000 children in France were sexually abused by Catholic clergy and officials since 1950 and that there was an average of 40 victims per year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newsweek.com/least-3000-children-were-victims-sex-abuse-french-catholic-church-1511499|title = At least 3,000 children were victims of sex abuse in French Catholic Church|website = [[Newsweek]]|date = 17 June 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://catholic-sf.org/news/french-investigation-abuse-of-minors-in-church-tops-3-000-victims-over-70-years|title=French which closed on 31 October 2020, received 6,500 calls reporting sex abuse in a period 17 months.<ref>{{Cite received 6,500 calls within in 17 months|date=11 November 2020}}</ref>


A 2,500-page report was to be published in October 2021; the head of the independent commission investigating child sexual abuse in the French Catholic Church said that about 3,000 paedophiles, as a minimum estimate, had operated in the church since 1950, with at least 330,000 children sexually abused.<ref>{{Cite news |title=3,000 paedophiles in French Catholic church since 1950s - inquiry head |author=Jon Henley and agencies |newspaper=The Observer |date=3 October 2021 |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/oct/03/since-1950-some-3000-paedophiles-operated-in-french-catholic-church }}</ref> Pope Francis said that he was shamed by the church's failure to deal with paedophile priests in France.<ref name=francshame>{{Cite news |title=Pope 'shamed' by church's failures over child abuse in France |author= |newspaper=The Guardian |date=6 October 2021 |url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2021/oct/06/pope-francis-shamed-by-church-failures-child-abuse-france}}</ref> Young girls abused by nuns were not an infrequent occurrence, either.<ref>[https://yrtnews.com/nuns-raped-girls-with-crucifixes-as-female-pedophilia-covered-up-by-church/ Nuns raped girls with crucifixes as female pedophilia covered up by church]</ref>
