'''Jahangir Mahmud oghlu Rustamov''' ({{lang-az|Cahangir Mahmud oğlu Rüstəmov}}, March 5, 1926 — February 13, 2007) was an Azerbaijani painter, [[People's Artist of Azerbaijan]] (2002).

== Biography ==
Jahangir Rustamov was born on March 5, 1926 in [[Shaki, Azerbaijan|Nukha]]. In 1939-1941, he studied at the Azerbaijan State Azim Azimzade Art School.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Cahangir Mahmud oğlu Rüstəmov |url=http://www.anl.az/down/medeniyyet2007/fevral/medeniyyet2007_fevral_149.htm |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=www.anl.az}}</ref> After finishing the art school, he entered the State Academic Institute of Fine Arts Surikov, but due to his family situation, he left his studies and returned to [[Baku]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |title=Bu gün Azərbaycan Respublikasının Xalq rəssamı Cahangir Rüstəmovun doğum günüdür |url=http://az.baku-art.com/az/bu-gun-azerbaycan-respublikasin-n-xalq-ressam-cahangir-r-st-movun-dogum-g-n-d-r/ |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=az.baku-art.com |language=az}}</ref>

He became a member of the [[Artists' Union of the USSR]] in 1955. Exhibitions of the artist were held in 1953, 1962, and 1973. His works were exhibited in 1979 exhibitions of Azerbaijani artists opened in other countries. In 2002, an individual exhibition of the artist was opened in the V. Samadova exhibition hall in Baku.<ref name=":0" />

Jahangir Rustamov died in 2007.<ref name=":0" />

== Awards ==
* [[People's Artist of Azerbaijan]] — May 30, 2002<ref>{{Cite web |last= |title=Təsviri sənət xadimlərinə Azərbaycan Respublikası fəxri adlarının verilməsi haqqında Azərbaycan Respublikası Prezidentinin Fərmanı |url=https://e-qanun.az/framework/1691 |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=e-qanun.az}}</ref>
* Honored Artist of the Azerbaijan SSR — 1982

'''Jana Hrochová''' née '''Štefáčková'''<ref name="NTB" /><!--(born 23 March 1972)--> is a Czech operatic [[mezzo-soprano]], based at the [[National Theatre Brno]].

== Life and career ==
Jana Štefáčková sang in a children's choir in [[Šumperk]], Moravia. She studied at the [[Prague Conservatory]] from 1993 to 1999, with Jarmila Krásová. She was a member of the Opera Mozart in Prague from 1997 to 2000, and also performed ancient music with the ensemble Ars Cameralis and folk music with the ensemble Muzika Jara.<ref name="NTB" />

Since 2000, she has been a member of the opera ensemble at the [[National Theatre Brno]] where she appeared as Bizet's [[Carmen]], Rossii's Rosina in ''[[Il barbiere di Siviglia]]'', Puccini's Suzuki in ''[[Madame Butterfly]]'', the tile role of Janáček's ''[[The Cunning Little Vixen]]), Varvara in [[Káťa Kabanová]]), Fenena in Verdi's ''[[Nabucco]]'', Hänsel in Humperdinck's ''[[Hänsel und Gretel (opera)|Hänsel und Gretel]]'', and Nicklausse in Offenbach's ''[[Les contes d'Hoffmann|Les]]'', among others.<ref name="NTB" />

'''''Wonder Drug: The Secret History of Thalidomide in America and its Hidden Victims''''' is a non-fiction book authored by [[Jennifer Vanderbes]] and published by [[Random House]] in 2023. It gives the story of [[Frances Oldham Kelsey]] and the effect of [[thalidomide]] in the US in the 1960s.<ref name=Klass2023>{{cite news |last1=Klass |first1=Perri |title=Review {{!}} Thousands of children were maimed by thalidomide. A new book explores why. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/books/2023/06/23/wonder-drug-book-thalidomide/ |access-date=31 August 2023 |work=Washington Post |date=22 June 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230831094047/https://www.washingtonpost.com/books/2023/06/23/wonder-drug-book-thalidomide/|archive-date=31 August 2023}}</ref><ref name=Spink2023>{{cite web |last1=Spink |first1=Geoff |title=Review: Jennifer Vanderbes’s deft and thorough Wonder Drug maps the thalidomide tragedy |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/books/reviews/article-wonder-drug-book-thalidomide/ |website=The Globe and Mail |access-date=31 August 2023 |language=en-CA |date=27 July 2023}}</ref><ref name=Rascoe2023>{{cite web |last1=Rascoe |first1=Ayesha |title=Jennifer Vanderbes on her book 'Wonder Drug' |url=https://www.npr.org/2023/06/25/1184198904/jennifer-vanderbes-on-her-book-wonder-drug |website=www.npr.org |publisher=npr |access-date=31 August 2023 |language=English |date=23 June 2023}}</ref><ref name=Thomas2020>{{cite news |last1=Thomas |first1=Katie |title=The Unseen Survivors of Thalidomide Want to Be Heard |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/23/health/thalidomide-survivors-usa.html |access-date=31 August 2023 |work=The New York Times |date=23 March 2020}}</ref>

name: Claudius Lavergne
info:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claudius_Lavergne

WQUlrich: added Category:Artists from Lyon using HotCat

[[File:Claudius Lavergne.jpg|thumb|185px|Claudius Lavergne<br>(date unknown)]]
[[File:Paris HôpitalLariboisière Chapelle664.JPG|thumb|185px|St.Peter, at the Hôpital Lariboisière]]
'''Claudius Lavergne''' (10 December 1815, [[Lyon]] - 31 December 1887, [[Paris]]) was a French artist who primarily worked in [[stained glass]]. He was also an art critic and an inspector of historical monuments.

== Biography ==
His father, Marin Lavergne (1796-1881), was a painter of heraldry and carriages. His mother, Marie, died while giving birth to his brother Pierre in 1817.<ref>[https://gw.geneanet.org/lozaneaux?lang=en&pz=bernard&nz=ozaneaux&p=marin&n=lavergne Marin Lavergne] @ [[Geneanet]]</ref> He began his education at a school associated with the [[Basilica of Saint-Martin d'Ainay]]. After graduating, he attended the [[École nationale supérieure des beaux-arts de Lyon]], where he studied with [[Claude Bonnefond]]. In 1834, his father sent him to study with [[Dominique Ingres|Ingres]] at the [[French Academy in Rome]].

He had his first exhibit at the [[Salon (Paris)|Salon]] in 1838, with a painting of Jesus surrounded by children. In 1840 he returned to France, for health reasons, and became a member of the [[Third Order of Saint Dominic]].<ref>''Correspondance'' of Father [[Henri Lacordaire]], letter 40/21, 22 January 1840</ref> Four years later, he married {{ill|Julie Lavergne|fr|lt=Julie Ozaneaux}}, a daughter of the writer and academician, {{ill|Georges Ozaneaux|fr}}. She also became a writer, of tales and short stories. They had nine children.

He produced his first major work in 1853: a mural in the chapel of the [[Château de Châtillon-d'Azergues]]. Three years later, the sculptor [[Émilien de Nieuwerkerke]], acting as an agent of the [[Second Empire]], commissioned him to design twelve windows depicting the [[twelve apostles]] for the chapel at the [[Hôpital Lariboisière]], with the stipulation that he also create the windows. As a result, Lavergne opened his first workshop in Paris.<ref>[https://inventaire.iledefrance.fr/dossier/ensemble-de-12-verrieres-chapelle-de-l-hopital-lariboisiere/72b81069-2deb-4d3c-801f-f0445ee82dc9 "Ensemble de 12 verrières. Chapelle de l'hôpital Lariboisière"] @ Inventaire Ile de France</ref>

He worked with [[Eugène Viollet-le-Duc]] as an architectural inspector, which enabled him to deepen his knowledge of stained glass and begin a new artistic career, creating a glass painting workshop that would be passed to his sons Georges and Noël.<ref>''Revue d'Archéologie moderne et d'Archéologie générale'', #7, Presses Paris Sorbonne, {{p.|86}} ([https://books.google.fr/books?id=26bOH_rjOOAC&pg=PA86&lpg=PA86&dq=Lavergne+peintre-verrier+Assas&source=bl&ots=u9rnYnGtwg&sig=ACfU3U1_TqbKnDKGX1ZaNfkrm06uWWWqkg&hl=fr&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiGjvTI9s7pAhXxxoUKHU6tDCsQ6AEwB3oECAoQAQ#v=onepage&q=Lavergne%20peintre-verrier%20Assas&f=false Online]).</ref> Later, he became President of the Union of Master Glassmakers; a position he held until his death. During this time. he also worked as an art critic for ''[[L'Univers illustré]]''.

In addition to his original works, he restored windows at the Chapels in the [[Château de Versailles]], and the [[Château de Blois]], as well as at the Church of Saint-Léonard in [[Alençon]], the [[Cathédrale Notre-Dame de Noyon]], and the [[Cathédrale Saint-Pierre de Rennes]]. These works earned him the title of Commander in the [[Order of St. Gregory the Great]].

He died at his home, shortly after his seventy-second birthday, and was interred at the [[Cemetery of Saint-Louis, Versailles]].

'''''Turkism, Islamism and Modernism''''' (Turkish: ''Türkleşmek, İslamlaşmak, Muasırlaşmak'') is a book written by [[Ziya Gökalp]] published in 1918 after the [[Balkan Wars]]. The book reflects his perspectives on various subjects and the political landscape of the Ottoman Empire during the writing process of the book, along with his personal political ideologies involving with the issues presented in the book.

The book is a compilation of various essays which were written under the [[Title (publishing)|title]] "''Türkleşmek, İslâmlaşmak, Muâsırlaşmak''" by Ziya Gökalp around 1913–1914, for literary magazines namely [[Türk Yurdu]] (Turkish Land) and [[İslam Mecmuası]] (Magazine of Islam), as a serialized work that had been released in different issues.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Oral |first1=Mustafa |title=Çağdaşları Tarafından Ziya Gökalp’in Eleştirisi |url=http://web.deu.edu.tr/ataturkilkeleri/pdf/cilt1sayi1/Makale_2_MustafaOral.pdf |website=Dokuz Eylül Üniversitesi |publisher=Dokuz Eylül University |access-date=31 August 2023 |ref=chadash}}</ref> Book is composed of eleven chapters and every chapter contains multiple essays which have episodes where the author expresses personal political views.

== History ==
The book has been first compiled and published in '''Evkaf-ı İslamiye Matbaası''' in 1918. Written in fairly plain [[Ottoman Turkish]], the main point of the book was, just like other books of Ziya Gökalp, to inform the Turkish public as part of the [[:tr:Millî Edebiyat|National Literature]] movement. On 24 July 1923, Turkish nation has officially declared independence, in 1923 he was appointed as a "Maarif Vekâleti Telif ve Tercüme" (Ministry of Education Copyright and Translation) minister and consequently died on 25 October 1924 as he was suffering from a certain illness.<ref name=onur />

In 1930s, as [[Kemalism]] was getting popular, the book had a stagnating popularity as the proposal of [[Turkish–Islamic synthesis]] had no audience in the general population however book regained popularity in course of 1940s to 1970s.<ref name="onur">{{cite web |last1=Torun |first1=Onur |title=Ziya Gökalp-Türkleşmek, İslamlaşmak, Muasırlaşmak |url=https://www.academia.edu/42763736/Ziya_G%C3%B6kalp_T%C3%BCrkle%C5%9Fmek_%C4%B0slamla%C5%9Fmak_Muas%C4%B1rla%C5%9Fmak |website=.academia.edu |access-date=31 August 2023 |ref=onur}}</ref> Book has been republished by [[Ministry of Culture and Tourism (Turkey)|Ministry of Culture]] in modern [[Turkish alphabet]], transliterated from [[Ottoman Turkish alphabet]] by İbrahim Kutluk, in 1976.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Orhan |first1=Cavit |title=Sosyoloji Konferansları Dergisi, Sayı 14, Yıl 1976 |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161122070751/http://www.journals.istanbul.edu.tr/iusoskon/article/view/1023006350/1023005874 |website=www.journals.istanbul.edu.tr |access-date=31 August 2023}}</ref> The [[:tr:Ötüken Neşriyat|Ötüken Neşriyat]] again republished the book in 2014 more faithful to the original Ottoman alphabet tone but again in modern Turkish alphabet, therefore retaining the publishing and popularity of the book.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Özsarı |first1=Mustafa |title=Türkleşmek, İslamlaşmak, Muasırlaşmak:Önsöz |url=https://www.otuken.com.tr/u/otuken/docs/t/u/turklesmek-1442401844.pdf |website=otuken.com.tr |publisher=Ötüken Neşriyar |access-date=31 August 2023}}</ref>

== Chapters ==

# ''Üç cereyan'' (Three movements)
# ''Lisan'' (Language)
# ''An'ane ve Kaid'' (Narratives and Belief)
# ''Hars Zümresi, Medeniyet Zümresi'' (Party of Culture and Party of Civilisation)
# ''Türklüğün Başına Gelenler'' (What Happened to Turkishness)
# ''Terbiye'' (Discipline)
# ''Mefkure'' (Ideal)
# ''Türk Milleti ve Turan'' ([[Turkish people|Turkish Nation]] and [[Turan]])
# ''Millet ve Vatan'' (Nation and Land)
# ''Milliyet Mefkuresi'' (Ideal of Nation)
# ''Milliyet ve İslâmiye'' (Nationalism and Islam)

== Ideological views ==

The book, as it reflects Ziya Gökalp's ideologies, both against [[Liberal individualism]] and [[Communism]] but supports the [[Solidarism]] as a solution for the Turkish nation. This proposal resembles [[Corporatism]] and it can be said that [[Romanticism]] and a desire to reconcile [[Islamism]] and [[Turkism]] has influenced the theme of book.<ref name=onur />

In chapter ''An'ane ve Kaid'' (Narratives and Belief) he openly criticizes both [[Conservatism|conservatives]] and [[Classical radicalism|radicals]] as in one party thinks the rules and beliefs are the ultimate truth while the latter is likened to "the English who are without rules" therefore suggesting a moderation between parties. In contrast in ''Türk Milleti ve Turan'' (Turkish people and Turan) he takes a more conservative stance, pointing out the "enemies of Turan" are [[Socialism]], [[Defeatism]] and [[School]]s and complains how "[[Germanisation]], [[Francization]] and [[Russification]]" are dividing the Turkish nation, openly criticizing westernization and sugggesting that "our land is neither Turkiye nor [[Turkestan|Turkistan]], our land is eternal and bigger: Turan"<ref>{{cite book |first1=Gökalp |first2=Karatay |last1=Z., |last2=O. |title=Türkleşmek, İslamlaşmak, muasırlaşmak. |date=2004 |publisher=Kültür Bakanlığı |isbn=9789753387897}}</ref>

The book lays down the constitution of Gökalp's idea of Turkishness, which is the fact that he asserted that nation is a structure which is composed by belief and ideals, will be repeated in another work '''''The Principles of Turkism''''' hence he formed a unique idea of Turkism and Turkish nationalism.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Doğanoğlu |first1=Mustafa |title=Mustafa Doğanoğlu |url=https://www.academia.edu/62972284/T%C3%BCrkle%C5%9Fmek_%C4%B0slamla%C5%9Fmak_Muas%C4%B1rla%C5%9Fmak_tan_T%C3%BCrk%C3%A7%C3%BCl%C3%BC%C4%9F%C3%BCn_Esaslar%C4%B1_na_Ziya_G%C3%B6kalp_ve_Ulus_Tasavvuru?sm=b |website=academia.edu |access-date=31 August 2023}}</ref> For the same reason, he is called "father of Turkish nationalism" by his followers.<ref name=melson>[[Robert Melson (political scientist)|Melson, Robert]]. ''Revolution and Genocide''. 1996, page 164.</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Hür |first1=Ayşe |title=Milliyetciliğe tanım gerek |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119090522/http://www.radikal.com.tr/haber.php?haberno=72616 |website=radikal |access-date=31 August 2023}}</ref>

'''Alberto Chuairi''' (24 May 1926 – 21 April 2013), simply known as '''Turcão''', was a Brazilian professional footballer who played as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://spfcpedia.com.br/enciclopedia/2021/Enciclopedia2021_00_2.pdf |title=Todos os Jogadores |website=SPFCpédia |access-date=30 August 2023 |language=pt}}</ref>

==Career==

Turcão arrived at the youth team of Palestra Itália, and was promoted after the club became the current SE Palmeiras.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.palmeiras.com.br/noticias/turcao-campeao-paulista-em-47-morre-em-sao-paulo-aos-86-anos/ |title=Turcão, campeão paulista em 47, morre em São Paulo aos 86 anos |website=SE Palmeiras |date=21 April 2013 |access-date=30 August 2023 |language=pt}}</ref> He stood out for his physical size and strength. In the 1950s, he transferred to rival São Paulo FC, where he managed to repeat part of his success. He scored 36 goals for the club, where he was the official penalty taker.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://m.folha.uol.com.br/cotidiano/2013/04/1270347-alberto-chuairi-1926-2013---turcao-um-zagueiro-artilheiro.shtml |title=Alberto Chuairi (1926-2013) - Turcão, um zagueiro artilheiro |website=Folha de São Paulo |date=29 April 2013 |access-date=30 August 2023 |language=pt}}</ref> Turcão ended his career at Santa Cruz de Recife after a serious knee injury.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://terceirotempo.uol.com.br/que-fim-levou/turcao-2707 |title=Que fim levou? Turcão (ex-zagueiro do Palmeiras e São Paulo) |website=Terceiro Tempo |access-date=30 August 2023 |language=pt}}</ref>

==Honours==
===Palmeiras===
*[[Campeonato Paulista]]: [[1947 Campeonato Paulista|1947]], [[1950 Campeonato Paulista|1950]]
*[[Torneio Rio-São Paulo]]: [[1951 Torneio Rio-São Paulo|1951]]
*[[Taça Cidade de São Paulo]]: 1950
===São Paulo===
*[[Campeonato Paulista]]: [[1953 Campeonato Paulista|1953]], [[1957 Campeonato Paulista|1957]]
*[[Small Club World Cup]]: [[1955 Small Club World Cup|1955]]

==Death==

Turcão passed away in his apartment at age of 86, due to advanced [[Alzheimer]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ge.globo.com/futebol/noticia/2013/04/morre-turcao-ex-lateral-de-palmeiras-e-sao-paulo.html |title=Morre Turcão, ex-lateral de Palmeiras e São Paulo |website=GloboEsporte |date=21 April 2013 |access-date=30 August 2023 |language=pt}}</ref>

The '''Mangaluru Central-Kabaka Puttur Express Special(Unreserved)''' is an [[Express trains in India|Express]] train belonging to [[Southern Railway zone]] that runs between [[Mangalore Central railway station|Mangaluru Central]] and [[Kabaka Puttur railway station|Kabaka Puttur]] in India. It is currently being operated with 06484/16585 train numbers on a daily basis.It is a lifeline to the people of Dakshina Kannada district as the people of rural parts of district travel to Mangaluru for their work.

== Service ==
The 06484/Kabaka Puttur-Mangaluru Central Express Special has an average speed of 33 km/h and covers 49 km in 1h 30m. The 06485/Mangaluru Central-Kabaka Puttur Express Special has an average speed of 33 km/h and covers 49 km in 1h 30m.

== Route and Halts ==
The halts of the train are:

* [[Mangalore Central railway station|Mangaluru Central]]
* [[Mangalore Junction railway station|Mangaluru Junction]]
* [[Bantwala railway station|Bantwala]]
* Neralakatte Halt
* [[Kabaka Puttur railway station|Kabaka Puttur]]

'''Ronald Hermanus Pattinasarany''' (9 February 1949 – 19 September 2008) was an Indonesian professional [[Association football|football]] player and manager. He is one of Indonesia's legendary players and had captained the [[Indonesian national football team]] from 1980 to 1985.

== Club career ==
Pattinasarany started his career as a football player when he joined [[PSM Makassar|PSM]] Junior in 1966. Two years later he managed to break through to the senior level of [[PSM Makassar]]. From PSM, he left for the [[Galatama]] club, [[Warna Agung]] from 1978 to 1982. This was where his career started to climb so he was elected to enter and become the national team captain. In 1982, he left for [[Tunas Inti]]. After only a year there, he decided to hang up his boots and switch professions as a coach.{{citation needed|date=August 2023}}

== International career ==
In the 1970s to 1980s, when [[Indonesian football]] was one of the giants in [[Asian Football Confederation|Asia]], Pattinasary was one of those who helped make the name of the ''[[Indonesia national football team|Red and Whites]]'' team famous. He is known as a top player. He received awards such as [[Asian All Star Player]] in 1982, [[Best National Athlete]] in 1976 and 1981, [[Best Galatama Player]] in 1979 and 1980, and won the [[SEA Games Silver Medal]] in 1979 and 1981.{{citation needed|date=August 2023}}

== Managerial career ==
There are several Indonesian clubs that he has coached, including [[Persiba Balikpapan]], [[Krama Yudha Tiga Berlian]], [[Persita Tangerang]], [[Petrokimia Putra]], [[Makassar Utama]], [[Persitara Jakarta Utara]] and [[Persija Jakarta]]. However, the best achievement ever made by Pattinasarany was when he managed Petrokimia Putra when he successfully won several trophies for the club. He led Petrokimia to win the [[Surya Cup]], [[Petro Cup]], and runner-up [[Tugu Muda Cup]].{{citation needed|date=August 2023}}

Towards the end of the 1990s, Pattynasarany, who at that time was predicted to be one of the best coaches in Indonesia, surprisingly said goodbye to the world of Indonesian football, and decided to stop being the coach of Petrokimia Putra Gresik which he was holding at that time, because Ronny wanted to focus on guiding his two children, Benny and Yerry, who at that time were struggling with their addiction to [[drugs]].{{citation needed|date=August 2023}}

== Other activities ==
=== Football Association of Indonesia ===
* 2006 Director of Youth Development
* 2006 Deputy Chairman of Komdis
* 2007 National Team Monitoring Team

== Personal life ==
Patynasarany married Stella Maria on November 29 1977. They have 3 children, Robenno "Benny" Pattrick, Henry "Yerry" Jacques, and Tresita "Cita" Diana.<ref>{{cite book|title=Kick Andy: Kumpulan Kisah Inspiratif|author=Gantyo Koespradono|url=https://books.google.co.id/books?id=71OUCfEz3goC&pg=PA46&lpg=PA46&dq=%22Tresita+Diana%22&source=bl&ots=YVqOGEr9M2&sig=Nw23beBpRanPnwzL4iyu_-8da6s&hl=id&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiPm6zXrNTJAhXCA44KHTGbAs8Q6AEIGzAA#v=onepage&q=%22Tresita%20Diana%22&f=false}}</ref> Then they adopted one child who was their nephew, Pieter Pattinasarany.

He also has two grandchildren, namely Clarrice Faithlyn Pattinasarany (daughter of Benny and Melisa Milanova) and Roland Dimitri Levinus Nangin (son of Cita and Reza Nangin).

In 2006, to coincide with Ronny-Stella's 29th wedding anniversary, they launched a historical book, one of which contains Ronny's struggle in guiding his two children, Benny and Yerry, to get out of the trap of drugs.

== Death ==
Ronny died on Friday, 19 September 2008, at 13:30 [[UTC+7]], at Omni Medical Center Hospital, Pulo Mas, [[East Jakarta]], due to [[liver cancer]] which he had suffered from since December 2007.<ref>[http://bola.okezone.com/index.php/ReadStory/2008/09/19/49/147519/ronny-pattinasarani-tutup-usia Ronny Pattinasarani Tutup Usia] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080920103029/http://bola.okezone.com/index.php/ReadStory/2008/09/19/49/147519/ronny-pattinasarani-tutup-usia |date=20 September 2008 }} - News on [[Okezone|Okezone.Com]]</ref>

name: David Limebeer
info:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Limebeer

Onel5969: clean up, added orphan tag, typo(s) fixed: Lecturer → lecturer, highly- → highly , 2467-2488 → 2467–2488 (9)

{{Orphan|date=August 2023}}

{{Infobox scientist
| name = David John Noel Limebeer
| citizenship =
| nationality = <!-- use only when necessary per [[WP:INFONAT]] -->
| fields = [[Control engineering]] and [[vehicle dynamics]]
| workplaces = [[University of Cambridge]]; [[Imperial College London]]; [[University of Oxford]]
| patrons =
| education =
| alma_mater = [[Michaelhouse]]<br>[[University of the Witwatersrand]]<br>[[University of Natal]]<br>[[University of London]]
| thesis_title = Analysis and control of AC rotating machines in the presence of series capacitor compensated transmission networks (1980)
| doctoral_advisor = Ronald G. Harley
| known_for = Contributions to [[electrical machine]]s, [[robust control]] and [[vehicle dynamics]]
| influences =
| influenced =
| awards = [[Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering|FREng]]<br>[[List of IEEE fellows|IEEE]]
}}
'''David John Noel Limebeer''' is an [[Electrical engineering|electrical engineer]] and academic. He is an Emeritus Professor of [[Control Engineering]] at the [[University of Oxford]] and a Distinguished Professor at the [[University of the Witwatersrand]]<ref name=ttt>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wits.ac.za/research/top-researchers/distinguished-professors/|title=Distinguished Professors - Wits University|website=www.wits.ac.za}}</ref> He is also an Emeritus Professorial Fellow at [[New College, Oxford]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.new.ox.ac.uk/emeritus-and-wykeham-fellows|title=Emeritus and Wykeham Fellows | New College|website=www.new.ox.ac.uk}}</ref>

Limebeer is known for his contributions in engineering dynamics, with his contributions spanning [[electrical machine]]s, [[robust control]] theory, and [[vehicle dynamics]]. He has published numerous peer-reviewed articles and books, including ''Linear Robust Control'' (with Michael Green), and ''Dynamics and Optimal Control of Road Vehicles'' (with Matteo Massaro). He is the recipient of two [[South African Institute of Electrical Engineers]] Prizes and award certificates, the [[University of Hong Kong]] William Mong Distinguished Lecture prize,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://engg.hku.hk/William-Mong-Research-Fund/Distinguished-Lectures|title=Distinguished Lectures | Faculty of Engineering, HKU|website=engg.hku.hk}}</ref> and the 2019 Honeywell International Medal from the [[Institute of Measurement and Control]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.instmc.org/about/instmc_awards.aspx|title=InstMC Awards|website=www.instmc.org}}</ref> He is A1 rated with the [[National Research Foundation (South Africa)|South African National Research Foundation]].<ref name=NRF>{{cite web|url= https://www.nrf.ac.za/about-us/nrf-awards/2022-2/a-rated-researchers-2022/professor-david-j-n-limebeer/|title= National Research Foundation}}</ref>

Limebeer is a Fellow of the [[Royal Academy of Engineering]],<ref name=ROY>{{Cite web|url=https://raeng.org.uk/about-us/people-council-committees/the-fellowship/list-of-fellows|title=Royal Academy of Engineering Fellows}}</ref>
the [[Institute of Electrical Engineers]],<ref name=IET>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theiet.org/|title=IET - Home|website=www.theiet.org}}</ref> the [[South African Academy of Engineering]], the [[City and Guilds of London Institute]], and is a Life Fellow of the [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers]].

==Education==
Limebeer obtained his B.Sc.in [[engineering]] from the University of the Witwatersrand in 1974 and then attended the [[University of Natal]] from 1975 to 1980, where he received his M.Sc. in engineering and a PhD degree. From 1980 to 1984, he was a post-doctoral fellow at the [[University of Cambridge]]. He earned a D.Sc. in engineering from the [[University of London]] in 1992,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.london.ac.uk/|title=Study with the University of London, anywhere in the world|website=www.london.ac.uk}}</ref> and a MA degree from the University of Oxford in 2009 (conferred by resolution).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gazette.web.ox.ac.uk/degrees-by-resolution-2020/21|title=Degrees by Resolution 2020/21|website=gazette.web.ox.ac.uk}}</ref>

==Career==
Limebeer joined [[Imperial College London]] in 1984 as a lecturer in the Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imperial.ac.uk/engineering/departments/electrical-engineering/|title=Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering|website=Imperial College London}}</ref> was promoted to Reader in 1989, Professor in 1993 and served as Head of the department between 1999 and 2008. He was Professor of Control Engineering at the University of Oxford between 2008 and 2019, where he was also a Professorial Fellow at New College (Oxford). Since 2019, he has been an Emeritus Professor of Control Engineering at the University of Oxford and an Emeritus Professorial Fellow at New College. Following his retirement and return to South Africa, where he held emeritus positions at the University of Pretoria and the University of Johannesburg. Since 2021 he has been serving as a Distinguished Professor at the University of the Witwatersrand.<ref name=ttt/>

Limebeer has acted as an expert witness in several [[product liability]], accident investigations, and patent cases. He has also consulted for several Formula One, [[Grand Prix motorcycle racing|MotoGP]] and NASCAR teams.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nrf.ac.za/about-us/nrf-awards/2022-2/a-rated-researchers-2022/professor-david-j-n-limebeer/|title=Professor David J.N. Limebeer}}</ref>

He has held a number of editorial positions, including Associate Editor for ''Systems and Control Letters'', an Editor for ''Automatica'', and serves as an Editorial Board Member for ''Multibody System Dynamics''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.springer.com/journal/11044/editors|title=Multibody System Dynamics|website=Springer}}</ref>

==Research==
Limebeer's research covers both theoretical and applied contributions to control engineering and dynamic systems. These include contributions to the understanding and prevention of subsynchronous resonance (SSR) in electrical machines, robust control and the dynamics of road vehicles including bicycles, motorcycles, and Formula One and NASCAR specification race cars.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.new.ox.ac.uk/engineering|title=Engineering Science | New College|website=www.new.ox.ac.uk}}</ref><ref name="auto">{{Cite journal|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/00423114.2022.2067573|title=Optimal control of a NASCAR – specification race car|first1=D. J. N.|last1=Limebeer|first2=M.|last2=Bastin|first3=E.|last3=Warren|first4=H. G.|last4=Fensham|date=May 4, 2023|journal=Vehicle System Dynamics|volume=61|issue=5|pages=1210–1235|via=CrossRef|doi=10.1080/00423114.2022.2067573}}</ref>

===Subsynchronous resonance===
Limebeer's research on the design, operation, and limitations of passive-SSR suppression filters<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://www.infona.pl//resource/bwmeta1.element.ieee-art-000004643318|title=Suppressing subsynchronous resonance with static filters|first1=D. J. N.|last1=Limebeer|first2=R. G.|last2=Harley|first3=M. A.|last3=Lahoud|date=August 31, 1981|journal=IEE Proceedings Generation, Transmission and Distribution [see also IEE Proceedings-Generation, Transmission and Distribution]|volume=1|issue=128|pages=33–44|via=www.infona.pl|doi=10.1049/ip-c:19810006}}</ref> has examined various aspects of these filters.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/9497014|title= Subsynchronous resonance of the Koeberg turbo-generators and of a laboratory micro-alternator system}}</ref> He also explored SSR in induction motors with series capacitor compensated feeders, this work revealed improved starting time and voltage regulation, with unstable speed bands in both single-cage,<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://www.infona.pl//resource/bwmeta1.element.ieee-art-000004643313|title=Subsynchronous resonance of single-cage induction motors|first1=D. J. N.|last1=Limebeer|first2=R. G.|last2=Harley|date=August 31, 1981|journal=IEE Proceedings B - Electric Power Applications|volume=1|issue=128|pages=33–42|via=www.infona.pl|doi=10.1049/ip-b:19810004}}</ref> and deep-bar motors.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://digital-library.theiet.org/content/journals/10.1049/ip-b.1981.0005|title=Subsynchronous resonance of deep-bar induction motors|first1=D. J. N.|last1=Limebeer|first2=R. G.|last2=Harley|date=January 1, 1981|journal=IEE Proceedings B (Electric Power Applications)|volume=128|issue=1|pages=43–51|via=digital-library.theiet.org|doi=10.1049/ip-b.1981.0005}}</ref>

===Robust control===
Having considered the central problem of finding low-order robust controllers in the 1980s, Limebeer established that low-order controllers exist;<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://epubs.siam.org/doi/10.1137/0325081|title=An Analysis of the Pole-Zero Cancellations in $H^\infty $-Optimal Control Problems of the First Kind|first1=D. J. N.|last1=Limebeer|first2=Y. S.|last2=Hung|date=November 30, 1987|journal=SIAM Journal on Control and Optimization|volume=25|issue=6|pages=1457–1493|via=CrossRef|doi=10.1137/0325081}}</ref> and also contributed to the solution of the optimal case.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://epubs.siam.org/doi/10.1137/0329016|title=A Characterization of All Solutions to the Four Block General Distance Problem|first1=K.|last1=Glover|first2=D. J. N.|last2=Limebeer|first3=J. C.|last3=Doyle|first4=E. M.|last4=Kasenally|first5=M. G.|last5=Safonov|date=March 31, 1991|journal=SIAM Journal on Control and Optimization|volume=29|issue=2|pages=283–324|via=CrossRef|doi=10.1137/0329016}}</ref> In the periodically time-varying case, he explored the robust control of a satellite in a three-dimensional "halo" orbit and introduced a quantifiable robust stability margin that maintains the orbit while also ensuring robust stability.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/00207179.2020.1798510|title=Robust control of the circular restricted three-body problem with drag|first1=David J. N.|last1=Limebeer|first2=Deon|last2=Sabatta|date=February 1, 2022|journal=International Journal of Control|volume=95|issue=2|pages=490–501|via=CrossRef|doi=10.1080/00207179.2020.1798510}}</ref> Much of this work is summarized in the textbook ''Linear Robust Control'' (with M. Green).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.worldcat.org/search?q=Linear+Robust+Control|title=Linear Robust Control - Search Results|website=www.worldcat.org}}</ref>

===Vehicle dynamics===
Another aspect of Limebeer's research is his work on motorcycle and race car dynamics. Working with Robin S. Sharp, he developed computational methods for finding vehicle models,<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://doi.org/10.1023/B:MUBO.0000049195.60868.a2|title=Advances in the Modelling of Motorcycle Dynamics|first1=R.S.|last1=Sharp|first2=S.|last2=Evangelou|first3=D.J.N.|last3=Limebeer|date=October 1, 2004|journal=Multibody System Dynamics|volume=12|issue=3|pages=251–283|via=Springer Link|doi=10.1023/B:MUBO.0000049195.60868.a2}}</ref> that were later made into the commercial software product BikeSim.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.carsim.com/publications/technical/motorcycle.php|title=BikeSim Technical References|website=www.carsim.com}}</ref> Prompted by the introduction in 2014 of fuel-saving regulations into Formula One, he studied the use of optimal control in closed-circuit racing,<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00423114.2014.889315|title=Optimal control for a Formula One car with variable parameters|first1=Giacomo|last1=Perantoni|first2=David J.N.|last2=Limebeer|date=May 4, 2014|journal=Vehicle System Dynamics|volume=52|issue=5|pages=653–678|via=CrossRef|doi=10.1080/00423114.2014.889315}}</ref> emphasizing on the optimal deployment of limited fuel sources,<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/00207179.2014.900705|title=Optimal control of Formula One car energy recovery systems|first1=D.J.N.|last1=Limebeer|first2=G.|last2=Perantoni|first3=A.V.|last3=Rao|date=April 23, 2014|journal=International Journal of Control|pages=1–16|via=CrossRef|doi=10.1080/00207179.2014.900705}}</ref> later work focused on tyre management,<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/00423114.2016.1213861|title=Optimal tyre usage for a Formula One car|first1=A. J.|last1=Tremlett|first2=D. J. N.|last2=Limebeer|date=October 2, 2016|journal=Vehicle System Dynamics|volume=54|issue=10|pages=1448–1473|via=CrossRef|doi=10.1080/00423114.2016.1213861}}</ref> and three-dimensional track modelling.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://doi.org/10.1115/1.4028253|title= Optimal Control of a Formula One Car on a Three-Dimensional Track. Part 1: Track Modelling and Identification}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://doi.org/10.1115/1.4029466|title=Optimal Control of a Formula One Car on a Three-Dimensional Track—Part 2: Optimal Control|first1=D. J. N.|last1=Limebeer|first2=G.|last2=Perantoni|date=May 1, 2015|journal=Journal of Dynamic Systems, Measurement, and Control|volume=137|issue=5|doi=10.1115/1.4029466}}</ref> In 2021, he focused on modifying his Formula One work for use on highly banked NASCAR ovals.<ref name="auto"/> Some of his vehicle dynamics work is included in the textbook ''Dynamics and Optimal Control of Road Vehicles''.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://academic.oup.com/book/43936|title=Dynamics and Optimal Control of Road Vehicles}}</ref>

==Awards and honors==
*1992 – Elected Fellow, [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers]]
*1994 – Elected Fellow, [[Institute of Electrical Engineers]]<ref name=IET/>
*1997 – Elected Fellow, [[Royal Academy of Engineering]]<ref name=ROY/>

*2018 – Life Fellow, Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
*2019 – Fellow, [[South African Academy of Engineering]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/author/37269701000|title=David J. N. Limebeer - IEEE Fellow}}</ref>
*2019 – Honeywell International medal, [[Institute of Measurement and Control]]
*2022 – A1 Rating, [[National Research Foundation (South Africa)|The NRF (South Africa)]]<ref name=NRF/>

'''''Carex secalina''''', the '''rye sedge''', is a species of flowering plant in the family [[Cyperaceae]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://eol.org/pages/1123402 |title=Rye Sedge |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2023 |website=eol.org |publisher=Encyclopedia of Life |access-date=31 August 2023 }}</ref> It is native to central and eastern Europe, the Caucasus, Iran, Kazakhstan, and on to Siberia, and it has been introduced to the Russian Far East, Belgium, and New York State.<ref name="POWO_302175-1" >{{cite POWO |id=302175-1 |title=''Carex secalina'' Willd. ex Wahlenb. |access-date=31 August 2023 }}</ref> It is usually found growing in saline, wet meadows, and so is pre-adapted to grow in ditches next to roads that are [[Deicing|heavily salted]] in winter.<ref>{{cite journal |title=''Carex secalina'' (Cyperaceae), an Introduced Sedge New to North America |date=2012 |last1=Werier |first1=David A. |last2=Naczi |first2=Robert F. C. |journal=Rhodora |volume=114 |issue=960 |pages=349–365 |doi=10.3119/12-06 |s2cid=86152833 }}</ref>

==Subtaxa==
The following varieties are accepted:<ref name=" POWO_302175-1" />
*''Carex secalina'' var. ''alpina'' {{small|Kük. & Bornm.}} – Iran
*''Carex secalina'' var. ''secalina'' – entire range

'''Elephant Peak''' is a {{convert|7938|ft|meter|adj=mid|-elevation|abbr=off|sp=us}} mountain [[summit]] located on the border shared by [[Lincoln County, Montana|Lincoln]] and [[Sanders County, Montana|Sanders]] counties in [[Montana]].

==Description==
Elephant Peak is located {{convert|20|mi}} south of [[Libby, Montana]], in the [[Cabinet Mountains Wilderness]], on land managed by [[Kaniksu National Forest]] and [[Kootenai National Forest]].<ref name="listsofjohn"/> It is set west of the [[Continental Divide]] in the [[Cabinet Mountains]] which are a subrange of the [[Rocky Mountains]].<ref name=pb/> Elephant Peak ranks as the fourth-highest summit in the Cabinet Mountains,<ref name=pb/> fourth-highest summit in Lincoln County and the fifth-highest in Sanders County.<ref name="listsofjohn"/> Precipitation runoff from the mountain's east slope drains into Libby Creek which is a tributary of the [[Kootenay River|Kootenai River]], whereas the west slope drains into headwaters of East Fork Bull River which is within the [[Clark Fork River]] watershed. [[Topographic relief]] is significant as the summit rises over {{convert|3500|ft|m}} above Libby Creek in 1.4 mile (2.25 km) and {{convert|3200|ft|m}} above Saint Paul Lake in 1.25 mile (2 km). The mountain's toponym was officially adopted in 1923 by the [[U.S. Board on Geographic Names]] and the name refers to the appearance of the mountain.<ref name="gnis"/>
[[File:Elephant heraldry Laos colony.svg|thumb|140px|Compare to the photo of Elephant Peak]]
==Climate==

Based on the [[Köppen climate classification]], Elephant Peak is located in a [[subarctic climate]] zone characterized by long, usually very cold winters, and cool to mild summers.<ref name=Peel>{{cite journal | author = Peel, M. C. |author2=Finlayson, B. L. |author3=McMahon, T. A. | year = 2007 | title = Updated world map of the Köppen−Geiger climate classification | journal = Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci. | volume = 11 |issue=5 | pages = 1633–1644 |doi=10.5194/hess-11-1633-2007 |bibcode=2007HESS...11.1633P |s2cid=9654551 | issn = 1027-5606| doi-access = free }}</ref> Winter temperatures can drop below −10 °F with wind chill factors below −30 °F. This climate supports a small glacier remnant on the north slope of the peak.

'''Rien Schuurhuis''' is a [[Dutch people|Dutch]]-born Vatican [[road cycling|road cyclist]] and industrial design engineer who competed for the [[Vatican City]] in the [[2022 UCI Road World Championships|2022]] and [[2023 UCI Road World Championships]]. He was the first cyclist and athlete who represented the Vatican City as a regular scoring competitor.<ref name="NBS">{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcsports.com/olympics/news/vatican-cyclist-rien-schuurhuis-world-championships |title=Vatican rider to make history at world road cycling championships |publisher=[[NBC Sports]] |date=23 September 2022 |access-date=31 August 2023}}</ref>

==Career==
Schuurhuis started competing internationally for teams such as [[CCACHE x Par Küp|Oliver's Real Food Racing]] and [[Nex CCN Cycling Team|Blank Inc Cycling Team]] under a Dutch sporting nationality.

In 2020 when he moved to [[Rome]], he was "immediately drawn to the values ​​and community spirit of [[Athletica Vaticana]]," and in 2021 he started competing for the [[Vatican City]].<ref name="CUTD" />
==Major results==

{{div col end}}
==Personal life==
Schuurhuis was introduced to cycling at a young age saying he "could ride a bike before I could walk," due to the [[Cycling in the Netherlands|Cycling culture of the Netherlands]].<ref name="NBS" />

Schuurhuis holds [[Dutch citizenship]] due to his birth, [[Australian citizenship]] as his wife [[Chiara Porro]] is Australian, and [[Vatican citizenship]] since he resides there and as his wife is the [[List of ambassadors of Australia to the Holy See|Australian Ambassador to the Holy See]].<ref name="NBS" /><ref name="ILFOGLIO">{{cite web |last=Trapani |first=Andrea |url=https://www.ilfoglio.it/sport/2022/09/21/news/come-pedala-il-vaticano-ai-mondiali-di-ciclismo-4461088/|title=Come pedala il Vaticano ai Mondiali di ciclismo |publisher=[[Il Foglio]] |date=21 September 2022 |access-date=31 August 2023 |lang=it}}</ref> He moved to [[Rome]] in [[2020]].<ref name="CUTD">{{cite web |url=https://cyclinguptodate.com/cycling/a-40-year-old-representing-vatican-city-at-the-world-championship-this-is-rien-schuurhuis-story |title=A 40-Year-Old Representing Vatican City At The World Championship - This Is Rien Schuurhuis' Story |publisher=Cycling Up To Date |date=23 September 2022 |access-date=31 August 2023}}</ref> He has two children, Thomas and George.<ref name="NA">{{cite web |last=Kenny |first=Michael |url=https://www.catholicweekly.com.au/new-ambassador-speaks-on-her-hopes-for-the-role/ |title=New Ambassador speaks on her hopes for the role |publisher=[[The Catholic Weekly]] |date=20 September 2020 |access-date=31 August 2023}}</ref>

'''Korvi Rakshand''' is a leader for quality education through [[JAAGO Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://rmaward.asia/awardee/korvi-rakshand |title=Awardees |website=Ramon Magsaysay Award Foundation |access-date=2023-08-31}}</ref> He was awarded the [[Ramon Magsaysay Award]] in 2023.<ref name="dstar">{{cite news |date=31 August 2023 |title=JAAGO's Korvi receives Magsaysay award, the 'Nobel Prize of Asia' |url=https://www.thedailystar.net/tech-startup/news/jaagos-korvi-receives-magsaysay-award-the-nobel-prize-asia-3407591 |work=The Daily Star}}</ref><ref >{{cite news |date=31 August 2023 |title=JAAGO’s Korvi honoured with Magsaysay Award |url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/people/324040/jaago%E2%80%99s-korvi-honoured-with-magsaysay-award|work=The Dhaka Tribune}}</ref>

==Education==
He studied in [[Scholastica School]] in Bangladesh. Then got his LLB degree from [[University of London]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://scholasticabd.com/docs/alumni/Korvi%20Rakshand.pdf |title=Profile of Korvi Rakshand |website=scholasticabd.com |access-date=31 August 2023}}</ref>

==Work==
He founded JAAGO Foundation in 2007. The Foundation provides free English-language education to over 30,000 students throughout Bangladesh.<ref name="dstar"/><ref>{{cite news |date=31 July 2015 |title=How one homeless child inspired this Bangladeshi to help hundreds|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2015/jul/24/bangladesh-online-school-education-jaago-korvi-rakshand |work=The Guardian}}</ref> He founded Volunteer for Bangladesh, the country's largest volunteer platform with over 35,000 young people taking part in voluntary activities in the country.<ref name="tbs">{{cite news |date=23 May 2021 |title=Korvi Rakshand named 181st Commonwealth Point of Light |url=https://www.tbsnews.net/bangladesh/korvi-rakshand-named-181st-commonwealth-point-light-249712 |work=The Business Standard.}}</ref>

==Award==
* Top 10 inspirational Bangladeshi - 2014 <ref>{{cite web |url=https://futurestartup.com/2011/12/14/korvi-rakshand/ |title=Face To Face With Korvi Rakshand, Founder, Jaago Foundation|website=futurestartup.com |access-date=31 August 2023}}</ref>
* Asia 21 Young Leader by Asia Society - 2015<ref>{{cite news |date=31 July 2015 |title=Korvi Rakshand Named Asia 21 Young Leader by Asia Society|url=https://www.thedailystar.net/star-weekend/opinion/korvi-rakshand-named-asia-21-young-leader-asia-society-119095 |work=The Daily Star}}</ref>
* 181st Commonwealth Point of Light-2021 <ref name="tbs"/><ref>{{cite news |date=24 May 2021 |title=Korvi Rakshand gets Commonwealth Points of Light award|url=https://bangladeshpost.net/posts/korvi-rakshand-gets-commonwealth-points-of-light-award-60463 |work=The Bangladesh Post}}</ref>
*[[Ramon Magsaysay Award]] - 2023

name: Murder of Iris Temperley
info:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Murder_of_Iris_Temperley

Reading Beans: Added tags to the page using Page Curation (orphan)

{{orphan|date=August 2023}}

{{Infobox person
|name=Iris Temperley
|birth_date={{birth date|1927|03|02|df=y}}
|birth_place=[[Springsure, Queensland]], Australia
|death_date={{death date and age|2010|02|03|1927|03|02|df=y}}
|death_place=[[Brisbane, Queensland]], Australia
|death_cause=[[homocide]] ([[bashing (pejorative)|bashing]])
|spouse=Gordon Temperley (1949-2004; his death)
|children=5
}}

'''Iris Daphne Temperley''' (née Donovan; 2 March 1927 – 3 February 2010) was an Australian woman who was murdered in [[Rockhampton]], [[Queensland]], Australia.<ref name=bled>{{cite news |last=Oberhardt|first=Mark|date=13 December 2011|title=Grandmother bled to death after being raped by teenager in her backyard on Australia Day|url=https://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/grandmother-bled-to-death-after-being-raped-by-teenager-in-her-backyard-on-australia-day/news-story/2881162947ea31879f8cd5787f7e8975|work=[[The Courier-Mail]]|location= |access-date=30 August 2023}}</ref>

18-year-old David Samuel Aubrey Ray randomly attacked and raped 82-year-old Temperley in the backyard of her home in George Street in the suburb of [[Rockhampton City]] on the morning of 26 January 2010.<ref name=details>{{cite news|last=Mesner|first=Kerri-Anne|date=19 September 2011|title=Details of rape horror revealed|url=https://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/rockhampton/details-of-rape-horror-revealed/news-story/53014b12f909cebd3ab9cac6527162ba|work=[[The Morning Bulletin]]|location= |access-date=30 August 2023}}</ref> He inflicted extensive injuries to Temperley in the particularly violent attack, which caused considerable anger within the Rockhampton community.<ref name=bled/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Ironside|first1=Robyn|last2=O'Loan|first2=James|date=27 January 2010|title=Police hunt backyard attacker of woman, 82|url=https://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/police-hunt-backyard-attacker-of-woman-82/news-story/891f3137f95c30ddf25499982cab1b50|work=The Courier-Mail|location= |access-date=30 August 2023}}</ref>

Temperley died from her injuries at the [[Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital]] on 3 February 2010 without having regained consciousness.<ref name=mourns/><ref name=life/>

==Background==
Temperley was born Iris Daphne Donovan at [[Springsure, Queensland]] on 2 March 1927.<ref name=farewell>{{cite news |last=Siegmeier|first=Melinda|date=11 February 2010|title=Farewell for Iris Temperley |url=https://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/rockhampton/farewell-for-iris-temperley/news-story/47547e8b23b20f2a3370fff68c19356e|work=The Morning Bulletin|location= |access-date=30 August 2023}}</ref> She married Gordon Temperley on 1 December 1949 at [[St Paul's Cathedral, Rockhampton|St Paul's Cathedral]] in Rockhampton, and together they had five children.<ref name=farewell/>

After spending some time managing a cattle property north of [[Duaringa]], the Temperley's moved to Rockhampton in 1959 and purchased a house in George Street where the family settled.<ref name=farewell/>

At the time of her death, Temperley had 11 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.<ref name=life/>

==Murder==
Temperley was raking leaves in the backyard of her George Street home when she was set upon by Ray who used a fire extinguisher in the attack, causing Temperley to sustain extensive injuries including skull swelling, broken nose, fractured ribs, fractured sternum, collapsed lung, and tearing to her genitals, causing profuse bleeding.<ref name=bled/>

Ray attacked Temperley after having stolen alcohol from the Leichhardt Hotel in Bolsover Street, and before committing a burglary at a neighbouring house.<ref name=bled/>

Temperley was admitted to the intensive care unit at Rockhampton Hospital in a critical condition before being flown to Brisbane, where she died from her injuries on 3 February 2010.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--not stated--> |date=27 January 2010|title=Woman, 82, critical after vicious attack|url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/national/yo-woman-critical-after-vicious-attack/news-story/e8f9b5473a13cc6d2b45360a6fc50fb0|work=The Daily Telegraph|location= |access-date=31 August 2023}}</ref><ref name=bled/>

After Temperley's death, a public memorial was held at St Paul's Cathedral, which was attended by more than 100 people.<ref name=mourns>{{cite news |author=<!--not stated--> |date=10 February 2010|title=Rockhampton mourns elderly bash victim|url=https://www.smh.com.au/national/rockhampton-mourns-elderly-bash-victim-20100210-ns9o.html|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|location= |access-date=30 August 2023}}</ref>

Member for Rockhampton [[Robert Schwarten]] said that Temperley's death had affected the Rockhampton community, stating: "Disbelief, revulsion, anger and fear has riled through this community."<ref name=mourns/>

==Arrest==
On 27 January 2010, Ray attended the Rockhampton Police Station with a relative where he admitted to assaulting an elderly lady but claimed to be having difficulty remembering specific details.<ref name=details/>

He was arrested and ultimately charged with murder and rape as well as stealing and property offences.<ref name=details/>

After a mention in the [[Rockhampton Courthouse|Rockhampton Magistrates Court]] in September 2010, a committal hearing was scheduled for November 2010.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lewis|first=Megan|date=7 September 2010|title=November trial for man accused of killing 82yo|url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2010-09-07/november-trial-for-man-accused-of-killing-82yo/2250602|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|location= |access-date=30 August 2023}}</ref> Following the three-day committal hearing, magistrate Annette Hennessy ordered Ray to stand trial for the rape and murder of Iris Temperley.<ref>{{cite news|last=Elsworth|first=Sophie|date=4 November 2010|title=Teen to stand trial over death of Rockhampton grandmother Iris Temperley, 82|url=https://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/teen-to-stand-trial-over-death-of-rockhampton-grandmother-iris-temperley-82/news-story/95654a4f1941b918ce0ff9122acd6c07|work=The Courier-Mail|location= |access-date=30 August 2023}}</ref>

==Trial==
Ray's trial in the Rockhampton Supreme Court was held in September 2011 where he pleaded guilty to one count of murder and two counts of rape for which he received life sentences.<ref name=life>{{cite news |author=<!--not stated--> |date=14 September 2011|title=Life sentence for vicious rape, murder|url=https://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/central-queensland/life-sentence-for-vicious-rape-murder/news-story/54ff70c1cb96eda5840f4e4231ad39fb|work=[[Central Queensland News|CQ News]]|location= |access-date=30 August 2023}}</ref> An additional 15 years was added to his prison term for the burglary at Temperley's home as well as numerous other offences.<ref name=life/>

A psychiatrist's report was tendered to the court but Justice [[Duncan McMeekin]] said despite the report indicating that Ray had felt genuine remorse while also detailing his long-standing [[substance abuse]] problem, there was no psychiatric excuse for what Ray had done.<ref name=details/>

McMeekin described the facts of the case as "appalling" given that Temperley was "a frail elderly lady of 82 years" and told Ray: "You murdered her by causing injuries which caused her death some days later... The doctors were unable to stop the bleeding. Fortunately, she did not regain consciousness after your attack."<ref name=life/>

===Appeal===
Ray argued that some of the sentences were manifestly excessive and successfully appealed to have his sentence reduced.<ref name=appeal>{{cite news|last=Robinson|first=Paul|date=14 December 2011|title=Grandma killer gets reduced rape sentence |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-12-14/grandma-killer-gets-reduced-rape-sentence/3730406|work=ABC News|location= |access-date=30 August 2023}}</ref> In a judgement, the [[Queensland Court of Appeal]] reduced Ray's sentence for Temperley's rape to 14 years and his sentence for burglary to three years.<ref name=appeal/>

Despite this, the sentences were still to be served concurrently with his life sentence for Temperley's murder.<ref name=appeal/>

==Legacy==
In 2020, Temperley's name was added to an online memorial called The Red Heart Campaign, designed by journalist Sherele Moody to honour women and children who had died as a result of acts of violence.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Kaitlyn|date=24 November 2020|title=CQ mum to be honoured in new online memorial|url=https://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/rockhampton/cq-mum-to-be-honoured-in-new-online-memorial/news-story/b925b8ac8ea474f555569f40b6761d3b|work=The Morning Bulletin|location= |access-date=30 August 2023|quote=The Red Heart Campaign also pays tribute to Rockhampton and Yeppoon residents such as Lisa Jackson, Mima Joan McKim-Hill, Michelle Coral Lewis, Julie Dawn Turner, Beverley Doreen Leggo, Keyra Steinhardt, Sylvia Maria Benedetti, Nicole Margaret Lieske, Iris Temperley...}}</ref>

As of April 2023, Ray was still incarcerated at the [[Capricornia Correctional Centre]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Jarrett|first=Vanessa|date=6 April 2023|title=Murderers serving life sentences at Capricornia Correctional Centre|url=https://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/rockhampton/police-courts/murderers-serving-life-sentences-at-capricornia-correctional-centre/news-story/c8ab11b8601dc8e4a1bfd6c33af4a734|work=The Morning Bulletin|location= |access-date=30 August 2023}}</ref>

Temperley's nephew, Vern Donovan, who served as [[Fitzroy Shire Council]]'s chief executive officer from 1965 to 2000, briefly wrote about Temperley's death in his autobiography ''You're Sincerely: My life's experiences and lessons learned, thus far''.<ref name=vern>{{cite book|last=Donovan|first=Vern|author-link= |date=2022|title=Yours sincerely: My life's experiences and lessons learned, thus far|url= |location= |publisher=Independently published|page=195|isbn=978-0-646-83636-2}}</ref>

Donovan said his elderly mother Merle Donovan was close to her sister-in-law and would speak regularly to Temperley on the phone. He said that Temperley's "sudden and cruel murder" had caused his mother who was residing in a [[Yeppoon]] retirement village to go into a "severe state of shock", and arrangements had to be made to have her transferred into a more calming area of the facility.<ref name=vern/>

'''Kyle Thomas''' is a British TikTok personality and social media influencer, most well known for his videos about rescued animals.

== Career ==

=== TikTok ===
Kyle began posting to TikTok in 2019,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |date=2022-08-15 |title=Who is TikTok star Kyle Thomas? |url=https://www.ladbible.com/entertainment/kyle-thomas-tiktok-20220815 |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=LADbible |language=en}}</ref> which is now his main focused platform, after already gaining some followers on Instagram.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |date=2023-05-21 |title=Belfast-based TikTok star Kyle Thomas's 'absolutely crazy' rise to millions of followers |url=https://www.itv.com/news/utv/2023-05-21/crazy-how-tiktok-star-gained-millions-of-followers-and-billions-of-likes |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=[[UTV]]}}</ref> He is most notably known for his content featuring rescued animals, including his [[meerkat]] Mylo.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |date=2022-08-16 |title=Meet Kyle Thomas: The most followed British TikToker of all time |url=https://thetab.com/uk/2022/08/16/kyle-thomas-tiktok-followers-net-work-meerkat-mylo-how-much-does-he-earn-book-268351 |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=The Tab |language=en-GB}}</ref> He is also known for comedy sketches, dancing, and food reviews.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Bryant |first=Toby |date=2021-07-19 |title=The Kent TikTok teen making £38k with every single post |url=https://www.kentlive.news/news/celebs-tv/kent-tiktok-teenager-making-38k-5672344 |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=KentLive |language=en}}</ref>

Kyle has been known to post around 60 videos a week, and has previously uploaded 25 videos in a single day to his various social media channels.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |last=Rewcastle |first=Elly |date=2022-10-17 |title=This teenage TikTok influencer has 33m followers and 25 pets |url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/real-life-kyle-thomas-one-25283776 |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=Manchester Evening News |language=en}}</ref>

In 2021, Kyle participated in a TikTok pop-up venue in [[Westfield London|Westfield shopping centre]] offering sessions on how to become an influencer, and what it's like creating for the platform.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Butler |first=Sarah |date=2021-07-12 |title=TikTok pop-up venue to open at Westfield London |language=en-GB |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2021/jul/12/tiktok-pop-up-venue-uk-westfield-london-kyle-thomas-ehiz-ufuah |access-date=2023-08-31 |issn=0261-3077}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-07-12 |title=Westfield shopping centre opens TikTok pop-up venue |url=https://www.retaildetail.eu/news/general/tiktok-opens-pop-experience-venue-westfield-shopping-centre/ |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=RetailDetail EU |language=en-US}}</ref>

It is estimated that he is the #1 highest earning TikTok personality in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Sacco |first=Dom |date=2023-03-25 |title=Top 10 highest-earning TikTok content creators in the UK |url=https://esports-news.co.uk/2023/03/25/highest-earning-tiktok-content-creators/ |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=esports-news.co.uk |language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-08-16 |title=Who is Kyle Thomas on TikTok and what is his net worth? |url=https://www.peeblesshirenews.com/news/national/uk-today/20661110.tiktoks-kyle-thomas-net-worth/ |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=Peeblesshire News |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-08-15 |title=Meet the UK's highest earning TikTok teenager, Kyle Thomas! |url=https://www.itv.com/thismorning/articles/meet-the-uks-highest-earning-tiktok-teenager-kyle-thomas |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=[[ITV]]}}</ref>

=== YouTube ===
Kyle also runs a YouTube channel, which mostly consists of reposts from his TikTok account, but also contains some original content.

=== TV ===
Kyle has had a number of TV interviews including one with ITV where he confirmed that he has a comfortable income from his work, which resulted in the presenters being criticised online for that line of questions.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Sansome |first=Jessica |date=2022-08-15 |title=This Morning viewers blast Andi Peters for 'rude' questioning of TikTok star |url=https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/tv/itv-morning-viewers-blast-andi-24761829 |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=Manchester Evening News |language=en}}</ref> He has also expressed interest in running an animal-based TV show.<ref name=":0" />

=== Books ===
Kyle released a book titled "Guardian of the Realm" about him and his pet meerkat Mylo.<ref name=":2" /> The book was written by Kyle and illustrated by Amrit Birdi, the Number 1 [[The Sunday Times|Sunday Times]] best selling Comic Book Artist.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Thomas |first=Kyle |url=https://www.penguin.co.uk/books/448163/guardian-of-the-realm-by-thomas-kyle/9781405952170 |title=Guardian of the Realm |last2=Reppion |first2=John |last3=Moore |first3=Leah |date=2022-07-21 |others=Illustrated by Amrit Birdi |language=en}}</ref>

== Personal life ==
Kyle was born in [[Kent]] on 19 September 2004, but is now based in [[Belfast]], [[Northern Ireland]]. He left school aged 16 to focus on his his social media career.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3" />

== Controversies ==

=== "Queen Elizabeth" the Capybara ===
Kyle's mother Zena Foord were convicted of smuggling a capybara from England to Northern Ireland with the help of a pet shop owner Michael Dickinson, and a man named James Hammond who transported the animal. Foord, Dickinson and Hammond were arrested and all pleaded guilty at [[Lisburn Courthouse|Lisburn Magistrate's Court]]. They were given two-year conditional discharged, and faced no jail time.<ref name=":4" />

Following [[Brexit]], any animals travelling between [[Great Britain]] and [[Northern Ireland]] require documentation. Authorities were notified the animal did not have the correct documentation following a visit to a vet after it became unwell.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news |last=Crisp |first=James |date=2023-08-17 |title=Brexit border row over capybara smuggled from England to Northern Ireland |language=en-GB |work=The Telegraph |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2023/08/17/capybara-queen-elizabeth-brexit-border-row-northern-ireland/ |access-date=2023-08-31 |issn=0307-1235}}</ref>

The Capybara, named "Queen Elizabeth" was often featured on Kyle's TikTok account.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Sandlin |first=Jennifer |date=2022-12-30 |title=Watch a capybara named Queen Elizabeth eating fruits and veg |url=https://boingboing.net/2022/12/30/watch-a-capybara-named-queen-elizabeth-eating-fruits-and-veg.html |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=Boing Boing |language=en-US}}</ref>

'''Palazzo Malinverni''' is a historical building in [[Legnano]]. It is the seat of the Town Hall (building) of the city. It is located in the central Piazza San Magno, next to the homonymous Basilica and was inaugurated on 28 November 1909,<ref name="cita-D-Ilario-p104">D’Ilario p. 104.</ref> during the city's period of greatest growth — industrial and demographic.

== History ==
The first seat of Legnano's town hall was a building in Piazza Grande (the modern Piazza San Magno) at no. 52.<ref name="cita-Autori-vari-p62">Autori vari p. 62 .</ref> The process that led to the design of Legnano's new town hall began in 1904, with the publication of the competition notice.<ref name=":0">Ferrarini p. 87.</ref> The latter envisaged the design of a three-storey building with a decreasing height starting from the ground floor and rising towards the attic: 5 m, 4.8 m and 3.5 m.<ref name=":0" /> Two entrances were planned, the main one towards the modern largo Franco Tosi and the secondary entrance, which would give onto via Bernardino Luini.<ref name=":0" />

The town hall was to be provided with a council chamber large enough to accommodate the seats of 40 councillors, members of the municipal council, the mayor, the secretary and the public.<ref name=":0" /> In addition, rooms were planned that would have housed the porter's lodge, the telegraph office, the duty post and the savings bank.<ref name=":0" /> It would have had underground rooms and the total number of rooms would have been 30.<ref name=":0" />

The projects that ranked in the top three places would be given a prize of 1,000, 500 and 250 [[Italian lira|litre]] respectively. A total expenditure of 100,000 lire was planned.<ref name=":0" /> It was then built from 1908 to 1909 to a design by architect Aristide Malinverni with a total expenditure that turned out to be three times the budgeted.<ref name=":0" />

== Description ==
It has a [[medieval|medieval architecture]] style with exposed brickwork and [[Bifora|bifore]] windows to which are added parts that recall other architectural styles such as [[Art Nouveau]] and [[neo-Renaissance]]. The upper cornice is decorated with the coats of arms of the municipalities that were part of the [[Lombard League]] and with those of the provincial capitals, including the coats of arms of the Pola, [[Province of Fiume|Fiume]] and [[Province of Zara|Zara]], which belonged to Italy between the two world wars. The coats of arms — created in graffito by the Ghiringhelli brothers — of the 100 cities of Italy that have been depicted in the Council Chamber and the paintings — on the first floor — by Ettore Falchi and Ernesto Crespi are valuable from an artistic point of view.

'''Érico de Paula Coelho Filho''' (8 September 1944 – 29 October 2014), simply known as '''Nenê''', was a Brazilian former professional footballer and manager who played as a [[Midfielder (association football)|midfielder]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://spfcpedia.com.br/enciclopedia/2021/Enciclopedia2021_00_2.pdf |title=Todos os Jogadores |website=SPFCpédia |access-date=30 August 2023 |language=pt}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://terceirotempo.uol.com.br/que-fim-levou/nene-peito-de-pombo-1565 |title=Que fim levou? Nenê peito de pombo |website=Terceiro Tempo |access-date=30 August 2023 |language=pt}}</ref>

==Career==

Nenê started in the youth categories of Piraju FC, and after a victory over the São Paulo reserves, was signed by the club. He played for several years at the Morumbi, until ended his career at São Bento de Sorocaba, the city where he created ties and lived until his last days. He was coach of two clubs in the city (São Bento and Atlético Sorocaba).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ge.globo.com/sp/tem-esporte/video/ex-sao-paulo-e-sao-bento-nene-morre-em-sorocaba-aos-70-anos-3729284.ghtml |title=Ex-São Paulo e São Bento, Nenê morre em Sorocaba aos 70 anos |website=GloboEsporte |access-date=30 August 2023 |language=pt}}</ref>

name: Cancellation Series
info:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cancellation_Series

Wikishovel: added Category:Mathematical series; removed {{uncategorized}} using HotCat

{{Orphan|date=August 2023}}

In mathematics, a [[telescoping series]] is a very important series for nowadays technology achievement.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Tessema |first=Ameha Tefera |date=/26/2021 |title=Cancellation Series |url=http://article.sapub.org/Mathematical%20series%20play%20an%20important%20role%20in%20various%20aspects%20of%20our%20life%20and%20help%20to%20predict,%20evaluate%20and%20monitor%20the%20outcome%20of%20a%20situation%20in%20order%20to%20pass%20decision.%20The%20purpose%20of%20this%20paper%20is%20to%20develop%20a%20new%20kind%20of%20series%20%20%20and%20the%20sum%20or%20deduction%20of%20two%20terms%20of%20which%20fractionally%20cancel%20in%20order%20to%20get%20the%20cancellation%20result%20.%20let%20for%20all%20%20%20%20and%20let%20%20such%20that%20%20and%20%20then%20. |journal=American Journal of Mathematics and Statistics |language=en |volume=11 |issue=3 |pages=59–60 |issn=2162-8475}}</ref>

It is very simple to use because of its alternative positive and negative sign for the same term in order to get cancellation zero and the sum of series() must be represented only by after each term cancelling with part of the next term is known as the method of differences.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Telescoping series - Components, Formula, and Technique |url=https://www.storyofmathematics.com/telescoping-series/ |access-date=2023-08-31 |language=en-US}}</ref>

The cancellation series can generate different kinds of unknown but viable series, which can be a base for number theory specifically and for mathematics in general. The benefit of this series enables us to add up sequences of couple terms having similar pattern. Here the result of cancellation series is the difference or addition between the first and last terms and the number of cancelled results even though the result of telescoping series leaves the difference between first and last term.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Telescoping Series - Mathonline |url=http://mathonline.wikidot.com/telescoping-series |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=mathonline.wikidot.com}}</ref>

It also utilizes the technique of [[partial fractions]] which is a way for us to express a rational function (algebraic fraction) as a sum of simpler fractions. The method does have a great addition to mathematics by simplifying tedious series into three terms.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Osler |first=Thomas J. |date=2007-03 |title=91.12 Some long telescoping series |url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/mathematical-gazette/article/abs/9112-some-long-telescoping-series/A674E63F5DF243BB92E607B6EF1E22E0 |journal=The Mathematical Gazette |language=en |volume=91 |issue=520 |pages=104–105 |doi=10.1017/S0025557200181082 |issn=0025-5572}}</ref>

The purpose of cancellation series is to get cancellation   and to form a new kind of series. The process of cancellation series is fractional. Therefore, this idea does have an effort in solving different mathematical problems.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Glaister |first=Paul |date=1991-12 |title=75.45 Telescoping series |url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/mathematical-gazette/article/abs/7545-telescoping-series/D89178448C75EFD65FA40CF528966366 |journal=The Mathematical Gazette |language=en |volume=75 |issue=474 |pages=443–445 |doi=10.2307/3618631 |issn=0025-5572}}</ref>
