The '''Telegraph Messengers Club''' was a [[rugby league]] club in [[Auckland]], [[New Zealand]] which existed from [[1916 Auckland Rugby League season|1916]] to [[1919 Auckland Rugby League season|1919]]. They competed in the [[Auckland Rugby League]] lower grade competitions. They were initially affiliated to the [[Ponsonby Ponies|Ponsonby United]] club before amalgamating with the [[Maritime Football Club]] during the 1920 season. They were composed of telegraph messengers for the Post and Telegraph organisation hence their name.

==History==
===1916 formation and debut season===
On May 8, 1916 “the Telegraph Messengers Club wrote nominating a team for the sixth grade, and the secretary was instructed to make the necessary arrangements for affiliation”.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Northern Union/Saturday’s Matches
| page = 3
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume XLVII, Issue 110
| date = 1916-05-09
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19160509.2.26
| accessdate = 2023-08-29}}</ref> The Observer newspaper said that they were “messenger boys”.<ref>{{cite news
| title =The League Game
| page = 10
| publisher = Observer, Volume XXXVI, Issue 37
| date = 1916-05-20
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/TO19160520.2.17.1
| accessdate = 2023-08-29}}</ref> They were affiliated with the [[Ponsonby Ponies|Ponsonby United]] club which was common for lower grade teams when forming.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Telegraph Messengers
| page = 7
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume XLVII, Issue 155
| date = 1916-06-30
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19160630.2.96
| accessdate = 2023-08-29}}</ref> Ultimately they entered a Fifth grade team and played their first match against [[Grafton Athletic]] at [[Devonport, Auckland|Devonport]] No. 1 at 2pm on May 20.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Grafton Athletic
| page = 7
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume XLVII, Issue 119
| date = 1916-05-19
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19160519.2.84
| accessdate = 2023-08-29}}</ref> The score was not reported however they lost the match. The Telegraph Messengers club had protested the result arguing that Emiraldi who played for Grafton was in fact a member of the [[North Shore Albions]]. The protest was initially upheld by the junior board but then reversed by the ARL board as Emeraldi was not a member of the North Shore side.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Auckland Rugby League
| page = 2
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume XLVII, Issue 124
| date = 1916-05-25
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19160525.2.17
| accessdate = 2023-08-29}}</ref>

Their next match was against [[North Shore Albions]] at Victoria Park at 12:45 on May 27. They lost 7 to 6. Their team was listed for the first time and included the following names: Bykers, Foster, Herd (captain), Dodds, Tooley, Knowles, Donaldson, Jones, Tracey, Sharp, Munro, Baker, and Powley.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Ponsonby United/Telegraph Messengers
| page = 7
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume XLVII, Issue 125
| date = 1916-05-26
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19160526.2.82.2
| accessdate = 2023-08-29}}</ref> It was reported in late May that the [[Auckland Rugby League]] chairman, Dick Benson was having a busy time as an instructor of the junior clubs and he was presently working with the Telegraph Messenger side.<ref>{{cite news
| title =The League Game/Notes
| page = 10
| publisher = Observer, Volume XXXVI, Issue 38
| date = 1916-05-27
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/TO19160527.2.17
| accessdate = 2023-08-30}}</ref> The Observer newspaper wrote in early June that “Mr. Sinclair, the organiser of the Telegraph Messengers’ Football Club, is a recent arrival to [[Auckland]] from [[Christchurch]], where he has played in the senior grade in past seasons. At present Mr. Sinclair is assisting in coaching the messenger boys, and in all probability will shortly be found donning the jersey for one of the Auckland city teams”.<ref>{{cite news
| title =The League Game
| page = 10
| publisher = Observer, Volume XXXVI, Issue 39
| date = 1916-06-03
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/TO19160603.2.18
| accessdate = 2023-08-30}}</ref>

The Star (Christchurch) wrote that “from a private letter received in Christchurch, I learn that C.R. Sinclair, who played for the Northern Suburbs Junior team last season, and who has since been transferred to Auckland, has been successful in forming a League club among the telegraph messengers, with a membership of fifty, and the majority of them players. Mr. Sinclair pays tribute to the league officials in Auckland, who he says, are keen and wide awake, and gave him every assistance”.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Rugby League Football/Notes And Comments
| page = 7
| publisher = Star (Christchurch), Issue 11717
| date = 1916-06-06
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/TS19160606.2.89
| accessdate = 2023-08-29}}</ref> He was Charles Sinclair and had transferred to Auckland from the Telegraph Dispatch in April, 1915.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Personals
| page = 7
| publisher = Sun (Christchurch), Volume II, Issue 382
| date = 1915-05-01
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/SUNCH19150501.2.34
| accessdate = 2023-08-29}}</ref> He also wrote that the [[Ponsonby Ponies|Ponsonby Club]] (which Telegraph Messengers were affiliated with) “is doing everything possible for the youths and schoolboys”.<ref>{{cite news
| title =League Rugby/Notes Of The Week
| page = 2
| publisher = Sun (Christchurch), Volume III, Issue 733
| date = 1916-06-16
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/SUNCH19160616.2.5.4
| accessdate = 2023-08-29}}</ref> On June 10 the side played [[Otahuhu Leopards|Ōtāhuhu Rovers]]. The behaviour of the Ōtāhuhu team was remarked on at the Wednesday, Auckland Rugby League meeting with chairman Benson saying “this kind of thing will have to be dealt with firmly” when commenting on the ”unruly conduct of the Ōtāhuhu players in the fifth grade match against Telegraph Messengers on Saturday”. It was then decided to caution the entire side.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Junior Players Cautioned
| page = 4
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LIII, Issue 16256
| date = 1916-06-15
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19160615.2.6.2
| accessdate = 2023-08-29}}</ref> The side struggled to get results, losing to North Shore, [[Manukau Magpies|Manukau]] 7–8, [[Grafton Athletic]] 2–3, and Ōtāhuhu 5–8, though they were competitive in most matches. Their scorers were rarely reported in the newspapers though their loss to Ōtāhuhu said their try scorer was Dodd, and Knowles converted the try.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Otahuhu v. Post and Telegraph
| page = 7
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume XLVII, Issue 169
| date = 1916-07-17
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19160717.2.55
| accessdate = 2023-08-29}}</ref> Heavier defeats followed against North Shore (2-19), and Manukau (7-14) though the later match was awarded to Telegraph Messengers after they protested against a refereeing decision and the Auckland Rugby League agreed.<ref>{{cite news
| title =The League Game
| page = 5
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LIII, Issue 16298
| date = 1916-08-03
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19160803.2.31.1
| accessdate = 2023-08-30}}</ref> This was the only recorded ‘win’ of their season and following an unreported score against City on August 5 their debut season came to an end. They finished having played 11 matches, with 1 win, 7 losses and 3 unreported results. They scored at least 29 points and had at least 59 scored against them finishing approximately last of the 6 sides. At the end of the season their secretary, Sinclair wrote a letter to the league thanking them for their assistance during the season.<ref>{{cite news
| title =The League Game
| page = 10
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LIII, Issue 16334
| date = 1916-09-14
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19160914.2.102.2
| accessdate = 2023-08-30}}</ref> In Ponsonby's annual meeting at the start of the following season their annual report recorded that “the club entered one team in each of the first, second, fourth, and sixth grades, and the Telegraph Club, which is affiliated, entered one team in the fifth grade: although no honours came their way, they put up a good performance, which is a credit to the club”.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Ponsonby United Club
| page = 10
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LIV, Issue 16507
| date = 1917-04-05
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19170405.2.76.1
| accessdate = 2023-08-30}}</ref>

===1917, 5th and 6th Grade teams===
The [[1917 Auckland Rugby League season|1917]] saw the Telegraph Messengers fielding two teams, once again a fifth grade side was entered, joined by a sixth grade team. The fifth grade side for their opening game against City A at Victoria Park was: Mathieson, Herd, Richards, Dodds, Knowles, Paris, Donaldson, Campbell, Munro, Bennett, Shaw, Baker (captain), and Powley. While the sixth grade team to play Richmond was: Clayton, Page (captain), Mackey, Cooke, Keefe, Curson, Curtis, Otway, Lee, O’Brien, Churton, Smith, and Pound.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Telegraph Messengers
| page = 2
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume XLVIII, Issue 118
| date = 1917-05-18
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19170518.2.16
| accessdate = 2023-08-30}}</ref> The fifth grade side had what was possibly their first on field win when they beat City A by 12 points to 3. However the sixth grade side lost their first ever match going down to [[Richmond Rovers]] 7–3.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Northern Union
| page = 7
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume XLVIII, Issue 120
| date = 1917-05-21
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19170521.2.74
| accessdate = 2023-08-30}}</ref> In late May two players joined their sides; Walter George Caddy registering from Richmond to join their 6th grade team, with S Grinlinton joining their 5th grade side from the [[Newton Rangers]] club.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Northern Union/Executive Committee Meeting
| page = 2
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume XLVIII, Issue 123
| date = 1917-05-24
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19170524.2.17
| accessdate = 2023-08-30}}</ref> Towards the end of the season their team lineups were published and the Sixth grade side featured two players named “Cooke”. It is highly likely that one of them is [[Bert Cooke (rugby)|Bert Cooke]] who went on to become a famous [[New Zealand national rugby union team|New Zealand]] rugby international and then later a [[New Zealand rugby league team|New Zealand]] rugby league international. He would have returned to Auckland from his schooling in Hamilton around this time aged 15–16 and was a messenger for the Post and Telegraph Department. He was also known to have played rugby league in the 1910s before joining the Grafton rugby club around 1920.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Telegraph Messengers
| page = 7
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LIV, Issue 16620
| date = 1917-08-17
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19170817.2.100.1
| accessdate = 2023-08-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite news
| title =Story: Cooke, Albert Edward
| publisher = Dictionary Of New Zealand Biography
| url =https://teara.govt.nz/en/biographies/4c32/cooke-albert-edward
| accessdate = 2023-08-30}}</ref>

The Fifth grade side only had 3 of their 12 results reported with the win over City and 2 losses to North Shore and [[City Rovers]] B. While the Sixth grade side won 1, lost 7 from 11 games with 3 results unreported.

===1918, 3 teams and a 4th Grade championship title===
The [[1918 Auckland Rugby League season|1918]] season saw the Telegraph Messengers field three teams for the first time and also saw them win their first and only grade championship. Their Fourth Grade side won the competition when they defeated [[Newton Rangers]] 15 to 2 on September 7. Cliff and Knowles each scored 2 tries, while Bennett kicked a goal.<ref>{{cite news
| title = Fourth Grade/Post And Telegraph V Newton
| page = 7
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume XLIX, Issue 215
| date = 1918-09-09
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19180909.2.63
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref> Of their 12 games played they won 8, lost 1, and had 3 scores unreported. Their Fifth Grade side was not so successful, playing 10 games and winning 1 and losing 4 of the games that had results reported. Several of their losses were heavy (0-42, 0–19, and 0–16). While the Sixth grade side also struggled, with 1 win, 6 losses and 7 scores unreported. They had trouble on attack with scores of 2, 0, 2, 0, 0, and 2, before a 13–5 win over Richmond to end their season.

In mid season the Herald published all three teams to play in the July 20 matches. The Fourth Grade side included: N. Dodds (captain), E. Smith, G. Baker, H. Munro, W. Tracey, Herd, A. Bennett, B. Daly, H. Knowles, D. Campbell, S. Sharpe, R. Cliffe, Chris?, and L. Manley. The fifth grade team named was A. Page, Caddy, W. Whittington, L, Baker, Walker, Menzies, Keele?, Daly, Pearce, Clayton, Dean, Troup, O’Brien, Smith, and McIntosh. While the Sixth grade side was: B. Sweeney, W. Somers, G. McLean, C. Moore, L. Moore, R. Grantly, R. Kelly, S. Dowle, R. Sandford, Wigg, Sleave, Brown, G. Sutherland, D. Sallen, Sampson, and Clark.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Teams for Tomorrow/Telegraph Messengers
| page = 3
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LV, Issue 16906
| date = 1918-07-19
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19180719.2.16.1
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news
| title =Northern Union/Telegraph Messengers
| page = 3
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume XLIX, Issue 213
| date = 1918-09-06
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19180906.2.30
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref>

At the end of the season the Telegraph Messengers fourth grade side travelled to Thames by steamer to play an exhibition game. The match was played on October 12 and saw the Messengers side win 12 to 10. Richmond had finished runners up in the championship to them. For the winning side Daly, Cliffe, Herd, and Shark scored tries with Seagar and Grigg scoring for Richmond, with J. Henderson kicking 2 goals.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Game At Thames
| page = 3
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LV, Issue 16980
| date = 1918-10-14
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19181014.2.13.1
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref>

===1919, Three teams and affiliation with Maritime===
In [[1919 Auckland Rugby League season|1919]] the Post and Telegraph club again fielded three teams in the Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth grades.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Under League Rules/Remainder Of Draw
| page = 7
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LVI, Issue 17146
| date = 1919-04-28
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19190428.2.104.2
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref> It was to be their last season as a standalone organisation as in the middle of the season they affiliated with the [[Maritime Football Club]]. The Fourth grade team fared best of the 3 sides finishing one point behind [[City Rovers]] in second place, tied with [[Otahuhu Leopards|Ōtāhuhu Rovers]].<ref>{{cite news
| title =A league Review/An Interesting Season
| page = 8
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume L, Issue 223
| date = 1919-09-19
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19190919.2.107
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref> At the start of their season their team was named and was virtually identical to the side which won the competition the previous season; Manley, Cliff, Sharpe, Dodds, Campbell, Bell, Bennett, Baker, Smith, Tracey, Herd, and Munro.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Practice Games
| page = 3
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume L, Issue 105
| date = 1919-05-02
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19190502.2.24
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref> Their Fifth and Sixth grade teams were also very similar to the 1918 teams.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Telegraph
| page = 3
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LVI, Issue 17156
| date = 1919-05-09
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19190509.2.5
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news
| title =Post And Telegraph
| page = 5
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LVI, Issue 17162
| date = 1919-05-16
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19190516.2.22.1
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref>

On June 14 the Post and Telegraph Football Club held a meeting in the Auckland Rugby League ‘League Rooms’ during the evening. This was unusual and indicated that there was a serious issue to be discussed.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Post And Telegraph Club
| page = 12
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LVI, Issue 17187
| date = 1919-06-14
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19190614.2.139.2
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref> They went so far as to publish an advertisement in the [[New Zealand Herald]]. It asked “all members to attend a THIS (SATURDAY) NIGHT, to be held in the League Rooms, 5 Swanson Street, at 7:30 p.m. Business: Urgent and important”, and was sent in by W. Pearce, their honorary secretary.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Post & Telegraph Football Club
| page = 18
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LVI, Issue 17187
| date = 1919-06-14
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19190614.2.150.4
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref> It seems that there was a dispute within the club about who had control over it. Messrs Charles Sinclair (their original secretary and organiser of the club), and W. Pearce travelled to the Auckland Rugby League officers on June 25 to the weekly meeting there. They reportedly “waited on the committee to discuss misunderstandings in connection with the Post and Telegraph Club. One stated that the P. and T. Football Club was, or had until recently been under the control of the P. and T. Social Club and asked the league to recognise that social body; while the other gentleman contended otherwise. The committee decided that the matter was one outside its jurisdiction, as it could recognise only registered and affiliated bodies, but the deputation was advised by Mr. Carlaw as to the course most likely to avert further friction”.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Northern Union
| page = 7
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume L, Issue 151
| date = 1919-06-26
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19190626.2.82
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref>

On July 12 all three team lists were published for their July 13 matches. Significantly these were to be their last games as a Telegraph Messengers/Post and Telegraph named club.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Post And Telegraph
| page = 3
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume L, Issue 164
| date = 1919-07-11
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19190711.2.19
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref> They made an application to be affiliated with the [[Maritime Football Club]] and it was granted at the board meeting on July 17.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Northern Union
| page = 7
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume L, Issue 169
| date = 1919-07-17
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19190717.2.81
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref> Interestingly at the start of the [[1920 Auckland Rugby League season|1920]] season W. Pearce of the Telegraph club was appointed the honorary secretary of the Maritime club.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Annual Meetings
| page = 9
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LVII, Issue 17418
| date = 1919-03-13
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19200313.2.126.3
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref>

===Appearances in midweek competitions===
In [[1922 Auckland Rugby League season|1922]] a Post and Telegraph rugby league competition was played midweek in Auckland. They played for the Engineers Cup of the Post and Telegraph Department with matches played on Thursday afternoons at Victoria Park. The teams involved were Postmen, Linesmen, Telegraph, Messengers, Workshops, and Faultmen.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Post and Telegraph Competition
| page = 8
| publisher = Auckland Star, Volume LIII, Issue 175
| date = 1922-07-26
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/AS19220726.2.134
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref> Then in [[1923 Auckland Rugby League season|1923]] Post and Telegraph entered a side in the Wednesday competition. They won it with 7 wins from 8 games, beating Tramways in the final 16-15. Their side featured the likes of [[Arthur Singe]] and [[Wally Somers]]. Somers was a [[New Zealand national rugby league team|New Zealand]] representative from 1919 to 1928, while Singe played for New Zealand in 1925 and 1926. They both worked for the company.<ref>{{cite news
| title =Wednesday Competitions
| page = 4
| publisher = New Zealand Herald, Volume LX, Issue 18407
| date = 1923-05-24
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/NZH19230524.2.7.2
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref> Throughout the same time period there was also a Post and Telegraph Rugby Football Club which played [[rugby union]], and in 1922 they amalgamated with the Technical College Old Boys to become known as United. However in 1927 the club reverted back to the name Technical College Old Boys and in 1950 they moved to [[Cornwall Park, Auckland|Cornwall Park]] and took on the name Cornwall. In the 1980s they became Carlton Rugby Football Club and in 1996 merged with Grammar, with further mergers following they are now part of the [[Grammar TEC RC]].<ref>{{cite news
| title =History
| publisher = Grammar TEC Rugby
| url =http://www.grammartec.co.nz/About-Us/History-1
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref>

The Post and Telegraph Department occasionally fielded rugby league teams into the 1930s before ceasing to do so at some point. In 1929 they played in a one off match against the Trotting Trainers. The in [[1931 Auckland Rugby League season|1931]] they played in the midweek competition at [[Carlaw Park]].<ref>{{cite news
| title =Trotting Lads in Lighter Strain
| page = 13
| publisher = Sun (Auckland), Volume III, Issue 769
| date = 1922-09-16
| url =https://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/newspapers/SUNAK19290916.2.138
| accessdate = 2023-08-31}}</ref>

'''Bethnal Green and Bow''' was an electoral division for the purposes of elections to the [[Greater London Council]]. The constituency elected one councillor for a four-year term in 1973, 1977 and 1981, with the final term extended for an extra year ahead of the abolition of the Greater London Council.

==History==
It was planned to use the same boundaries as the Westminster Parliament constituencies for election of councillors to the Greater London Council (GLC), as had been the practice for elections to the predecessor [[London County Council]], but those that existed in 1965 crossed the Greater London boundary. Until new constituencies could be settled, the 32 London boroughs were used as electoral areas. The London Borough of Tower Hamlets formed the [[Tower Hamlets (electoral division)|Tower Hamlets]] electoral division. This was used for the Greater London Council elections in 1964, 1967 and 1970.

The new constituencies were settled following the [[Second Periodic Review of Westminster constituencies]] and the new electoral division matched the boundaries of the [[Bethnal Green and Bow (UK Parliament constituency)|Bethnal Green and Bow]] parliamentary constituency.

The area was in a long-term period of population decline that was yet to reverse. The electorate reduced from 55,242 in 1973 to 51,159 in 1981. It covered an area of {{convert|810|hectare|sqkm}}.

==Elections==
The Bethnal Green and Bow constituency was used for the Greater London Council elections in [[1973 Greater London Council election|1973]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://data.london.gov.uk/documents/GLCE_1973-4-12.pdf |title=Greater London Council Election | date=12 April 1973 |accessdate=23 July 2023 |url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822164806/http://data.london.gov.uk/documents/GLCE_1973-4-12.pdf |archivedate=22 August 2013}}</ref> [[1977 Greater London Council election|1977]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://data.london.gov.uk/documents/GLCE_1977-5-5.pdf |title=Greater London Council Election | date=5 May 1977 |accessdate=23 July 2023 |url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822160411/http://data.london.gov.uk/documents/GLCE_1977-5-5.pdf |archivedate=22 August 2013 }}</ref> and [[1981 Greater London Council election|1981]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.london.gov.uk/documents/GLCE_1981-5-7.pdf |title=Greater London Council Election | date=7 May 1981 |accessdate=23 July 2023 |url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822145946/http://data.london.gov.uk/documents/GLCE_1981-5-7.pdf |archivedate=22 August 2013 }}</ref> One councillor was elected at each election using [[first-past-the-post]] voting.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Boothroyd |first1=David |title=Greater London Council Election results: Tower Hamlets |url=http://www.election.demon.co.uk/glc/glcth.html |website=United Kingdom Election Results |access-date=29 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151024224533/http://www.election.demon.co.uk/glc/glcth.html |archive-date=24 October 2015}}</ref>

===1973 election===
The fourth election to the GLC (and first using revised boundaries) was held on 12 April 1973. The electorate was 55,242 and one Labour Party councillor was elected. The turnout was 22.0%. The councillor was elected for a three-year term. This was extended for an extra year in 1976 when the electoral cycle was switched to four-yearly.<ref>{{cite web |title=The London Councillors Order 1976 |url=https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/1976/213/pdfs/uksi_19760213_en.pdf |website=legislation.gov.uk |access-date=25 July 2023 |date=17 February 1976}}</ref>

===1977 election===
The fifth election to the GLC (and second using revised boundaries) was held on 5 May 1977. The electorate was 51,172 and one Labour Party councillor was elected. The turnout was 28.7%. The councillor was elected for a four-year term.

===1981 election===
The sixth and final election to the GLC (and third using revised boundaries) was held on 7 May 1981. The electorate was 51,159 and one Labour Party councillor was elected. The turnout was 37.9%. The councillor was elected for a four-year term, extended by an extra year by the Local Government (Interim Provisions) Act 1984, ahead of the abolition of the council.

'''Roberto Paganelli''' is an [[Italian]] [[physician]], clinical [[immunologist]] and [[academic]]. He was a [[Professor]] of [[Internal Medicine]] at the Università G. d’Annunzio.<ref name=yy>{{Cite web|url=https://cn.unich.it/ugov/person/682|title=PAGANELLI Roberto | Università degli Studi "G. d'Annunzio" Chieti - Pescara|website=cn.unich.it}}</ref>

Paganelli is most known for his work on [[allergy]], [[immunology]], inflammatory responses, and [[immunosenescence]], and focusing on [[food allergy]], immune complex diseases, immunoglobulin deficiencies, [[T-cell]] defects, and internal medicine.<ref name=kk>{{Cite web|url=https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=uJQffVMAAAAJ&hl=it|title=Roberto PAGANELLI|website=scholar.google.com}}</ref>

Paganelli is the section editor-in-chief for the journal ''Pathogens''.<ref name=bb>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mdpi.com/journal/pathogens/editors|title=Pathogens|website=www.mdpi.com}}</ref>

==Education==
Paganelli obtained his [[medical degree]] from [[Università degli Studi di Roma "La Sapienza"|Universita La Sapienza]] in 1976 and completed his [[specialization]] in [[Allergy]] and [[Clinical Immunology]] in 1984 from the same university.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unicamillus.org/personnel/paganelli-roberto-2/|title=Paganelli Roberto}}</ref>

==Career==
After an internship at the 3rd Medical Clinic of the Universita La Sapienza in Rome, Paganelli spent four years at the [[University of London]] – Institute of Child Health as [[Research Fellow]] until 1982 under the supervision of [[John Soothill|J.F. Soothill]] and R.J. Levinsky. He then began his academic journey in 1983, by joining the Università degli Studi dell'Aquila as an [[assistant professor]], a role he held until 1984. In November 1984, he became part of the Universita’ La Sapienza, where he served as an assistant professor until 1999. Later, he joined Universita’ G. D’Annunzio and held the position of [[associate professor]] of Internal Medicine from 1999 to 2004, followed by a subsequent appointment as professor from 2004 to 2021.<ref name=yy/>

At Universita’ G. D’Annunzio, Paganelli held multiple appointments, notably as the director of the School of Specialization in Rheumatology from 2007 to 2014, and the director of the School of Specialization in Allergy and Clinical Immunology from 2017 to 2021.

Paganelli serves as the section editor-in-chief for the journal ''Pathogens''.<ref name=bb/>

==Research==
Paganelli's research has focused on the [[Immune system]], allergic diseases, and [[immunopathology]] investigations. He has authored numerous publications spanning the areas of [[clinical immunology]], inflammatory responses, and [[immunosenescence]] including over 250 articles in peer-reviewed journals.<ref name=kk/>

===Immunology===
Paganelli's immunology research has provided insights into the immune system's intricacies and its role in health and disease. Centered on immune complex formation in patients with allergies and parasitic infections,<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/87729/|title=Immune complexes containing food proteins in normal and atopic subjects after oral challenge and effect of sodium cromoglycate on antigen absorption|first1=R.|last1=Paganelli|first2=R. G.|last4=Wraith|date=June 16, 1979|journal=Lancet (London, England)|volume=1|issue=8129|pages=1270–1272|via=PubMed|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(79)92230-x|pmid=87729}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/6601473/|title=Differences between normal and milk allergic subjects in their immune responses after milk ingestion|first1=R.|last1=Paganelli|first2=D. J.|last2=Atherton|first3=R. J.|last3=Levinsky|date=March 31, 1983|journal=Archives of Disease in Childhood|volume=58|issue=3|pages=201–206|via=PubMed|doi=10.1136/adc.58.3.201|pmid=6601473|pmc=1627834}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7379329/|title=Circulating immune complexes in onchocerciasis|first1=R.|last1=Paganelli|first2=J. J.|editor-last=Bourne|date=August 31, 1981|publisher=Springer Netherlands|pages=154–180|via=Springer Link|doi=10.1007/978-94-009-8331-1_8}}</ref> and devised a two-step technique to detect specific antigens in serum sample immune complexes.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/6896019/|title=Detection of specific antigen within circulating immune complexes: validation of the assay and its application to food antigen-antibody complexes formed in healthy and food-allergic subjects|first1=R.|last1=Paganelli|first2=R. J.|last3=Atherton|date=October 31, 1981|journal=Clinical and Experimental Immunology|volume=46|issue=1|pages=44–53|via=PubMed|pmid=6896019|pmc=1536342}}</ref> His research into the involvement of immune complexes in atopic dermatitis (AD)<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2683844/|title=Role of immune complexes in atopic dermatitis|first1=R.|last1=Paganelli|first2=E.|last2=Scala|first3=E.|last3=Guerra|first4=I.|last4=Quinti|date=August 31, 1989|journal=Allergy|volume=44 Suppl 9|pages=65–69|via=PubMed|pmid=2683844}}</ref> revealed that while immune system imbalances are present in AD, these disparities might be consequential rather than the fundamental cause of the condition.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10417442/|title=Heterogeneity of atopic dermatitis defined by the immune response to inhalant and food allergens|first1=Fabrizi|last1=G|first2=Romano|last2=A|first3=Vultaggio|last3=P|first4=Bellegrandi|last4=S|first5=Paganelli|last5=R|first6=Venuti|last6=A|date=July 31, 1999|journal=European journal of dermatology : EJD|volume=9|issue=5|via=pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov|pmid=10417442}}</ref> Furthermore, his investigation into the impacts of prolonged exposure to electromagnetic fields (ELMFs) from radio and television broadcasting stations on women's immune systems revealed diminished levels of diverse immune cell types, coupled with reduced production of crucial immune-regulating molecules.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11419593/|title=Effects of electromagnetic fields produced by radiotelevision broadcasting stations on the immune system of women|first1=P.|last1=Boscol|first2=M. ===Inflammatory responses===
Paganelli's research has explored the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying inflammatory responses. In collaboration with GA Rabinovich, he investigated the extracellular and intracellular functions of galectins and provided insights into mechanisms for controlling cellular processes such as proliferation, signal transduction, and cell death.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12072371/|title=Galectins and their ligands: amplifiers, silencers or tuners of the 2009 study on tendinopathy pathogenesis highlighted the collaborative relationship between inflammation and degeneration and proposed that overuse-induced micro-tears in tendon fibers lead to a dynamic interplay of healing processes, inflammation, neovascularization, and nerve growth.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19591655/|title=Pathogenesis of tendinopathies: name: 1975 Copa Libertadores group stage
info:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1975_Copa_Libertadores_group_stage

Ardije:

The '''1975 Copa Libertadores group stage''' or 1975 Copa Libertadores first stage was played from 16 February to 11 April 1975. A total of 20 teams competed in the group stage to decide 5 places in the [[1975 Copa Libertadores semi-finals|semi-finals]] of the [[1975 Copa Libertadores]], where they joined [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]], who qualified directly to the semi-finals as defending champions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.conmebol.com/galeria-historica/libertadores-1975-11-participantes-campeon-independiente-argentina-vicecampeon-union-espanola-chile/|title=Libertadores 1975: 11 participantes – Campeón: Independiente (Argentina) Vicecampeón: Unión Española (Chile)|publisher=[[CONMEBOL]]|website=CONMEBOL.com|language=es|date=20 June 2017|access-date=31 August 2023}}</ref>

==Groups composition==
The 20 participating teams were divided into 5 groups of 4, which consisted of two teams from one national association and two teams from another.

*Group 1: {{fba|ARG}} and {{fba|PAR}}
*Group 2: {{fba|CHI}} and {{fba|BOL}}
*Group 3: {{fba|BRA}} and {{fba|COL}}
*Group 4: {{fba|ECU}} and {{fba|VEN}}
*Group 5: {{fba|PER}} and {{fba|BOL}}

==Format==
In the group stage, each group was played on a home-and-away [[round-robin tournament|round-robin]] basis. The teams were ranked according to the following criteria: 1. [[Points (association football)|Points]] (2 points for a win, 1 point for a draw, and 0 points for a loss); 2. [[Goal difference]]

If two teams from the same national association tie on points, the above criteria would not apply and their final positions would be determined in an extra match to be played at a venue within their own country that was decided by drawing of lots. Winners of this match qualified for the seminfinals; in the event of a draw, the team with the best goal difference in the group would have qualified.

The winners of each group advanced to the [[1975 Copa Libertadores semi-finals|semi-finals]].

name: El Norte: The Epic and Forgotten Story of Hispanic North America
info:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/El_Norte:_The_Epic_and_Forgotten_Story_of_Hispanic_North_America

Onel5969: clean up, typo(s) fixed: Spainish → Spanish

{{short description|}}
__NOTOC__
{{Use British English|date=August 2023}}{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2023}}

{{Infobox book
| italic title = yes
| name = El Norte: The Epic and Forgotten Story of Hispanic North America
| image =
| alt =
| caption = Book cover
| author = [[Carrie Gibson]]
| audio_read_by = [[Thom Rivera]]
| language = English
| subject = [[New Spain]], [[Spanish Empire]]
| genre = Non-fiction, history
| publisher = [[Atlantic Monthly Press]]
| pub_date = 2019
| pages = 576
| isbn = 978-0802127020
| website = [https://groveatlantic.com/book/el-norte/ Grove Atlantic]
}}

'''''El Norte: The Epic and Forgotten Story of Hispanic North America''''' is a book by [[Carrie Gibson]] published in 2019 by [[Atlantic Monthly Press]]. The work explores the world of [[New Spain]] by profiling a variety of centers of Spanish power and settlement, from the earliest settlements in what would become [[Puerto Rico]], [[Florida]] and the southeastern United States, to middle American settlements such as [[New Madrid, Missouri]], and settlements in [[The Californias]] and what would become the American southwest. The work covers the period from initial Spanish exploration and settlement in North American during the 16th century to the beginning of the 21st century.<ref>{{Citation | website=American Quarterly | vauthors=((Crandall, R.)) | title=El Norte: The Epic and Forgotten Story of Hispanic North America | url=https://americasquarterly.org/article/el-norte-the-epic-and-forgotten-story-of-hispanic-north-america/ | access-date=29 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Citation | website=New York Times | vauthors=((Ortega, J.)) | year=2019 | title=Anglos, Hispanics and the Formation of America | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/06/books/review/carrie-gibson-el-norte.html | access-date=29 August 2023}}</ref>

==Structure==
The work begins with normal front material and an author's Introduction about Nogales, Arizona, followed by 16 chapters each focused on a Spanish settlement:

* Chapter 1: Santa Elena, South Carolina, ca. 1492–1550
* Chapter 2: St. Johns River, Florida, ca. 1550–1700
* Chapter 3: Alcade, New Mexico, ca. 1540–1720
* Chapter 4: Fort Mose, Florida, ca. 1600–1760
* Chapter 5: New Madrid, Missouri, ca. 1760–90
* Chapter 6: Nootka Sound, Canada, ca. 1760s–1789
* Chapter 7: New Orleans, Louisiana, ca. 1790–1804
* Chapter 8: Sabine River, ca. 1804–23
* Chapter 9: San Antonio de Béxar, Texas, ca. 1820–48
* Chapter 10: Mesilla, New Mexico, ca. 1850–77
* Chapter 11: Ybor City, Florida, ca. 1870–98
* Chapter 12: Del Rio, Texas, ca. 1910–40
* Chapter 13: New York, ca. 1920s–’60s
* Chapter 14: Los Angeles, California ca. 1920s–’70s
* Chapter 15: Miami, Florida, ca. 1960–80
* Chapter 16: Tucson, Arizona, ca. 1994–2018

The work concludes with an epilogue about Georgia in 1914, a bibliography and timeline of key events.

* {{Citation | website=Foreign Affairs | vauthors=((Feinberg, R.)) | year=2020 | title=El Norte: The Epic and Forgotten Story of Hispanic North America | url=https://www.foreignaffairs.com/reviews/capsule-review/2020-04-14/el-norte-epic-and-forgotten-story-hispanic-north-america | access-date=29 August 2023}}
* {{Citation | website=The Guardian | vauthors=((Kaiser, C.)) | year=2019 | title=El Norte review: an epic and timely history of Hispanic North America | url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2019/mar/16/el-norte-review-carrie-gibson-epic-history-hispanic-north-america | access-date=29 August 2023}}
* {{Citation | website=New York Times | vauthors=((Ortega, J.)) | year=2019 | title=Anglos, Hispanics and the Formation of America | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/06/books/review/carrie-gibson-el-norte.html | access-date=29 August 2023}}
* {{Citation | vauthors=((Sherman, M.)) | website=Jazebel | year=2019 | title=Carrie Gibson’s El Norte Recenters the Continent’s Hispanic History | url=https://jezebel.com/carrie-gibsons-el-norte-recenters-the-continents-hispan-1832307391 | access-date=29 August 2023}}
* {{Citation | vauthors=((Duffy, B.)) | title=El Norte: The Epic and Forgotten Story of Hispanic North America | website=Washington Independent Review of Books | url=https://www.washingtonindependentreviewofbooks.com/index.php/bookreview/el-norte-the-epic-and-forgotten-story-of-hispanic-north-america | access-date=29 August 2023}}

==Publication history==
* Gibson, C. (2019). El Norte: The Epic and Forgotten Story of Hispanic North America (Original hardback edition, audiobook, and ebook). Atlantic Monthly Press.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://groveatlantic.com/book/el-norte/|website=Grove/Atlantic Publisher|title=El Norte: The Epic and Forgotten Story of Hispanic North America |access-date=27 August 2023}}</ref>
* Gibson, C. (2020). El Norte: The Epic and Forgotten Story of Hispanic North America (Paperback edition). Grove/Atlantic.

==About the author==
{{ Main|Carrie Gibson }}
Carrie Gibson is a British author and historian focusing on the Spanish Caribbean in the era of the Haitian Revolution. They earned their PhD from [[Cambridge University]]. In addition to ''El Notre'' are also the author of ''[[Empire's Crossroads: A History of the Caribbean from Columbus to the Present Day]]'' published by Atlantic Monthly Press in 2014.<ref>{{Citation |website=Atlantic Grove Press | title=Empire’s Crossroads: A History of the Caribbean from Columbus to the Present Day | url=https://groveatlantic.com/book/empires-crossroads/ | access-date=30 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |website=Atlantic Grove Press | title=Carrie Gibson |website=Grove Atlantic | url=https://groveatlantic.com/book/el-norte/ | access-date=30 August 2023}}</ref>

==Similar or related works==

* ''[[América: The Epic Story of Spanish North America, 1493-1898]]'' by [[Robert Goodwin]]
* ''[[The Encomenderos of New Spain, 1521-1555]]'' by [[Robert Himmerich y Valencia]] and [[Joseph P. Sánchez]]

'''Matías Emiliano Rocha Calderón''' (born 13 February 2001) is a Uruguayan professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as an [[centre-back]] for [[F.C. Arouca|Arouca]].

==Professional career==
Rocha is a youth product of [[Defensor Sporting]], and on 22 December 2020 signed a professional contract with the club for 3 seasons.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.elobservador.com.uy/nota/mercado-de-pases-rodrigo-rojo-de-penarol-a-defensor-202012193836|title=Mercado de pases: Ignacio Lores es nuevo jugador de Wanderers|website=El Observador}}</ref> He was part of the Defensor side that earned promotion to the [[Uruguayan Primera División]] in 2021, and won the [[2022 Copa Uruguay]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.espn.com.mx/futbol/uruguay/nota/_/id/12425627/defensor-sporting-matias-rocha-fichaje-arouca-portugal|title=Matías Rocha dejó Defensor Sporting para jugar en Portugal|date=August 10, 2023|website=ESPN.com.mx}}</ref> In the summer of 2023, he was due to transfer to the Argentine club [[Unión de Santa Fe]], but the move fell through.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://euro.eseuro.com/local/752924.html|title=Matías Rocha is already in Santa Fe to join Unión}}</ref> Instead on 11 August 2023, he transferred to the [[Primeira Liga]] club [[F.C. Arouca|Arouca]] on a 4-year contract.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://maisfutebol.iol.pt/transferencias/arouca/oficial-internacional-sub-20-uruguaio-e-o-sucessor-de-basso-no-arouca|title=OFICIAL: internacional sub-20 uruguaio é o sucessor de Basso no Arouca|website=Maisfutebol}}</ref>

==International career==
Rocha was called up to the [[Uruguay national under-20 football team|Uruguay U20]]s in October 2020.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.auf.org.uy/27-convocados-en-la-sub-20/|title=27 convocados en la sub-20 - AUF|website=www.auf.org.uy}}</ref>

name: Twickenham (electoral division)
info:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twickenham_(electoral_division)

MRSC: /* Elections */

{{Short description|Electoral division in Greater London, 1973–1986}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2023}}
{{Use British English|date=August 2023}}
{{Infobox constituency
|name = Twickenham
|constituency_type = electoral division
|parl_name = [[Greater London Council]]
|district = [[London Borough of Richmond upon Thames|Richmond upon Thames]]
|towns = [[Twickenham]]
|year = 1973
|abolished = 1986
|members = 1
|next =
|previous = [[Richmond upon Thames (electoral division)|Richmond upon Thames]]
|population =
|electorate = {{ubl|72,265 (1973)|71,699 (1977)|70,875 (1981)}}
|area = {{convert|2842|hectare|sqkm}}
}}
'''Twickenham''' was an electoral division for the purposes of elections to the [[Greater London Council]]. The constituency elected one councillor for a four-year term in 1973, 1977 and 1981, with the final term extended for an extra year ahead of the abolition of the Greater London Council.

==History==
It was planned to use the same boundaries as the Westminster Parliament constituencies for election of councillors to the Greater London Council (GLC), as had been the practice for elections to the predecessor [[London County Council]], but those that existed in 1965 crossed the Greater London boundary. Until new constituencies could be settled, the 32 London boroughs were used as electoral areas. The London Borough of Richmond upon Thames formed the [[Richmond upon Thames (electoral division)|Richmond upon Thames]] electoral division. This was used for the Greater London Council elections in 1964, 1967 and 1970.

The new constituencies were settled following the [[Second Periodic Review of Westminster constituencies]] and the new electoral division matched the boundaries of the [[Twickenham (UK Parliament constituency)|Twickenham ]] parliamentary constituency.

It covered an area of {{convert|2842|hectare|sqkm}}.

==Elections==
The Twickenham constituency was used for the Greater London Council elections in [[1973 Greater London Council election|1973]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://data.london.gov.uk/documents/GLCE_1973-4-12.pdf |title=Greater London Council Election | date=12 April 1973 |accessdate=23 July 2023 |url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822164806/http://data.london.gov.uk/documents/GLCE_1973-4-12.pdf |archivedate=22 August 2013}}</ref> [[1977 Greater London Council election|1977]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://data.london.gov.uk/documents/GLCE_1977-5-5.pdf |title=Greater London Council Election | date=5 May 1977 |accessdate=23 July 2023 |url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822160411/http://data.london.gov.uk/documents/GLCE_1977-5-5.pdf |archivedate=22 August 2013 }}</ref> and [[1981 Greater London Council election|1981]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.london.gov.uk/documents/GLCE_1981-5-7.pdf |title=Greater London Council Election | date=7 May 1981 |accessdate=23 July 2023 |url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822145946/http://data.london.gov.uk/documents/GLCE_1981-5-7.pdf |archivedate=22 August 2013 }}</ref> One councillor was elected at each election using [[first-past-the-post]] voting.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Boothroyd |first1=David |title=Greater London Council Election results: Richmond upon Thames |url=http://www.election.demon.co.uk/glc/glcrm.html |website=United Kingdom Election Results |access-date=29 August 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304090813/http://www.election.demon.co.uk/glc/glcrm.html |archive-date=4 March 2016}}</ref>

===1973 election===
The fourth election to the GLC (and first using revised boundaries) was held on 12 April 1973. The electorate was 72,265 and one Conservative Party councillor was elected. The turnout was 44.0%. The councillor was elected for a three-year term. This was extended for an extra year in 1976 when the electoral cycle was switched to four-yearly.<ref>{{cite web |title=The London Councillors Order 1976 |url=https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/1976/213/pdfs/uksi_19760213_en.pdf |website=legislation.gov.uk |access-date=25 July 2023 |date=17 February 1976}}</ref>

===1977 election===
The fifth election to the GLC (and second using revised boundaries) was held on 5 May 1977. The electorate was 71,699 and one Conservative Party councillor was elected. The turnout was 50.0%. The councillor was elected for a four-year term.

{{Short description|Australian radio play by Edmund Barclay}}
'''''Nocturne''''' is a 1939 Australian radio play by [[Edmund Barclay]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article234333704 |title="BOHEMIA" IN CITY LIFE. |newspaper=[[Macleay Argus]] |issue=8682 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=24 February 1939 |accessdate=31 August 2023 |page=9 |via=National Library of Australia}} </ref>

It was called "a play of King's Cross, or of acorresponding section of Melbourne, or other Australian city, and it is a play of people enjoying the night life of the place, and who imagine they are having "a devil of a time"
— frightfully smart and delightfully wicked."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article214649076 |title=Radio Programmes |newspaper=[[Nambucca And Bellinger News]] |volume=34, |issue=1709 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=24 February 1939 |accessdate=31 August 2023 |page=4 |via=National Library of Australia}} </ref>

name: Assault Breaker
info:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assault_Breaker

Mztourist: link

'''Assault Breaker''' was a [[Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency]] (DARPA) program begun in 1978 to integrate a number of technologies including lasers, electro-optical sensors, microelectronics, data processors and radars important for [[precision guided munition]]s (PGMs).<ref name=DARPA>{{cite web|url=https://www.darpa.mil/about-us/timeline/assault-breaker|title=Assault Breaker|publisher=Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency|access-date=31 August 2023}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>

Assault Breaker was conceived to attack moving, rear echelon armor massed deep behind enemy lines. At the time the program commenced the only means for attacking these targets was by the use of manned, penetrating aircraft. The perceived advantage of Assault Breaker was that it would permit attacking these targets with [[Standoff missile|standoff weapons]]. Assault Breaker was conceived to obtain a uniquely high kill rate at a much smaller risk and cost than existing tactics permitted. [[United States Department of Defense]] officials believed that Assault Breaker's fire rate could destroy in a few hours sufficient vehicles in [[Warsaw Pact]] reinforcement divisions to prevent their exploiting a breakthrough at the [[forward edge of battle area]]. Two modes of delivering Assault Breaker munitions were considered, ground-launched
and air-launched missiles. Assault Breaker involved the use of an airborne radar, airborne or surface launchers, strike missiles with submunition dispensers, self-guided submunitions that are dispensed over the target and a communications, command and control
network to link the target acquisition, data transmission and strike functions.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gao.gov/assets/masad-81-9.pdf|title=Decisions to be made in charting future of DoD's Assault Breaker|publisher=Government Accountability Office|date=28 February 1981|access-date=31 August 2023|page=1}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>

The program had four phases:

*The first phase involved a focussed effort on the component technologies - verifying that they really were available and that their performance estimates added up to a feasible overall concept.
*The second phase involved testing most of the critical component technologies in parallel and making further developments as necessary. At least two contractors were involved in all the tests and developments. Thus, there were two different approaches, by [[Hughes Aircraft Company]] and [[Norden Systems]], to the [[Pave Mover]] radar system and for the related ground processing stations; two "missile bus" contractors, [[Martin Marietta]] for the [[MIM-104 Patriot|Patriot]] (T16) and [[Ling-Temco-Vought]] for the [[MGM-52 Lance|Lance]] (T22) missile; and two subminitions contractors, [[General Dynamics]] for the TGSM and [[AVCO]] for the [[BLU-108|SKEET]]. Submunitions components were tested individually, with emphasis on the required dispensing and homing properties.
*In the third phase gradually more complex degrees of system integration were tested. Missile flight tests were conducted, first with inertial guidance only: the T-16 used a Stellar-sight gyro update and the T-22 used an Army-developed optical laser gyro. Later, radar guidance, ground and airborne, was used to steer the missile. Both missiles qualified successfully, achieving the desired accuracies. After this, tests were made including integration of the submunitions with the missile, along with increased complexity in the command signals directing the time, location, and characteristics of submunitions release.
*In the last phase of the program, tests of the combined airborne radar-missile submunitions systems were conducted against some tank targets at [[White Sands Missile Range]]. The final tests (which involved a ground-based radar simulating the Pave Mover) in late 1982 had several failures; but in the last test five TGSMs made five direct hits, one on each tank in a pattern of five stationary tanks. The SKEETs however did not achieve any hits.<ref name=Technical>{{cite web|url=https://apps.dtic.mil/sti/pdfs/ADA241725.pdf|title=DARPA Technical Accomplishments Volume II|publisher=Institute for Defense Analyses|date=April 1991|access-date=31 August 2023}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>{{rp|5-9}}

The major technological features had been demonstrated by the DARPA program, proof of concept was established and a decision could have been made to enter full scale engineering development if the services had adopted Assault Breaker as a system.<ref name=Technical/>{{rp|5-11}}

DARPA outlays for Assault Breaker and related previous studies from project records appear to have been about $155 million; for Pave Mover about $50 million.<ref name=Technical/>{{rp|5-19}}

Over a four-year period, Assault Breaker laid the technological foundation for several smart-weapon systems that were ultimately fielded. Among these systems were the [[Joint Surveillance Target Attack Radar System]] (JSTARS), which integrated PGMs with advanced intelligence, surveillance and reconnaissance (ISR) systems developed with DARPA support; the [[Global Hawk]] unmanned aerial vehicles; a [[United States Air Force]] air-to-ground missile with terminally guided submunitions; the [[Army Tactical Missile System]] (ATMS), which featured all-weather, day/night capability effective against mobile and other targets; and the [[Brilliant Anti-Tank]] (BAT) submunition, which used acoustic sensors on its wings to detect and target tanks.<ref name=DARPA/>

==References==
{{reflist}}

مسیریاب سخنگو فارسی + نقشه و مکان یاب انلاین برای موبایل، برنامه جی پی اس Gps|date=November 7, 2022|website=ایمنا|access-date=August 31, 2023|archive-date=August 31, name: Frank Smullin
info:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Smullin

Wikishovel: + 5 categories using HotCat

{{Orphan|date=August 2023}}

'''Frank Mayer Smullin''' (10 March 1943 - 14 November 1983) was an American sculptor known for pioneering computer-aided methods in art and for his large welded tubular sculptures.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |title=Frank Smullin |url=http://act.mit.edu/cavs/person/EHuxLEh0H8zSzv7I1wjgHd |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=act.mit.edu}}</ref>

== Biography ==
Frank Smullin was born on 10 March 1943. He received a Master of Fine Arts at Columbia University in 1972,<ref name=":1">{{Cite book |last=Duke University |url=http://archive.org/details/bulletinofdukeun7302duke |title=Bulletin of Duke University [serial] |last2=Nicholas School of the Environment (Duke University) |last3=Nicholas School of the Environment (Duke University). Marine Laboratory |last4=Duke University. School of Law |last5=Duke University. Divinity School |last6=Duke University. Trinity College of Arts and Sciences |last7=Duke University. School of Engineering |last8=Fuqua School of Business (Duke University) |last9=Duke University. Graduate School |date=1929 |publisher=Durham, N.C. : The University |others=Duke University Libraries}}</ref> and was a Fellow from 1979 to 1980 at MIT's Center for Advanced Visual Studies and Sculpture Space in Utica, New York, which helped enabled him to make large-scale works.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite web |title=BU Public Art Artists » Arts Initiative {{!}} Boston University |url=https://www.bu.edu/arts/public-art/artists/#frank-smullin |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=www.bu.edu}}</ref>

Smullin went on to teach design and art at Duke University,<ref name=":1" /> where his interdisciplinary course "Structures" was co-taught by Smullin together with the zoologist Steve Wainwright and engineer George Pearsall.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Wiebe |first=Eric N. |date=30 November 1997 |title=Turning Point |url=https://alumni.duke.edu/magazine/articles/duke-university-alumni-magazine-87 |journal=Duke University Alumni Magazine}}</ref> He passed away on 14 November 1983 at the age of 40.<ref>{{Cite web |title=The Boston Globe 21 Nov 1983, page 23 |url=https://bostonglobe.newspapers.com/image/437533836/ |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=Newspapers.com |language=en}}</ref>

== Sculptures ==
Smullin's art, which he referred to as Analytic Constructivism,<ref>{{Cite book |last=Smullin |first=Frank |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w5VPAAAAMAAJ&newbks=0&hl=en |title=Frank Smullin--sculpture & Drawings: April 1-April 29, 1984, School of Design Gallery, North Carolina State University |date=1984 |publisher=Duke University |language=en}}</ref> includes massive sheet metal sculptures found around university campuses on the East Coast, including Boston University,<ref name=":2" /> Columbia University,<ref>{{Cite web |date=2016-05-05 |title=“Utica Overland” (or “The Pipes”), Frank Smullin (1980) |url=https://qcpublicart.wordpress.com/portfolio/utica-overland-frank-smullin-1980/ |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=PUBLIC ART AT QUEENS COLLEGE |language=en}}</ref> and MIT. Three pieces are also held at the Smithsonian Institute.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Record Standing Figure Eight, (sculpture) {{!}} Collections Search Center, Smithsonian Institution |url=https://collections.si.edu/search/detail/edanmdm:siris_ari_327222?q=Smullin,+Frank+Mayer&record=1&hlterm=Smullin,+Frank+Mayer |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=collections.si.edu}}</ref>

In 1981, Smullin gave a keynote lecture about his tubular sculptures and techniques at a design conference in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], paying particular attention to the [[Granny knot (mathematics)|granny-knot]], which he found to have "an artistically much more interesting, 3-dimensional structure than the functionally preferred, but much flatter [[Square knot (mathematics)|square-knot]]."<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal |last=Séquin |first=Carlo |date=2001 |title=Sculpture Design |url=https://www.computer.org/csdl/proceedings-article/vsmm/2001/14020832/12OmNz2kqnH |journal=Proceedings Seventh International Conference on Virtual Systems and MultiMedia Enhanced Realities: Augmented and Unplugged |pages=832 |doi=10.1109/VSMM.2001.969757}}</ref> Smullin had written a computer programme called SCULPT to assist with the vector analysis in his design process, implemented on a [[Tektronix 4050|Tektronix 4052]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Frank Smullin: Labayrinth of Data List – ACM SIGGRAPH ART SHOW ARCHIVES |url=https://digitalartarchive.siggraph.org/artwork/frank-smullin-labayrinth-of-data-list/ |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=digitalartarchive.siggraph.org}}</ref> He was calculating the elliptic intersections and producing computer-generated outlines of his sculptures which he would color by hand; he would then use a pen-plotter to produce a scale cardboard model, before finally cutting a rolling the final sheet-metal version; his techniques left a lasting influence on computer scientist [[Carlo H. Séquin|Carlo Séquin]], who was in the audience.<ref name=":3" />

'''Bundit Singprakarn''' ({{lang-th|บรรดิษฐ์ สิงห์ปราการ}}); is a Thai [[Muay Thai]] fighter who competed in the 1970s.

==Biography and career==
Bundit started to train at home with his father and was competing by the age of 15. He struggled in his first attempts in Bangkok where he was dismissed during two fights.

Bundit started to have success in the stadiums in 1971 withg a his strong middle kick style. A year later he won the [[Lumpinee Stadium]] 126 lbs title on December 8, 1972, against Denthoranee Muangsurin, he scored two knockdowns to win the belt by unanimous decision. He successfully defended his title and kept it until 1977 when he was dismissed during a fight against [[Sagat Petchyindee|Sagat Pontawee]]. During the 1970s Bundit defeated many champions of his era such as [[Sirimongkol Luksiripat]], [[Ruengsak Porntawee]], [[Vicharnnoi Porntawee]], [[Khunponnoi Kiatsuriya]] or [[Jocky Sitkanpai]].<ref>{{cite web |title=History of Muaythai Legends #55 Bundit Singprakan |url=https://www.facebook.com/MuaythaiIyarin/posts/1573695579629288 |website=facebook.com |publisher=Muay Siam Magazine |access-date=30 August 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=123 All-time greatest Muay Thai fighters of Thailand |page=101 |url=https://8limbsus.com/muay-thai-forum/uploads/monthly_2020_05/632791829_44-BundittSinghprakarn.jpg.eb4510a40fd8424b8cb7c27f0f48e782.jpg |access-date=31 August 2023}}</ref>

After his fighting career Bundit became a muay thaio trainer both in Thailand and Japan. He later opened a restaurant in his native province.

==Titles and accomplishments==
*'''[[Lumpinee Stadium]]'''
** 1972 Lumpinee Stadium Featherweight (126 lbs) Champion <small>(one denfense)</small>

name: Tor A. Kwembe
info:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tor_A._Kwembe

Reading Beans: AFC draft

{{AfC submission|t||ts=20230831094529|u=Weoir Yeni|ns=118|demo=}}
{{Short description|A Tiv - American diaspora mathematician}}
'''Tor Anthony Kwembe''' is a professor of mathematics and statistical sciences and a scholar at [[Jackson State University]] (JSU) in Jackson, Mississippi, US.<ref>{{cite web |title=Dr. Tor A. Kwembe – Department of Mathematics & Statistical Sciences |url=https://www.jsums.edu/math/tor-a-kwembe/ |website=Jackson State University}}</ref>

== Early life and education ==
Born in [[Gboko|Gboko,]] Nigeria, the prima city of the [[Tiv people]]. In 1989, Kwembe graduated from the [[University of Illinois Chicago|University of Illinois at Chicago]] (UIC) with a PhD in applied mathematics under the guidance of Professor Calixto Pedro Calderón,in 1983,<ref>{{cite web |title=PhD & DA Alumni {{!}} Dept of Math, Stat, & Comp Sci |url=https://mscs.uic.edu/graduate/people/phd-da-alumni/ |website=University of Illinois Chicago}}</ref> he graduated from the [[University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign|University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] with a [[master’s degree]] in mathematics, and in 1980, he graduated from the [[University of Calabar|University of Calabar in Calabar, Nigeria]] with a [[bachelor's degree]] in mathematics and statistics with honors.

He attended the Tiv Native Education Authority (NEA) Primary School Gboko Central at the tail end of the British Colony and the Mount Saint Michael’s Secondary School Aliade, Benue State, Nigeria completing both the fifth and sixth forms. Kwembe's father was Peter Wundu Kwembe, who served Nigeria as an [[Epidemiology|epidemiologist]] with the [[Northern Region, Nigeria|Northern Nigerian]] [[Tsetse fly|Tsetse]] and [[Trypanosomiasis]] Research Institute to eradicate [[Malaria|malaria,]] [[trypanosomiasis]], and [[sleeping sickness]] diseases caused respectively by [[Mosquito|mosquitoes]] and [[Tsetse fly|tsetse flies]] in [[Nigeria|Nigeria.]] His mother was Adzuai Margarete Kwembe who tutored him primary school arithmetic while nursing eight of them. Prior to joining JSU, he worked with the Department of Mathematics and Computer Science at [[Chicago State University]] (CSU) in [[Chicago|Chicago,]] [[Illinois]] in teaching, research, and various service responsibilities from August 1990 to August 2004 where he rose through the ranks and tenure to full Professor in 1998.

==Research work==
His early research interests were focused in [[biomathematics]], classical and [[Harmonic analysis]]. His current research interest is in the [[Mathematical model|mathematical]] and [[Statistics|statistical]] methods of Computational Data Enabled Science and Engineering (CDS&E) with emphasis on [[Big data analytics|Big Data Analytics,]] [[Visualization (graphics)|visualization]], and the enabling technologies applied to [[Artificial intelligence|Artificial Intelligence]]- Data Centric [[Machine learning|Machine Learning]] and [[Deep learning]].

== Selected publications ==
His papers that are currently most contributing to new knowledge are:
* Calderon, C. P., and Kwembe, T. A. (1991). "Modeling Tumor Growth.” [[Mathematical Biosciences]] Vol. 103, No. 1, pp. 97-114. doi.org/10.1016/0025-5564(91)90093-X.  
* Calderon, C. P., and Kwembe, T. A. (1991). "Dispersal Models.” Revista de la Union Matematica Argentina Volumen 37, pp. 212- 229.
* Kwembe, T. A. (2001). "Existence and uniqueness of global solutions for the parabolic equation of the bi-harmonic type." Nonlinear Analysis: Theory, Methods & Applications Vol. 47, No. 2, pp. 1321-1332. doi.org/10.1016/S0362-546X (01)00268-1.
* Hu, G., Wang, F., Lu, W., Kwembe, T. A., and Whalin, R. W. (2020). “Cooperative bypassing algorithm for connected and autonomous vehicles in mixed traffic.”  [[IET Intelligent Transport Systems]] Vol. 14, No. 8, pp. 915 – 923.
* Kwembe T.A. (2014).” Computational Analysis for a Mathematical Model of the Mechanics of Aneurysm Development and Rupture.” In: Georgakis C., Stokolos A., Urbina W. (eds) Special Functions, Partial Differential Equations, and Harmonic Analysis. Springer Proceedings in Mathematics & Statistics, vol. 108. Springer, Cham. <nowiki>https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-319-10545-1_11</nowiki>

On 31 August 2023, a fire engulfed a building in [[Johannesburg]], South Africa, killing at least 73 people and injuring 52 others.<ref name=reuters /><ref name=_1 /><ref name=_2 /><ref name=_3 /> The fire started around 1:30 a.m.<ref name="forbes1">{{Cite news |last=Hart |first=Robert |date=31 August 2023 |title=At Least 73 Killed In Johannesburg Fire, South African Officials Say |language=en |work=Forbes |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/roberthart/2023/08/31/at-least-73-killed-in-johannesburg-fire-south-african-officials-say/}}</ref>

The fire occurred in the [[Johannesburg CBD|Central Business District]] at a five-story abandoned building at the corner of Delvers and Albert Streets that was being used as informal housing by homeless people seeking shelter. According to witnesses, there had been up to 200 people living in the building.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Imray |first1=Gerald |last2=Magome |first2=Mogomotsi |title=A building fire in Johannesburg kills at least 73 people, many of them homeless, authorities say |url=https://apnews.com/article/fire-johannesburg-south-africa-dead-a365fc66541584e61ec5cd3e7b375e67 |work=AP News |date=31 August 2023 |language=en}}</ref>

Councillor [[Mgcini Tshwaku]] reported that partitions and gates inside the building prevented people from escaping.<ref>{{cite news |title=Joburg inner city building fire claims at least 73 lives |url=https://centralnews.co.za/joburg-inner-city-building-fire-claims-at-least-73-lives/ |work=Central News South Africa|date=31 August 2023 |language=en-ZA}}</ref>

}}{{ElectionsOR}}The '''2010 Oregon State Treasurer special election''' was held on November 2, 2010, to elect the [[Oregon State Treasurer]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Oregon Secretary of State |url=http://sos.oregon.gov/ |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=sos.oregon.gov |language=en}}</ref>

This election determined who would fill the remaining two years of the term of [[Ben Westlund]], who died in office from lung cancer earlier in the year. Incumbent [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] State Treasurer [[Ted Wheeler]], who was appointed by [[Governor of Oregon|Governor]] [[Ted Kulongoski]] to serve until this special election could be held, ran for election to the office. In primary elections held on May 18, Wheeler captured the Democratic nomination, and the Republicans picked [[Oregon State Senate|State Senator]] [[Chris Telfer]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Oregonian/OregonLive |first=Jeff Mapes {{!}} The |date=2010-03-10 |title=Ted Wheeler's appointment as state treasurer sets off filing day frenzy |url=https://www.oregonlive.com/politics/2010/03/ted_wheelers_appointment_as_st.html |access-date=2023-08-30 |website=oregonlive |language=en}}</ref>

Wheeler won the election, defeating Telfer and two third-party candidates handily.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Content Manager WebDrawer - 2010 Primary Election Official Results |url=http://records.sos.state.or.us/ORSOSWebDrawer/Recordhtml/6873663 |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=records.sos.state.or.us}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Content Manager WebDrawer - 2010 General Election Official Results |url=http://records.sos.state.or.us/ORSOSWebDrawer/Recordhtml/6873642 |access-date=2023-08-31 |website=records.sos.state.or.us}}</ref>

name: Volvarina bazini
info:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volvarina_bazini

Onel5969: clean up, typo(s) fixed: 10-15 → 10–15

{{Short description|Species of gastropod}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2023}}
{{Speciesbox
| image = Volvarina bazini (MNHN-IM-2000-1316).jpeg
| image_caption = Shell of ''Volvarina bazini'' (syntype at MNHN, Paris)
| taxon = Volvarina bazini
| authority =Jousseaume, 1875
| synonyms_ref =
| synonyms =
}}

'''''Volvarina bazini''''' is a [[species]] of [[sea snail]], a marine [[gastropod]] [[mollusk]] in the [[family (biology)|family]] [[Marginellidae]], the margin snails.<ref name="WoRMS">
MolluscaBase eds. (2023). MolluscaBase. Volvarina bazini Jousseaume, 1875. Accessed through: World Register of Marine Species at: https://www.marinespecies.org/aphia.php?p=taxdetails&id=474015 on 2023-08-31</ref>

==Description==
The length of the shell attains 6.4 mm, its diameter 2.5 mm.

The small shell small has the shape of an elongated ovoid. It is slightly narrower in front than behind. The shell is vitreous white, fairly solid, subtransparent, smooth and shiny. It is adorned, near the suture, with a yellowish-brown border, which allows, at first sight, to distinguish it from other species of the same genus.

The [[Spire (mollusc)|spire]] consists of four [[Whorl (mollusc)|whorl]]s, separated by a whitish linear suture, bordered outside by the yellowish-brown border that we have just mentioned. The first three whorls form, at the posterior end, a small mamillate [[protoconch]]. The [[body whorl]] constitutes almost the entire length of the shell.

The [[Aperture (mollusc)|aperture]] extends from one end of the shell to the other. It has the shape of a slit, narrower behind than in front. It widens noticeably at the level of the columellar plicae. It ends behind in a narrow and superficial channel, and ends in front in a broad and deep gutter. Its outer edge, almost straight, smooth and of a porcelain white, flows inwards at the level of its middle part. It is doubled on the outside by a fairly wide and projecting longitudinal bead, which originates behind on the penultimate whorl of which it does not exceed the posterior suture. The columellar edge, slightly sinuous, shows in front four projecting and oblique plicae.<ref>[https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/33047555 Jousseaume F. (1875). Coquilles de la famille des marginelles. Monographie. Revue et Magazin de Zoologie. ser. 3, 3: 164-271; 429-435.]</ref>

==Distribution==
This marine species occurs off [[Senegal]].

==References==
{{Reflist}}
* Cossignani T. & Lorenz F. (2020). Quattro nuove marginelle dalle Filippine. Malacologia Mostra Mondiale. 107: 10–15.

'''Hai Robotics''', fully referred to as Hai Robotics Co., Ltd., is a warehouse robotics manufacturer<ref>{{cite web | author=Rita Liao | title=China roundup: Meng Wanzhou's release and Huawei's future | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=September 26, 2021 | url=https://techcrunch.com/2021/09/26/china-roundup-meng-wanzhous-release-and-huaweis-future/ | archive-url=https://archive.ph/20230615082047/https://techcrunch.com/2021/09/26/china-roundup-meng-wanzhous-release-and-huaweis-future/ | archive-date=June 15, 2023 | url-status=live }}</ref> founded by Richie Chen in 2016.<ref>{{cite web | title=Hai Robotics Raises More Than $100 Million In D+ Financing Round | work=[[MENAFN]] | publisher=Robotics & Automation News | date=June 15, 2022 | url=https://menafn.com/1104377381/Hai-Robotics-Raises-More-Than-100-Million-In-D-Financing-Round |
